License: arXiv.org perpetual non-exclusive license
arXiv:2410.04907v1 [math.CO] 07 Oct 2024

Decomposition Polyhedra of Piecewise
Linear Functions

Marie-Charlotte Brandenburg
KTH Royal Institute of Technology
brandenburg@kth.se
&Moritz Grillo
Technische Universität Berlin
grillo@math.tu-berlin.de
&Christoph Hertrich
Université libre de Bruxelles
christoph.hertrich@ulb.be
Abstract

In this paper we contribute to the frequently studied question of how to decompose a continuous piecewise linear (CPWL) function into a difference of two convex CPWL functions. Every CPWL function has infinitely many such decompositions, but for applications in optimization and neural network theory, it is crucial to find decompositions with as few linear pieces as possible. This is a highly challenging problem, as we further demonstrate by disproving a recently proposed approach by Tran & Wang (2024). To make the problem more tractable, we propose to fix an underlying polyhedral complex determining the possible locus of nonlinearity. Under this assumption, we prove that the set of decompositions forms a polyhedron that arises as intersection of two translated cones. We prove that irreducible decompositions correspond to the bounded faces of this polyhedron and minimal solutions must be vertices. We then identify cases with a unique minimal decomposition, and illustrate how our insights have consequences in the theory of submodular functions. Finally, we improve upon previous constructions of neural networks for a given convex CPWL function and apply our framework to obtain results in the nonconvex case.

1 Introduction

Continuous piecewise linear (CPWL) functions play a crucial role in optimization and machine learning. While they have traditionally been used to describe problems in geometry, discrete and submodular optimization, or statistical regression, they recently gained significant interest as functions represented by neural networks with rectified linear unit (ReLU) activations (Arora et al., 2018). Extensive research has been put into understanding which neural network architectures are capable of representing which CPWL functions (Chen et al., 2022; Haase et al., 2023; Hertrich et al., 2021). A major source of complexity in all the aforementioned fields is nonconvexity. Indeed, not only are nonconvex optimization problems generally much harder to solve than convex ones, but also for neural networks, nonconvexities are usually responsible for making the obtained representations complicated.

It is a well-known folklore fact that every (potentially nonconvex) CWPL function f:ℝn→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R can be written as the difference f=g−h𝑓𝑔ℎf=g-hitalic_f = italic_g - italic_h of two convex CPWL functions (Melzer, 1986; Kripfganz & Schulze, 1987). Consequently, a natural idea to circumvent the challenges induced by nonconvexity is to use such a decomposition f=g−h𝑓𝑔ℎf=g-hitalic_f = italic_g - italic_h and solve the desired problem separately for g𝑔gitalic_g and hℎhitalic_h. This is the underlying idea of many successful optimization routines, known as DC programming (see survey by Le Thi & Pham Dinh (2018)), and also occurs in the analysis of neural networks (Zhang et al., 2018). However, the crucial question arising from this strategy is: how much more complex are g𝑔gitalic_g and hℎhitalic_h compared to f𝑓fitalic_f? A well-established measure for the complexity of a CPWL function is the number of its linear pieces. Therefore, the main question we study in this article is the following.

Problem 1.1.

How to decompose a CPWL function f𝑓fitalic_f into a difference f=g−h𝑓𝑔ℎf=g-hitalic_f = italic_g - italic_h of two convex CPWL functions with as few pieces as possible?

There exist many ways in the literature to obtain such a decomposition, as we discuss later, but none of them guarantees minimality or at least a useful bound on the number of pieces of g𝑔gitalic_g and hℎhitalic_h depending on those of f𝑓fitalic_f. In fact, no finite procedure is known that guarantees to find a minimal decomposition, despite a recent attempt by Tran & Wang (2024).

1.1 Our Contributions

In this article, we propose a novel perspective on 1.1 making use of polyhedral geometry and prove a number of structural results. We then apply our approach to existing decompositions in the literature, as well as to the theory of submodular functions and to the construction of neural networks representing a given CPWL function, serving as an additional motivation. Our detailed contributions are outlined as follows.

Decomposition Polyhedra.

After setting the preliminaries in Section 2, Section 3 presents our new polyhedral approach to 1.1. Instead of aiming for a globally optimal decomposition, we propose to restrict to solutions that are compatible with a given regular polyhedral complex 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. In short, this means fixing where the functions g𝑔gitalic_g and hℎhitalic_h may have breakpoints, that is, points where they are not locally linear. We prove that the set of solutions to decompose f𝑓fitalic_f in a way that is compatible with 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is a polyhedron 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) that arises as the intersection of two shifted polyhedral cones. We call this the decomposition polyhedron of f𝑓fitalic_f with respect to 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. We prove several structural properties of 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ). Among them, we show that the bounded faces of 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) are exactly those that cannot easily be simplified by subtracting a convex function, and we show that a minimal solution must be a vertex of 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ). The latter implies a finite procedure to find a minimal decomposition among those that are compatible with 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P, by simply enumerating the vertices of 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ). It also implies that, if only a single vertex exists, then there is a unique minimal decomposition. We demonstrate that this is indeed the case for important CPWL functions, e.g., the median function, or those computed by a 1-hidden-layer ReLU network.

Existing Decompositions.

Afterwards, in Section 4, we put our investigations into a broader context within the existing literature. We compare our minimality conditions with existing methods to construct decompositions. Notably, in this context, we refute a conjecture by Tran & Wang (2024), who provide an optimal construction method in dimension 2 and suggest that it might generalize to higher dimensions. We show that it does not.

Applications to Submodular Function.

In Section 5, we show that our framework entails the setup of set functions which are decomposed into differences of submodular set functions. Representing a set function as such a difference is a popular approach to solve optimization problems similarly to DC programming, see Narasimhan & Bilmes (2005); Iyer & Bilmes (2012); El Halabi et al. (2023). We apply our results from Section 3 to obtain analogous structural insights about (submodular) set functions.

Application to Neural Network Constructions.

Finally, in Section 6, we study the problem of constructing neural networks representing a given CPWL function. For convex CPWL functions, we blend two incomparable previous constructions by Hertrich et al. (2021) and Chen et al. (2022) to let the user freely choose a trade-off between depth and width of the constructed networks. We then apply the results of this paper to extend this to the nonconvex case by first decomposing the input function as a difference of two convex ones.

Limitations.

We emphasize that the focus of our paper is fundamental research by building a theoretical foundation to tackle 1.1 and connecting it with other fields. As such, our paper does not imply any direct improvement for a practical task, but it might prove helpful for that in the future. In particular, it is beyond the scope of our paper to provide any implementation of a (heuristic or exact) method to decompose a CPWL function into a difference of two convex ones. We consider it an exciting avenue for future research to do so, and to apply it to DC programming, discrete optimization, or neural networks.

On the theoretical side, the approach of fixing an underlying compatible polyhedral complex imposes some restriction on the set of possible solutions and can therefore be seen as a limitation. However, we think that this assumption is well justified by the structural properties this assumption allows us to infer and by the examples we demonstrate to fit into the framework. Even with this assumption, the problem remains very challenging.

1.2 Further Related Work

Explicit constructions to decompose CPWL functions as differences of convex CPWL functions can be found in several articles, such as Kripfganz & Schulze (1987); Zalgaller (2000); Wang (2004); Schlüter & Darup (2021). This was initiated in the 1111-dimensional case by Bittner (1970), and already laid out for positively homogeneous functions in general dimensions by Melzer (1986). Typically, such decompositions are based on certain representations of CPWL functions, which have been constructed, e.g., in Tarela & Martinez (1999); Ovchinnikov (2002); Wang & Sun (2005); see also Koutschan et al. (2023; 2024) for a fresh perspective. These representations also help to understand the representative capabilities of neural networks, see Arora et al. (2018); Hertrich et al. (2021); Chen et al. (2022).

Recently, a minimal decomposition for the 2222-dimensional case was given by Tran & Wang (2024). They use a duality between CPWL functions and polyhedral geometry, based on the “balancing condition” from tropical geometry. This condition has already been studied by McMullen (1996) in terms of weight spaces of polytopes. Generally, methods from tropical geometry have been successfully used to understand the geometry of neural networks, see e.g. Zhang et al. (2018); Hertrich et al. (2021); Montúfar et al. (2022); Haase et al. (2023); Brandenburg et al. (2024).

Submodular functions are sometimes called the discrete analogue of convex functions, and optimizing over them is a widely studied problem, which is also relevant for machine learning. A submodular function can be minimized in polynomial time (Grötschel et al., 1981). In analogy to DC programming, this sparked the idea of minimizing a general set function by representing it as a difference of two submodular ones (Narasimhan & Bilmes, 2005; Iyer & Bilmes, 2012; El Halabi et al., 2023). Related decompositions were recently studied by Bérczi et al. (2024). In polyhderal theory, such a decomposition is equivalent to Minkowski differences of generalized permutahedra (Ardila et al., 2009; Jochemko & Ravichandran, 2022).

Another closely related stream of work is concerned with the (exact and approximate) representative capabilities of neural networks, starting with universal approximation theorems (Cybenko, 1989), and specializing to ReLU networks, their number of pieces, as well as depth-width-tradeoffs (Telgarsky, 2016; Eldan & Shamir, 2016; Arora et al., 2018). In addition, Hertrich & Skutella (2023); Hertrich & Sering (2024) provide neural network constructions for CPWL functions related to combinatorial optimization problems. Geometric insights have also proven to be useful to understand the computational complexity of training neural networks (Froese et al., 2022; Bertschinger et al., 2024; Froese & Hertrich, 2024). Recently, Safran et al. (2024) give an explicit construction of how to efficiently approximate the maximum function with ReLU networks.

2 Preliminaries

In this section we introduce the necessary preliminaries on polyhedral geometry and CPWL functions. For m∈ℕ𝑚ℕm\in\mathbb{N}italic_m ∈ blackboard_N, we write [m]≔{1,2,…,m}≔delimited-[]𝑚12…𝑚[m]\coloneqq\{1,2,\dots,m\}[ italic_m ] ≔ { 1 , 2 , … , italic_m }.

Polyhedra and Polyhedral Complexes.

A polyhedron P𝑃Pitalic_P is the intersection of finitely many closed halfspaces and a polytope is a bounded polyhedron. A hyperplane supports P𝑃Pitalic_P if it bounds a closed halfspace containing P𝑃Pitalic_P, and any intersection of P𝑃Pitalic_P with such a supporting hyperplane yields a face F𝐹Fitalic_F of P𝑃Pitalic_P. A face is a proper face if F⊊P𝐹𝑃F\subsetneq Pitalic_F ⊊ italic_P and inclusion-maximal proper faces are referred to as facets. A polyhedral cone C⊆ℝn𝐶superscriptℝ𝑛C\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_C ⊆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a polyhedron such that λ⁢u+μ⁢v∈C𝜆𝑢𝜇𝑣𝐶\lambda u+\mu v\in Citalic_λ italic_u + italic_μ italic_v ∈ italic_C for every u,v∈C𝑢𝑣𝐶u,v\in Citalic_u , italic_v ∈ italic_C and λ,μ∈ℝ≥0𝜆𝜇subscriptℝabsent0\lambda,\mu\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}italic_λ , italic_μ ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The dual cone of C𝐶Citalic_C is C∨={y∈(ℝn)∗∣⟨x,y⟩≥0⁢ for all ⁢x∈C}.superscript𝐶conditional-set𝑦superscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑛𝑥𝑦0 for all 𝑥𝐶C^{\vee}=\{y\in(\mathbb{R}^{n})^{*}\mid\langle x,y\rangle\geq 0\text{ for all % }x\in C\}.italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∨ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { italic_y ∈ ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ ⟨ italic_x , italic_y ⟩ ≥ 0 for all italic_x ∈ italic_C } . A cone is pointed if it does not contain a line. A cone C𝐶Citalic_C is simplicial, if there are linearly independent vectors v1,…,vk∈ℝnsubscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑘superscriptℝ𝑛v_{1},\ldots,v_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that C={∑i=1kλi⁢vi∣λi≥0}𝐶conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖0C=\{\sum_{i=1}^{k}\lambda_{i}v_{i}\mid\lambda_{i}\geq 0\}italic_C = { ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0 }. For a cone C𝐶Citalic_C and t∈ℝn𝑡superscriptℝ𝑛t\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_t ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we call t+C𝑡𝐶t+Citalic_t + italic_C a shifted cone or translated cone.

A polyhedral complex 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is a finite collection of polyhedra such that (i) ∅∈𝒫𝒫\emptyset\in\mathcal{P}∅ ∈ caligraphic_P, (ii) if P∈𝒫𝑃𝒫P\in\mathcal{P}italic_P ∈ caligraphic_P then all faces of P𝑃Pitalic_P are in 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P, and (iii) if P,P′∈𝒫𝑃superscript𝑃′𝒫P,P^{\prime}\in\mathcal{P}italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_P, then P∩P′𝑃superscript𝑃′P\cap P^{\prime}italic_P ∩ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a face both of P𝑃Pitalic_P and P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For a polyhedral complex 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P in ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we denote by 𝒫dsuperscript𝒫𝑑\mathcal{P}^{d}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the set of d𝑑ditalic_d-dimensional polyhedra in 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. Given two n𝑛nitalic_n-dimensional polyhedral complexes 𝒫,𝒬𝒫𝒬\mathcal{P},\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_Q, the complex 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is a refinement of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q if for every τ∈𝒫n𝜏superscript𝒫𝑛\tau\in\mathcal{P}^{n}italic_τ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT there exists σ∈𝒬n𝜎superscript𝒬𝑛\sigma\in\mathcal{Q}^{n}italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that τ⊆σ𝜏𝜎\tau\subseteq\sigmaitalic_τ ⊆ italic_σ. The complex 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q is a coarsening of 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P if 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is a refinement of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q.

The star of a face τ∈𝒫𝜏𝒫\tau\in\mathcal{P}italic_τ ∈ caligraphic_P is the set of all faces containing τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, i.e., star𝒫⁡(τ)={σ∈𝒫∣τ⊆σ}subscriptstar𝒫𝜏conditional-set𝜎𝒫𝜏𝜎\operatorname{star}_{\mathcal{P}}(\tau)=\{\sigma\in\mathcal{P}\mid\tau% \subseteq\sigma\}roman_star start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_τ ) = { italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P ∣ italic_τ ⊆ italic_σ }. We only consider complete polyhedral complexes, that is, complexes which cover ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A polyhedral fan is a polyhedral complex in which every polyhedron is a cone.

An n𝑛nitalic_n-dimensional polyhedral complex can be equipped with a weight function w:𝒫n−1→ℝ:𝑤→superscript𝒫𝑛1ℝw:\mathcal{P}^{n-1}\to\mathbb{R}italic_w : caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R, as we describe as follows. Given a face σ∈𝒫𝜎𝒫\sigma\in\mathcal{P}italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P, we denote by aff⁡(σ)⊆ℝnaff𝜎superscriptℝ𝑛\operatorname{aff}(\sigma)\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{n}roman_aff ( italic_σ ) ⊆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the unique smallest affine subspace containing σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ. The relative interior of σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ is the interior of σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ inside the affine space aff⁡(σ)aff𝜎\operatorname{aff}(\sigma)roman_aff ( italic_σ ). For any dimension d≤n𝑑𝑛d\leq nitalic_d ≤ italic_n and any τ∈𝒫d−1,σ∈𝒫dformulae-sequence𝜏superscript𝒫𝑑1𝜎superscript𝒫𝑑\tau\in\mathcal{P}^{d-1},\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{d}italic_τ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with τ⊆σ𝜏𝜎\tau\subseteq\sigmaitalic_τ ⊆ italic_σ, let eσ/τ∈ℝnsubscript𝑒𝜎𝜏superscriptℝ𝑛e_{\sigma/\tau}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ / italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the normal vector of τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ with respect to σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ, that is, the unique vector with length one that is parallel to aff⁡(σ)aff𝜎\operatorname{aff}(\sigma)roman_aff ( italic_σ ), orthogonal to aff⁡(τ)aff𝜏\operatorname{aff}(\tau)roman_aff ( italic_τ ), and points from the relative interior of τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ into the relative interior of σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ. A pair (𝒫,w)𝒫𝑤(\mathcal{P},w)( caligraphic_P , italic_w ) forms a balanced (weighted) polyhedral complex if the weight function satisfies the balancing condition at every τ∈𝒫n−2𝜏superscript𝒫𝑛2\tau\in\mathcal{P}^{n-2}italic_τ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT:

∑σ∈𝒫n−1:σ⊃τw⁢(σ)⋅eσ/τ=0subscript:𝜎superscript𝒫𝑛1absent𝜏𝜎⋅𝑤𝜎subscript𝑒𝜎𝜏0\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}:\\ \sigma\supset\tau\end{subarray}}w(\sigma)\cdot e_{\sigma/\tau}=0∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_σ ⊃ italic_τ end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w ( italic_σ ) ⋅ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ / italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0

Continuous Piecewise Linear Functions.

A function f:ℝn→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R is called continuous and piecewise linear (CPWL), if there exists a polyhedral complex 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P such that the restriction of f𝑓fitalic_f to each full-dimensional polyhedron P∈𝒫n𝑃superscript𝒫𝑛P\in\mathcal{P}^{n}italic_P ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an affine function. If this condition is satisfied, we say that f𝑓fitalic_f and 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P are compatible with each other.

In line with Chen et al. (2022), we define the number of pieces q𝑞qitalic_q of f𝑓fitalic_f to be the smallest possible number |𝒫n|superscript𝒫𝑛\lvert\mathcal{P}^{n}\rvert| caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | of full-dimensional regions of a compatible polyhedral complex 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. Note that this requires pieces to be convex sets, as they are polyhedra. The function f𝑓fitalic_f might realize the same affine function on distinct pieces P,Q∈𝒫n𝑃𝑄superscript𝒫𝑛P,Q\in\mathcal{P}^{n}italic_P , italic_Q ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. To account for that, we define the number of affine components k𝑘kitalic_k to be the the number of different affine functions realized on all the pieces in 𝒫nsuperscript𝒫𝑛\mathcal{P}^{n}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that this quantity is independent of the choice of the particular compatible complex 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P.

It holds that k≤q≤k!𝑘𝑞𝑘k\leq q\leq k!italic_k ≤ italic_q ≤ italic_k ! and each of these inequalities can be strict, compare the discussion by Chen et al. (2022). We can assume that k>n𝑘𝑛k>nitalic_k > italic_n (and thus q>n𝑞𝑛q>nitalic_q > italic_n) because otherwise f𝑓fitalic_f can be written as a composition of an affine projection to a lower dimension n′superscript𝑛′n^{\prime}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT followed by a CPWL function defined on ℝn′superscriptℝsuperscript𝑛′\mathbb{R}^{n^{\prime}}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

If f𝑓fitalic_f is a convex CPWL function, then it can be written as the maximum of finitely many affine functions f⁢(x)=maxi∈[k]⁡gi⁢(x)𝑓𝑥subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑘subscript𝑔𝑖𝑥f(x)=\max_{i\in[k]}g_{i}(x)italic_f ( italic_x ) = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_k ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ). It follows that there is a unique coarsest compatible polyhedral complex 𝒫fsubscript𝒫𝑓\mathcal{P}_{f}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, namely the one with 𝒫fn={{x∣gi⁢(x)=maxj⁡gj⁢(x)}∣i∈[k]}superscriptsubscript𝒫𝑓𝑛conditional-setconditional-set𝑥subscript𝑔𝑖𝑥subscript𝑗subscript𝑔𝑗𝑥𝑖delimited-[]𝑘\mathcal{P}_{f}^{n}=\{\{x\mid g_{i}(x)=\max_{j}g_{j}(x)\}\mid i\in[k]\}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { { italic_x ∣ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) } ∣ italic_i ∈ [ italic_k ] }. In particular, we have k=q𝑘𝑞k=qitalic_k = italic_q if f𝑓fitalic_f is convex. We call a polyhedral complex 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P regular, if there exists a convex CPWL function f𝑓fitalic_f such that 𝒫=𝒫f𝒫subscript𝒫𝑓\mathcal{P}=\mathcal{P}_{f}caligraphic_P = caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

3 Decomposition Polyhedra

In this section, we introduce and generally study the main concept of the paper, decomposition polyhedra. These polyhedra describe the set of possible decompositions of a CPWL function f𝑓fitalic_f into a difference f=g−h𝑓𝑔ℎf=g-hitalic_f = italic_g - italic_h that are compatible with a given polyhedral complex. We start by establishing a handful of general results concerning the space of CPWL functions compatible with a given polyhedral complex. Proofs that are omitted from the main text as well as some auxiliary statements can be found in Appendix E.

Lemma 3.1.

Let 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P be a polyhredral complex. The set of CPWL functions compatible with 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P forms a linear subspace 𝒱𝒫subscript𝒱𝒫\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the space of continuous functions.

Let Aff⁡(ℝn)Affsuperscriptℝ𝑛\operatorname{Aff}(\mathbb{R}^{n})roman_Aff ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) be the space of affine functions from ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to ℝℝ\mathbb{R}blackboard_R. For many of our arguments, adding or subtracting an affine function a∈Aff⁡(ℝn)𝑎Affsuperscriptℝ𝑛a\in\operatorname{Aff}(\mathbb{R}^{n})italic_a ∈ roman_Aff ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) does not change anything. In particular, a function f𝑓fitalic_f is convex if and only if f+a𝑓𝑎f+aitalic_f + italic_a is convex. Therefore it makes sense to define the quotient space 𝒱¯𝒫≔𝒱𝒫/Aff⁡(ℝn)≔subscript¯𝒱𝒫subscript𝒱𝒫Affsuperscriptℝ𝑛\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}\coloneqq\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}/% \operatorname{Aff}(\mathbb{R}^{n})over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / roman_Aff ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where we identify functions in 𝒱𝒫subscript𝒱𝒫\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that only differ by adding an affine function. The following lemma shows that we can parameterize a function f∈𝒱¯𝒫𝑓subscript¯𝒱𝒫f\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by keeping track of “how convex or concave” the function is at the common face σ∈𝒫n−1𝜎superscript𝒫𝑛1\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of two neighboring pieces. For the case that w𝑤witalic_w is nonnegative and rational, the lemma follows from the structure theorem of tropical geometry (Maclagan & Sturmfels, 2015). In Section E.2, we present a generalization of the proof adapted to our setting.

Lemma 3.2.

The vector space 𝒲𝒫≔{w:𝒫n−1→ℝ∣(𝒫,w)\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}\coloneqq\{w\colon\mathcal{P}^{n-1}\to\mathbb{R}\mid(% \mathcal{P},w)caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ { italic_w : caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R ∣ ( caligraphic_P , italic_w ) is balanced}}\}} is isomorphic to 𝒱¯𝒫subscript¯𝒱𝒫\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Figure 1 illustrates the different parameterizations of the median function according to Lemma 3.2. Moreover, from Lemma 3.2 we can deduce that 𝒱𝒫subscript𝒱𝒫\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is finite-dimensional (Corollary E.1) and the following proposition.

Proposition 3.3.

A function f∈𝒱𝒫𝑓subscript𝒱𝒫f\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is convex if and only if wfsubscript𝑤𝑓w_{f}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is nonnegative. Moreover, f𝑓fitalic_f is convex with 𝒫=𝒫f𝒫subscript𝒫𝑓\mathcal{P}=\mathcal{P}_{f}caligraphic_P = caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT if and only if wfsubscript𝑤𝑓w_{f}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is strictly positive.

The set 𝒱¯𝒫+superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of convex functions in 𝒱¯𝒫subscript¯𝒱𝒫\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT forms a polyhedral cone (Lemma E.2). In the following, we now fix a function f∈𝒱𝒫𝑓subscript𝒱𝒫f\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and consider the space of decompositions f=g−h𝑓𝑔ℎf=g-hitalic_f = italic_g - italic_h into differences of convex functions which are also compatible with 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. In Lemma E.3, we show that for a regular complex 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P such a decomposition does indeed always exist. In particular, 𝒱¯𝒫=span⁡(𝒱¯𝒫+)subscript¯𝒱𝒫spansuperscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}=\operatorname{span}(\overline{\mathcal{V}% }_{\mathcal{P}}^{+})over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_span ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), which implies that dim(𝒱¯𝒫)=dim(𝒱¯𝒫+)dimensionsubscript¯𝒱𝒫dimensionsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫\dim(\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}})=\dim(\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{% \mathcal{P}}^{+})roman_dim ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = roman_dim ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

Definition 3.4.

For a CPWL function f𝑓fitalic_f and a polyhedral complex 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P, the decomposition polyhedron of f𝑓fitalic_f with respect to 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)≔{(g,h)∣g,h∈𝒱¯𝒫+,f=g−h}.≔subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓conditional-set𝑔ℎformulae-sequence𝑔ℎsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫𝑓𝑔ℎ\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)\coloneqq\{(g,h)\mid g,h\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_% {\mathcal{P}}^{+},f=g-h\}.caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ≔ { ( italic_g , italic_h ) ∣ italic_g , italic_h ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_f = italic_g - italic_h } .

The projection π⁢((g,h))=g𝜋𝑔ℎ𝑔\pi((g,h))=gitalic_π ( ( italic_g , italic_h ) ) = italic_g induces an isomorphism between 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) and π⁢(𝒟𝒫⁢(f))𝜋subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))italic_π ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) since 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)={(g,g−f)∣g∈π⁢(𝒟𝒫⁢(f))}.subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓conditional-set𝑔𝑔𝑓𝑔𝜋subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)=\{(g,g-f)\mid g\in\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f% ))\}.caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) = { ( italic_g , italic_g - italic_f ) ∣ italic_g ∈ italic_π ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) } . We now show that this is indeed a polyhedron, which arises as the intersection of two shifted copies of a cone.

Theorem 3.5.

The set 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) is a polyhedron that arises as the intersection of convex functions with an affine hyperplane Hf={(g,h)∣f=g−h}subscript𝐻𝑓conditional-set𝑔ℎ𝑓𝑔ℎH_{f}=\{(g,h)\mid f=g-h\}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { ( italic_g , italic_h ) ∣ italic_f = italic_g - italic_h }, namely 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)=(𝒱¯𝒫+×𝒱¯𝒫+)∩Hf.subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫subscript𝐻𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)=(\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\times% \overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+})\cap H_{f}.caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) = ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT × over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∩ italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . Under the bijection π𝜋\piitalic_π, the decomposition polyhedron is the intersection of two shifted copies of the polyhedral cone 𝒱¯𝒫+superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. More specifically, π⁢(𝒟𝒫⁢(f))=𝒱¯𝒫+∩(𝒱¯𝒫++f).𝜋subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫𝑓\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))=\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\cap% (\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}+f).italic_π ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) = over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∩ ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_f ) .

Remark 3.6.

Under the isomorphism of Lemma 3.2, we identify 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) with the polyhedron {(wg,wh)∈𝒲𝒫+×𝒲𝒫+∣wg−wh=wf}conditional-setsubscript𝑤𝑔subscript𝑤ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝒲𝒫superscriptsubscript𝒲𝒫subscript𝑤𝑔subscript𝑤ℎsubscript𝑤𝑓\{(w_{g},w_{h})\in\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\times\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}% ^{+}\mid w_{g}-w_{h}=w_{f}\}{ ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT × caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } in 𝒲𝒫×𝒲𝒫subscript𝒲𝒫subscript𝒲𝒫\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}\times\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT × caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and π⁢(𝒟𝒫⁢(f))𝜋subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))italic_π ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) with the polyhedron {wg∈𝒲𝒫+∣wg≥wf}conditional-setsubscript𝑤𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒲𝒫subscript𝑤𝑔subscript𝑤𝑓\{w_{g}\in\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\mid w_{g}\geq w_{f}\}{ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, where 𝒲𝒫+={w∈𝒲𝒫∣w≥0}superscriptsubscript𝒲𝒫conditional-set𝑤subscript𝒲𝒫𝑤0\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}=\{w\in\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}\mid w\geq 0\}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { italic_w ∈ caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_w ≥ 0 }.

For the remainder of this section, we analyze the faces of the polyhedron 𝒱¯𝒫+superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in terms of the properties of the corresponding decompositions.

Definition 3.7.

A decomposition (g,h)∈𝒟𝒫⁢(f)𝑔ℎsubscript𝒟𝒫𝑓(g,h)\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)( italic_g , italic_h ) ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) is called reduced, if there is no convex function ϕ∈𝒱¯𝒫+∖{0}italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫0\phi\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\setminus\{0\}italic_ϕ ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∖ { 0 } such that g−ϕ𝑔italic-ϕg-\phiitalic_g - italic_ϕ and h−ϕℎitalic-ϕh-\phiitalic_h - italic_ϕ are both convex.

If a decomposition is not reduced, then we can obtain a “better” decomposition by simultaneously simplifying both g𝑔gitalic_g and hℎhitalic_h through subtracting a convex function ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ. Hence, it makes sense to put a special emphasis on reduced decompositions. Conveniently, the following theorem links this notion to the geometry of 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ).

Theorem 3.8.

A decomposition (g,h)∈𝒟𝒫⁢(f)𝑔ℎsubscript𝒟𝒫𝑓(g,h)\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)( italic_g , italic_h ) ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) is reduced if and only if (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is contained in a bounded face of 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ).

Definition 3.9.

We call a convex function g∈𝒱¯𝒫+𝑔superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫g\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}italic_g ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT a coarsening of another convex function g′∈𝒱¯𝒫+superscript𝑔′superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫g^{\prime}\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if the unique coarsest polyhedral complex 𝒫gsubscript𝒫𝑔\mathcal{P}_{g}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of g𝑔gitalic_g is a coarsening of the unique coarsest polyhedral complex 𝒫g′subscript𝒫superscript𝑔′\mathcal{P}_{g^{\prime}}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For a pair of convex CPWL functions (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ), we call (g′,h′)superscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) a coarsening of (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) if g−h=g′−h′𝑔ℎsuperscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′g-h=g^{\prime}-h^{\prime}italic_g - italic_h = italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and g𝑔gitalic_g and hℎhitalic_h are coarsenings of g′superscript𝑔′g^{\prime}italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and h′superscriptℎ′h^{\prime}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT respectively. The coarsening is called non-trivial if (𝒫g,𝒫h)≠(𝒫g′,𝒫h′)subscript𝒫𝑔subscript𝒫ℎsubscript𝒫superscript𝑔′subscript𝒫superscriptℎ′(\mathcal{P}_{g},\mathcal{P}_{h})\neq(\mathcal{P}_{g^{\prime}},\mathcal{P}_{h^% {\prime}})( caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≠ ( caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). For a function f∈𝒱𝒫𝑓subscript𝒱𝒫f\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, let supp𝒫⁡(f)={σ∈𝒫n−1∣wg⁢(σ)≠0}subscriptsupp𝒫𝑓conditional-set𝜎superscript𝒫𝑛1subscript𝑤𝑔𝜎0\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)=\{\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}\mid w_{g}(% \sigma)\neq 0\}roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) = { italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ ) ≠ 0 }.

Lemma 3.10.

A convex function g′∈𝒱¯𝒫+superscript𝑔′superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫g^{\prime}\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a coarsening of g∈𝒱¯𝒫+𝑔superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫g\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}italic_g ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if and only if supp𝒫⁡(g′)⊆supp𝒫⁡(g)subscriptsupp𝒫superscript𝑔′subscriptsupp𝒫𝑔\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}({g^{\prime}})\subseteq\operatorname{supp}_{% \mathcal{P}}(g)roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ⊆ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ). The coarsening is non-trivial if and only if supp𝒫⁡(g′)⊂supp𝒫⁡(g)subscriptsupp𝒫superscript𝑔′subscriptsupp𝒫𝑔\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}({g^{\prime}})\subset\operatorname{supp}_{% \mathcal{P}}(g)roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ⊂ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ).

Theorem 3.11.

Let (g,h)∈𝒟𝒫⁢(f)𝑔ℎsubscript𝒟𝒫𝑓(g,h)\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)( italic_g , italic_h ) ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ), then the following three statements are equivalent:

  1. 1.

    There is no non-trivial coarsening of (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ).

  2. 2.

    (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is a vertex of 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ).

  3. 3.

    (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is a vertex of 𝒟𝒬⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒬𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{Q}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) for all polyhedral complexes 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q compatible with g𝑔gitalic_g and hℎhitalic_h.

Definition 3.12.

A decomposition (g,h)∈𝒟𝒫⁢(f)𝑔ℎsubscript𝒟𝒫𝑓(g,h)\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)( italic_g , italic_h ) ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) is called minimal, if it is not dominated by any other decomposition, that is, if there is no other decomposition (g′,h′)∈𝒟𝒫⁢(f)superscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) where g′superscript𝑔′g^{\prime}italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has at most as many pieces as g𝑔gitalic_g, h′superscriptℎ′h^{\prime}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has at most as many pieces as hℎhitalic_h, and one of the two has stricly fewer pieces. See Figure 2 in Section A.2 for a visualization.

The number of pieces relates to the notion of monomial complexity studied in Tran & Wang (2024), and a minimal decomposition translates to a decomposition which is minimal with respect to monomial complexity. We now give a geometric interpretation of this property in term of 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ).

Theorem 3.13.

A minimal decomposition (g,h)∈𝒟𝒫⁢(f)𝑔ℎsubscript𝒟𝒫𝑓(g,h)\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)( italic_g , italic_h ) ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) is always a vertex of 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ).

This theorem implies a simple finite procedure to find a minimal decomposition: enumerate all the vertices of 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) and choose one satisfying Definition 3.12. It also suggests the following important special case.

Proposition 3.14.

If 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ), or equivalently π⁢(𝒟𝒫⁢(f))𝜋subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))italic_π ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ), has a unique vertex, then this vertex corresponds to the unique minimal decomposition within 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ).

We now demonstrate that this case is not only convenient, but also it indeed arises for important classes of functions. To this end, recall that π⁢(𝒟𝒫⁢(f))=𝒱¯𝒫+∩(𝒱¯𝒫++f)𝜋subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫𝑓\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))=\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\cap% (\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}+f)italic_π ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) = over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∩ ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_f ), where 𝒱¯𝒫+superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a convex, pointed polyhedral cone. In Lemma E.6, we give some sufficient conditions for such intersections of shifted cones to yield a polyhedron with a unique vertex. Moreover, the support of a decomposition can serve as certificate to verify if a decomposition is a unique vertex, and hence minimal. For f∈𝒱¯𝒫+𝑓superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫f\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}italic_f ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, let supp𝒫+⁡(f)≔{σ∈𝒫∣wf⁢(σ)>0}≔superscriptsubscriptsupp𝒫𝑓conditional-set𝜎𝒫subscript𝑤𝑓𝜎0\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}(f)\coloneqq\{\sigma\in\mathcal{P}\mid w_% {f}(\sigma)>0\}roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ≔ { italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P ∣ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ ) > 0 } and supp𝒫−⁡(f)≔{σ∈𝒫∣wf⁢(σ)<0}≔superscriptsubscriptsupp𝒫𝑓conditional-set𝜎𝒫subscript𝑤𝑓𝜎0\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}^{-}(f)\coloneqq\{\sigma\in\mathcal{P}\mid w_% {f}(\sigma)<0\}roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ≔ { italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P ∣ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ ) < 0 }.

Proposition 3.15.

If for f∈𝒱¯𝒫𝑓subscript¯𝒱𝒫f\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, there are g,h∈𝒱¯𝒫+𝑔ℎsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫g,h\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}italic_g , italic_h ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that f=g−h𝑓𝑔ℎf=g-hitalic_f = italic_g - italic_h and supp+⁡(f)=supp𝒫⁡(g)superscriptsupp𝑓subscriptsupp𝒫𝑔\operatorname{supp}^{+}(f)=\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(g)roman_supp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_f ) = roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ) as well as supp−⁡(f)=supp𝒫⁡(h)superscriptsupp𝑓subscriptsupp𝒫ℎ\operatorname{supp}^{-}(f)=\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(h)roman_supp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_f ) = roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_h ), then (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is the unique vertex of 𝒟𝒬⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒬𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{Q}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) for every regular complete complex 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q compatible with f𝑓fitalic_f. In this case, g𝑔gitalic_g and hℎhitalic_h have at most as many pieces as f𝑓fitalic_f.

While Proposition 3.15 sounds technical, it is powerful as it allows us to prove that important functions satisfy the condition of Proposition 3.14.

Definition 3.16.

A hyperplane function with k𝑘kitalic_k hyperplanes is a function f:ℝn→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R given by f⁢(x)=∑i∈[k]λi⋅max⁡{⟨x,ai⟩+bi,⟨x,ci⟩+di}𝑓𝑥subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑘⋅subscript𝜆𝑖𝑥subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖𝑥subscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖f(x)=\sum_{i\in[k]}\lambda_{i}\cdot\max\{\langle x,a_{i}\rangle+b_{i},\langle x% ,c_{i}\rangle+d_{i}\}italic_f ( italic_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_k ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ roman_max { ⟨ italic_x , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⟨ italic_x , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } for any ai,ci∈ℝn,bi,di,λi∈ℝ,i∈[k]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑐𝑖superscriptℝ𝑛subscript𝑏𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖ℝ𝑖delimited-[]𝑘a_{i},c_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n},b_{i},d_{i},\lambda_{i}\in\mathbb{R},i\in[k]italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R , italic_i ∈ [ italic_k ].

Hyperplane functions are precisely the functions that are computable by a ReLU neural network with one hidden layer and appear in this context as 2-term max functions (Hertrich et al. (2021)). They also coincide with functions computable with the hinging hyperplane model (Breiman (1993); Wang & Sun (2005)). Moreover, in Example D.14 we will see that hyperplane functions include continuous extensions of cut functions.

Definition 3.17.

The k𝑘kitalic_k-th order statistic is the function f:ℝn→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R that returns the k𝑘kitalic_k-th largest entry of an input vector x∈ℝn𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For k=⌊n2⌋𝑘𝑛2k=\lfloor\frac{n}{2}\rflooritalic_k = ⌊ divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ⌋, this coincides with the median.

In Section A.3, we show that the conditions of Propositions 3.14 and 3.15 are indeed fulfilled for both, hyperplane functions and k𝑘kitalic_k-th order statistics. This shows that they admit decompositions with at most as many pieces as the function itself.

Theorem 3.8 characterizes the reduced decompositions as bounded faces and Proposition 3.15 provides a condition that can identify a given decomposition as the minimal one. The natural follow-up question is how to find these decompositions. In the following, we show that this can be done via linear programming over the decomposition polyhedron.

Theorem 3.18.

A decomposition in π⁢(𝒟𝒫⁢(f))=𝒱¯𝒫+∩(f+𝒱¯𝒫+)𝜋subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫𝑓superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))=\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\cap% (f+\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+})italic_π ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) = over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∩ ( italic_f + over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is reduced if and only if it is the minimizer in π⁢(𝒟𝒫⁢(f))𝜋subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))italic_π ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) of a direction contained in the interior of the dual cone of 𝒱¯𝒫+superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In particular, if π⁢(𝒟𝒫⁢(f))𝜋subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))italic_π ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) has a single vertex, then the unique minimizer is the unique reduced and minimal decomposition. Under the isomorphism to 𝒲𝒫subscript𝒲𝒫\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the direction u𝑢uitalic_u can be chosen as u⁢(σ)=1𝑢𝜎1u(\sigma)=1italic_u ( italic_σ ) = 1 for all σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ.

4 Analysis of existing decompositions

Constructions of decompositions of CPWL functions as difference of two convex functions have appeared in many contexts. In this section, we relate some of these existing constructions to our framework. Moreover, we provide a counterexample to a construction which was proposed by Tran & Wang (2024) to obtain a minimal decomposition in general dimensions.

4.1 Hyperplane extension and local maxima decomposition

The literature contains a variety of different constructions to decompose a CPWL function. It is worth noting, however, that these constructions usually follow one of two main themes. The first theme is to construct (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) in a way such that they are compatible with the complex 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P that arises by extending the codimension-1111 faces of 𝒫fsubscript𝒫𝑓\mathcal{P}_{f}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to hyperplanes, see e.g. Zalgaller (2000) and Schlüter & Darup (2021). The second theme is to exploit the properties of the lattice representation of a CPWL function (Wang, 2004).

Both of these themes were already illustrated by Kripfganz & Schulze (1987), and we describe their constructions in Appendix B as Construction B.1 (“hyperplane extensions”) and Construction B.2 (“local maxima decomposition”). In Section B.1, we show that for the functions that compute the k𝑘kitalic_k-th order statistic, both constructions do not yield the unique minimal decompositions, which exist by Proposition 3.14. This implies the following result.

Proposition 4.1.

There is a function CPWL function f𝑓fitalic_f such that constructions B.1 and B.2 do not provide a vertex of 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) for any regular polyhedral complex 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P compatible with f𝑓fitalic_f.

Moreover, Proposition B.3 shows that the suboptimality of the existing decompositions in the literature is not caused by the concrete construction method, but rather by the polyhedral complexes underlying these methods.

4.2 Minimal decompositions

A construction for a unique minimal decomposition for certain CPWL functions f𝑓fitalic_f in dimension 2222 was presented by Tran & Wang (2024), by introducing a single new 1111-dimensional face to 𝒫fsubscript𝒫𝑓\mathcal{P}_{f}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and an adapted weight function to satisfy the balancing condition.

Their approach builds on a duality theory between positively homogeneous convex CPWL functions and Newton polytopes. A CPWL function f𝑓fitalic_f is positively homogeneous if f⁢(0)=0𝑓00f(0)=0italic_f ( 0 ) = 0 and 𝒫fsubscript𝒫𝑓\mathcal{P}_{f}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a polyhedral fan. Such functions are the support functions of their Newton polytopes, as we describe in more detail in Section C.1; see also Joswig (2021, Section 1.2) and Maclagan & Sturmfels (2015, Chapter 2).

Based on their 2222-dimensional construction, Tran & Wang (2024) propose a procedure to reduce the n𝑛nitalic_n-dimensional case to 2222-dimensions via projections, which we describe in Construction C.2 in Section C.2. The final step in this procedure is to construct a global function in n𝑛nitalic_n dimensions by “gluing together” the projections. In Example C.3 we illustrate that this final step is not always well-defined. Our conclusion is that the construction by Tran & Wang (2024) does not extend beyond the 2222-dimensional case, leaving it an open problem to find any finite algorithm that guarantees to return a minimal decomposition without fixing an underlying polyhedral complex. Note that for any fixed underlying polyhedral complex, Theorem 3.13 implies a finite algorithm by enumerating the vertices of the decomposition polyhedron, as discussed earlier.

5 Submodular Functions

We demonstrate that a special case of our framework is to decompose a general set function into a difference of submodular set funtions and translate our results to this setting. Such decompositions are a popular approach to solve optimization problems as disussed in the introduction. Here, we sketch the idea, all details can be found in Appendix D. Let the polyhedral complex 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P be induced by the braid arrangement, that is, the hyperplane arrangement consisting of the (n2)binomial𝑛2\binom{n}{2}( FRACOP start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) hyperplanes xi=xjsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗x_{i}=x_{j}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with 1≤i<j≤n1𝑖𝑗𝑛1\leq i<j\leq n1 ≤ italic_i < italic_j ≤ italic_n, and let ℱnsubscriptℱ𝑛\mathcal{F}_{n}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the vector space of set functions from 2[n]superscript2delimited-[]𝑛2^{[n]}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to ℝℝ\mathbb{R}blackboard_R.

Proposition 5.1.

The mapping ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ that maps f∈𝒱𝒫𝑓subscript𝒱𝒫f\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to the set function F⁢(S)=f⁢(𝟙S)𝐹𝑆𝑓subscript1𝑆F(S)=f(\mathds{1}_{S})italic_F ( italic_S ) = italic_f ( blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where 𝟙S=∑i∈Seisubscript1𝑆subscript𝑖𝑆subscript𝑒𝑖\mathds{1}_{S}=\sum_{i\in S}e_{i}blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is a vector space isomorphism.

Conversely, starting with a set function F𝐹Fitalic_F, then f=Φ−1⁢(F)𝑓superscriptΦ1𝐹f=\Phi^{-1}(F)italic_f = roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ) is by definition a continuous extension of F𝐹Fitalic_F, which is known as the Lovász extension (Lovász, 1983). The Lovász extension is an important concept in the theory and practice of submodular function optimization as it provides a link between discrete submodular functions and continuous convex functions.

Definition 5.2.

A set function F:2[n]→ℝ:𝐹→superscript2delimited-[]𝑛ℝF\colon 2^{[n]}\to\mathbb{R}italic_F : 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R is called submodular if F⁢(A)+F⁢(B)≥F⁢(A∪B)+F⁢(A∩B)𝐹𝐴𝐹𝐵𝐹𝐴𝐵𝐹𝐴𝐵F(A)+F(B)\geq F(A\cup B)+F(A\cap B)italic_F ( italic_A ) + italic_F ( italic_B ) ≥ italic_F ( italic_A ∪ italic_B ) + italic_F ( italic_A ∩ italic_B ) for all A,B⊆[n]𝐴𝐵delimited-[]𝑛A,B\subseteq[n]italic_A , italic_B ⊆ [ italic_n ]. F𝐹Fitalic_F is called modular if equality holds for all A,B⊆[n]𝐴𝐵delimited-[]𝑛A,B\subseteq[n]italic_A , italic_B ⊆ [ italic_n ].

Since a set function F𝐹Fitalic_F is submodular if and only if its Lovász extension f=Φ−1⁢(F)𝑓superscriptΦ1𝐹f=\Phi^{-1}(F)italic_f = roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ) is convex (Lovász (1983)), we can specialize 1.1 in the setting of this section as follows.

Problem 5.3.

Given a set function F∈ℱn𝐹subscriptℱ𝑛F\in\mathcal{F}_{n}italic_F ∈ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, how to decompose it into a difference of submodular set functions such that their Lovász extensions have as few pieces as possible?

Having a Lovász extension with few pieces is desirable because it allows the submodular function to be stored and accessed efficiently during computational tasks. Moreover, as we argue in Appendix D, for accordingly normalized submodular functions, the number of pieces of the Lovász extension is precisely the number of vertices of the base polytope, which, in turn, is precisely the Newton polytope of the Lovász extension.

As 5.3 is a special case of 1.1, we can translate our results from Section 3 to the setting of submodular functions.

Corollary 5.4 (informal).

The set of decompositions of a general set function into a difference of submodular functions (modulo modular functions) is a polyhedron that arises as the intersection of two shifted copies of the cone of submodular functions. In analogy to our general results, the irreducible decompositions correspond precisely to the bounded faces of that polyhedron and every minimal decomposition is a vertex.

Example D.14 shows that the Lovász extensions of cut functions are hyperplane functions and thus admit a unique minimal decomposition into submodular functions, which are themselves cut functions. In particular, the Lovász extensions of the decomposition have at most as many pieces as the Lovász extensions of the original cut function.

6 Neural Network Constructions

In this section we consider the following question: Given a CPWL function f:ℝn→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R with q𝑞qitalic_q pieces and k𝑘kitalic_k affine components, what is the necessary depth, width, and size of a neural network exactly representing this function? To this end, we first discuss the necessary background on neural networks and known results on neural complexity. We then prove better results for the case of f𝑓fitalic_f being convex. Finally, we extend these results to nonconvex functions by writing them as a difference of convex functions.

6.1 Background

For a number of hidden layers d≥0𝑑0d\geq 0italic_d ≥ 0, a neural network with rectified linear unit (ReLU) activiations is defined by a sequence of d+1𝑑1d+1italic_d + 1 affine transformations Ti:ℝni−1→ℝni:subscript𝑇𝑖→superscriptℝsubscript𝑛𝑖1superscriptℝsubscript𝑛𝑖T_{i}:\mathbb{R}^{n_{i-1}}\to\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, i∈[d+1]𝑖delimited-[]𝑑1i\in[d+1]italic_i ∈ [ italic_d + 1 ]. We assume that n0=nsubscript𝑛0𝑛n_{0}=nitalic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_n and nd+1=1subscript𝑛𝑑11n_{d+1}=1italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1. If σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ denotes the function that computes the ReLU function x↦max⁡{x,0}maps-to𝑥𝑥0x\mapsto\max\{x,0\}italic_x ↦ roman_max { italic_x , 0 } in each component, the neural network is said to compute the function f:ℝn→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R given by f=Td+1∘σ∘Td∘σ∘⋯∘σ∘T1𝑓subscript𝑇𝑑1𝜎subscript𝑇𝑑𝜎⋯𝜎subscript𝑇1f=T_{d+1}\circ\sigma\circ T_{d}\circ\sigma\circ\dots\circ\sigma\circ T_{1}italic_f = italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∘ italic_σ ∘ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∘ italic_σ ∘ ⋯ ∘ italic_σ ∘ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We say that the neural network has depth d+1𝑑1d+1italic_d + 1, width maxi∈[d]⁡nisubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑑subscript𝑛𝑖\max_{i\in[d]}n_{i}roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_d ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and size ∑i∈[d]nisubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑑subscript𝑛𝑖\sum_{i\in[d]}n_{i}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_d ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

It is well-known that the maximum of n𝑛nitalic_n numbers can be computed with depth ⌈log2⁡n⌉+1subscript2𝑛1\lceil\log_{2}n\rceil+1⌈ roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ⌉ + 1 and overall size 𝒪⁢(n)𝒪𝑛\mathcal{O}(n)caligraphic_O ( italic_n ) (Arora et al., 2018). This simple fact has been used in the literature to deduce exact representations of CPWL functions with neural networks from known representations of CPWL functions. We would like to focus on two of them here, which are in a sense incomparable. The first one goes back to Hertrich et al. (2021) and builds upon ideas from Wang & Sun (2005). We present it here in a slightly stronger form.

Theorem 6.1.

Every CPWL function f:ℝn→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R with k𝑘kitalic_k affine components can be represented by a neural network with depth ⌈log2⁡(n+1)⌉+1subscript2𝑛11\lceil\log_{2}(n+1)\rceil+1⌈ roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_n + 1 ) ⌉ + 1 and overall size 𝒪⁢(kn+1)𝒪superscript𝑘𝑛1\mathcal{O}(k^{n+1})caligraphic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

The second one goes back to Chen et al. (2022) and is based on the lattice representation of CPWL functions, compare Tarela & Martinez (1999).

Theorem 6.2 ((Chen et al., 2022)).

Every CPWL function f:ℝn→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R with q𝑞qitalic_q pieces and k𝑘kitalic_k affine components can be represented by a neural network with depth ⌈log2⁡p⌉+⌈log2⁡q⌉+1subscript2𝑝subscript2𝑞1\lceil\log_{2}p\rceil+\lceil\log_{2}q\rceil+1⌈ roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ⌉ + ⌈ roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ⌉ + 1 and overall size 𝒪⁢(k⁢q)𝒪𝑘𝑞\mathcal{O}(kq)caligraphic_O ( italic_k italic_q ).

As noted before, one can assume that n<k≤q𝑛𝑘𝑞n<k\leq qitalic_n < italic_k ≤ italic_q, since otherwise we could affinely project to a lower dimension without losing information. In fact, one would usually assume that the input dimension n𝑛nitalic_n is much lower than the number of affine components k𝑘kitalic_k. Therefore, Theorem 6.1 provides the better representation in terms of depth, while Theorem 6.2 provides the better representation in terms of size. However, both theorems are kind of inflexible for the user, dictating a certing depth and providing only these two specific options. So, the naturally occuring question is: can we somehow freely choose a depth and trade depth against size in these representations? In other words: can we smoothly interpolate between the low-depth high-size representation of Theorem 6.1 and the low-size high-depth representation of Theorem 6.2? In the remaining section we present results that achieve this to some extent.

6.2 New Constructions for the Convex Case

In this part we prove that we can achieve the desired tradeoff easily in the convex case by mixing the two representations of Theorem 6.1 and Theorem 6.2.

Theorem 6.3.

Every convex CPWL function f:ℝn→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R with q=k𝑞𝑘q=kitalic_q = italic_k affine components can be represented by a neural network with depth ⌈log2⁡(n+1)⌉+⌈log2⁡r⌉+1subscript2𝑛1subscript2𝑟1\lceil\log_{2}(n+1)\rceil+\lceil\log_{2}r\rceil+1⌈ roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_n + 1 ) ⌉ + ⌈ roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r ⌉ + 1 and overall size 𝒪⁢(r⁢sn+1)𝒪𝑟superscript𝑠𝑛1\mathcal{O}(rs^{n+1})caligraphic_O ( italic_r italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), for any free choice of parameters r𝑟ritalic_r and s𝑠sitalic_s with r⁢s≥k𝑟𝑠𝑘rs\geq kitalic_r italic_s ≥ italic_k.

In order to see how this provides a tradeoff between the representations of Theorem 6.1 and Theorem 6.2, it is worth looking at the extreme cases. If we choose r=1𝑟1r=1italic_r = 1 and s=k𝑠𝑘s=kitalic_s = italic_k, we exactly obtain the bounds from Theorem 6.1. On the other hand, if we choose r=k𝑟𝑘r=kitalic_r = italic_k and s=1𝑠1s=1italic_s = 1, we obtain a neural network with depth 𝒪⁢(log⁡k)𝒪𝑘\mathcal{O}(\log k)caligraphic_O ( roman_log italic_k ) and size 𝒪⁢(k)𝒪𝑘\mathcal{O}(k)caligraphic_O ( italic_k ), which is qualitatively close to the bounds of Theorem 6.2. In fact, the even better size bound stems from the fact that our construction heavily relies on convexity.

In conclusion, by choosing an appropriate r𝑟ritalic_r (and corresponding s𝑠sitalic_s), the user can freely decide how to trade depth against size in neural network representations and thereby interpolate between the two extreme representations of Theorem 6.1 and Theorem 6.2.

6.3 Extension to the Nonconvex Case

The construction of Theorem 6.3 provides a nice blueprint of how to interpolate between Theorem 6.1 and Theorem 6.2, but it has the big limitation that it only works in the convex case. Simply mixing the two known representations of Theorems 6.1 and 6.2 does not appear to work in the nonconvex case, as one cannot as easily identify groups of affine components that can be treated separately.

Instead we propose a different approach: given a CPWL function, first split it into a difference of two convex ones and then apply Theorem 6.3 to these two functions. To do this efficiently, it requires to find a good answer to 1.1.

As discussed in this paper, it is quite challenging to give a satisfying answer to 1.1 in full generality, but there are special cases, where we do have a good answer; see Section 3. For example, we obtain the following result by combining Theorem 6.3 with Lemma E.3.

Corollary 6.4.

Let f:ℝn→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R be a CPWL function that is compatible with a regular polyhedral complex 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P with q~=|𝒫n|~𝑞superscript𝒫𝑛\tilde{q}=\lvert\mathcal{P}^{n}\rvertover~ start_ARG italic_q end_ARG = | caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | full-dimensional polyhedra. Then, f𝑓fitalic_f can be represented by a neural network with depth ⌈log2⁡(n+1)⌉+⌈log2⁡r⌉+1subscript2𝑛1subscript2𝑟1\lceil\log_{2}(n+1)\rceil+\lceil\log_{2}r\rceil+1⌈ roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_n + 1 ) ⌉ + ⌈ roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r ⌉ + 1 and overall size 𝒪⁢(r⁢sn+1)𝒪𝑟superscript𝑠𝑛1\mathcal{O}(rs^{n+1})caligraphic_O ( italic_r italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), for any free choice of parameters r𝑟ritalic_r and s𝑠sitalic_s with r⁢s≥q~𝑟𝑠~𝑞rs\geq\tilde{q}italic_r italic_s ≥ over~ start_ARG italic_q end_ARG.

For a given CPWL function f𝑓fitalic_f, provided that one can find a regular polyhedral complex such that q~~𝑞\tilde{q}over~ start_ARG italic_q end_ARG is not much larger than the number of pieces q𝑞qitalic_q, Corollary 6.4 does indeed provide a smooth tradeoff between Theorem 6.1 and Theorem 6.2 in the general, nonconvex case. As q𝑞qitalic_q is the minimal number of fulldimensional polyhedra in any (potentially nonregular) polyhedral complex compatible with f𝑓fitalic_f, the big question is how much of a restriction the assumption of regularity might be.

7 Open Problems

From the theoretical perspective, the maybe most dominant open question is the following precise version of 1.1.

Problem 7.1.

Given a CPWL function f𝑓fitalic_f in dimension n𝑛nitalic_n with q𝑞qitalic_q pieces, does there always exist a decomposition f=g−h𝑓𝑔ℎf=g-hitalic_f = italic_g - italic_h such that the number of pieces of g𝑔gitalic_g and hℎhitalic_h is polynomial in n𝑛nitalic_n and q𝑞qitalic_q?

Note that by definition, f𝑓fitalic_f is compatible with a polyhedral complex 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P with |𝒫n|=qsuperscript𝒫𝑛𝑞\lvert\mathcal{P}^{n}\rvert=q| caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | = italic_q. To answer 7.1 positively, by Lemma E.3 it would be sufficient to find a regular polyhedral complex 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q with |𝒬n|=poly⁢(n,q)superscript𝒬𝑛poly𝑛𝑞\lvert\mathcal{Q}^{n}\rvert=\mathrm{poly}(n,q)| caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | = roman_poly ( italic_n , italic_q ) that is a refinement of 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. Conversely, if we can answer 7.1 positively, then the underlying complex of g+h𝑔ℎg+hitalic_g + italic_h would give us such a regular complex 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q. Therefore, to solve 7.1, one needs to answer the following question: given an arbitrary complete polyhedral complex 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P, what is the “coarsest” refinement of 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P that is regular? A positive answer to 7.1 would have useful consequences for our two applications in the context of (submodular) set function optimization and neural network representations. However, also a negative answer would be equally interesting.

One possible approach to resolve 7.1 could be to analyze which objective direction according to Theorem 3.18 leads to a good vertex of the decomposition polyhedron and prove theoretical properties about that vertex. The same theorem might also be key to developing algorithms that find good decompositions with linear programming. Generally, while beyond the scope of this paper, turning any of our insights into practical algorithms, preferably with theoretical guarantees, is a broad avenue for future research.
