  • Wang & Sun (2005) Shuning Wang and Xusheng Sun. Generalization of hinging hyperplanes. IEEE Transactions on Information Theory, 51(12):4425–4431, 2005.
  • Zalgaller (2000) V. A. Zalgaller. Representation of functions of several variables by differences of convex functions. Journal of Mathematical Sciences, 100(3):2209–2227, June 2000. ISSN 1573-8795. doi: 10.1007/s10958-000-0006-4.
  • Zhang et al. (2018) Liwen Zhang, Gregory Naitzat, and Lek-Heng Lim. Tropical geometry of deep neural networks. In International Conference on Machine Learning, pp. 5824–5832. PMLR, 2018.

Appendix A Examples

A.1 Different parameterizations of median function

Example A.1 (Median).

In this example, we have a look at the different parameterizations for the function that computes the median of 3333 numbers. To have a 2222-dimensional example, we set x3≔0≔subscript𝑥30x_{3}\coloneqq 0italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ 0. Let the polyhedral complex 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P be induced by the maximal polyhedra Pπ={x∈ℝ2∣xπ⁢(1)≤xπ⁢(2)≤xπ⁢(3)}subscript𝑃𝜋conditional-set𝑥superscriptℝ2subscript𝑥𝜋1subscript𝑥𝜋2subscript𝑥𝜋3P_{\pi}=\{x\in\mathbb{R}^{2}\mid x_{\pi(1)}\leq x_{\pi(2)}\leq x_{\pi(3)}\}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( 2 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( 3 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } where π:[3]→[3]:𝜋→delimited-[]3delimited-[]3\pi\colon[3]\to[3]italic_π : [ 3 ] → [ 3 ] is a permutation and f:ℝ3→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ3ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{3}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R be the function given by f|Pπ⁢(x)=xπ⁢(2)evaluated-at𝑓subscript𝑃𝜋𝑥subscript𝑥𝜋2f|_{P_{\pi}}(x)=x_{\pi(2)}italic_f | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( 2 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The function f𝑓fitalic_f has concave breakpoints whenever the median and the higher coordinate change, i.e., at the facets that are given as σπ,1={x∈ℝ2∣xπ⁢(1)≤xπ⁢(2)=xπ⁢(3)}subscript𝜎𝜋1conditional-set𝑥superscriptℝ2subscript𝑥𝜋1subscript𝑥𝜋2subscript𝑥𝜋3\sigma_{\pi,1}=\{x\in\mathbb{R}^{2}\mid x_{\pi(1)}\leq x_{\pi(2)}=x_{\pi(3)}\}italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( 2 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( 3 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and convex breakpoints whenever the median and the lower coordinate change, that is, at the facets that are given as σπ,2={x∈ℝ2∣xπ⁢(1)=xπ⁢(2)≤xπ⁢(3)}subscript𝜎𝜋2conditional-set𝑥superscriptℝ2subscript𝑥𝜋1subscript𝑥𝜋2subscript𝑥𝜋3\sigma_{\pi,2}=\{x\in\mathbb{R}^{2}\mid x_{\pi(1)}=x_{\pi(2)}\leq x_{\pi(3)}\}italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π , 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( 2 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( 3 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. Since ‖e1−e2‖2=2subscriptnormsubscript𝑒1subscript𝑒222\|e_{1}-e_{2}\|_{2}=\sqrt{2}∥ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG and ‖e1‖2=‖e2‖2=1subscriptnormsubscript𝑒12subscriptnormsubscript𝑒221\|e_{1}\|_{2}=\|e_{2}\|_{2}=1∥ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∥ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1, it holds that

wf⁢(σπ,1)={−2xπ⁢(1)=x3−1xπ⁢(1)≠x3 and wf⁢(σπ,2)={2xπ⁢(3)=x31xπ⁢(3)≠x3.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑤𝑓subscript𝜎𝜋1cases2subscript𝑥𝜋1subscript𝑥31subscript𝑥𝜋1subscript𝑥3 and subscript𝑤𝑓subscript𝜎𝜋2cases2subscript𝑥𝜋3subscript𝑥31subscript𝑥𝜋3subscript𝑥3w_{f}(\sigma_{\pi,1})=\begin{cases}-\sqrt{2}&x_{\pi(1)}=x_{3}\\ -1&x_{\pi(1)}\neq x_{3}\end{cases}\quad\text{ and }\quad w_{f}(\sigma_{\pi,2})% =\begin{cases}\sqrt{2}&x_{\pi(3)}=x_{3}\\ 1&x_{\pi(3)}\neq x_{3}.\end{cases}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = { start_ROW start_CELL - square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL - 1 end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW and italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π , 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = { start_ROW start_CELL square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( 3 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( 3 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . end_CELL end_ROW

See Figure 1 for a 2222-dimensional illustration.

A.2 Illustration of Definition 3.12

A.3 Examples for unique minimal decompositions

Example A.2 (Minimal decomposition for hyperplane functions).

Let f:ℝn→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R be a hyperplane function given as f⁢(x)=∑i∈[k]λi⋅max⁡{⟨x,ai⟩+bi,⟨x,ci⟩+di}𝑓𝑥subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑘⋅subscript𝜆𝑖𝑥subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖𝑥subscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖f(x)=\sum_{i\in[k]}\lambda_{i}\cdot\max\{\langle x,a_{i}\rangle+b_{i},\langle x% ,c_{i}\rangle+d_{i}\}italic_f ( italic_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_k ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ roman_max { ⟨ italic_x , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⟨ italic_x , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. We can assume without loss of generality that the hyperplanes

Hi={x∈ℝn∣⟨x,ai⟩+bi=⟨x,ci⟩+di}subscript𝐻𝑖conditional-set𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛𝑥subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖𝑥subscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖H_{i}=\{x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\mid\langle x,a_{i}\rangle+b_{i}=\langle x,c_{i}% \rangle+d_{i}\}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ ⟨ italic_x , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ⟨ italic_x , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }

are pairwise distinct, because otherwise we can simply adjust λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i}italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The polyhedral complex 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P induced by the hyperplane arrangement {Hi}i∈[k]subscriptsubscript𝐻𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑘\{H_{i}\}_{i\in[k]}{ italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_k ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is compatible with f𝑓fitalic_f. The convex functions g,h𝑔ℎg,hitalic_g , italic_h given by

g⁢(x)=∑λi≥0λi⋅max⁡{⟨x,ai⟩+bi,⟨x,ci⟩+di}⁢ and ⁢h⁢(x)=∑λi<0λi⋅max⁡{⟨x,ai⟩+bi,⟨x,ci⟩+di}𝑔𝑥subscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖0⋅subscript𝜆𝑖𝑥subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖𝑥subscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖 and ℎ𝑥subscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖0⋅subscript𝜆𝑖𝑥subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖𝑥subscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖g(x)=\sum_{\lambda_{i}\geq 0}\lambda_{i}\cdot\max\{\langle x,a_{i}\rangle+b_{i% },\langle x,c_{i}\rangle+d_{i}\}\text{ and }h(x)=\sum_{\lambda_{i}<0}\lambda_{% i}\cdot\max\{\langle x,a_{i}\rangle+b_{i},\langle x,c_{i}\rangle+d_{i}\}italic_g ( italic_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ roman_max { ⟨ italic_x , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⟨ italic_x , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and italic_h ( italic_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ roman_max { ⟨ italic_x , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⟨ italic_x , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }

are the unique minimal decomposition of f𝑓fitalic_f since supp𝒫⁡(g)=supp𝒫+⁡(f)={σ∈𝒫n−1∣σ⊆⋃λi≥0Hi}subscriptsupp𝒫𝑔subscriptsuperscriptsupp𝒫𝑓conditional-set𝜎superscript𝒫𝑛1𝜎subscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖0subscript𝐻𝑖\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(g)=\operatorname{supp}^{+}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)=% \{\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}\mid\sigma\subseteq\bigcup_{\lambda_{i}\geq 0}H_{i}\}roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ) = roman_supp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) = { italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ italic_σ ⊆ ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and supp𝒫⁡(h)=supp𝒫−⁡(f)={σ∈𝒫n−1∣σ⊆⋃λi<0Hi}subscriptsupp𝒫ℎsubscriptsuperscriptsupp𝒫𝑓conditional-set𝜎superscript𝒫𝑛1𝜎subscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖0subscript𝐻𝑖\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(h)=\operatorname{supp}^{-}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)=% \{\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}\mid\sigma\subseteq\bigcup_{\lambda_{i}<0}H_{i}\}roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_h ) = roman_supp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) = { italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ italic_σ ⊆ ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }.

Example A.3 (Minimal decomposition of k𝑘kitalic_k-th order statistic).

We construct a polyhedral complex that is compatible with the function f:ℝn→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R that outputs the k𝑘kitalic_k-th largest entry of x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For U⊆[n]𝑈delimited-[]𝑛U\subseteq[n]italic_U ⊆ [ italic_n ] with |U|=k𝑈𝑘|U|=k| italic_U | = italic_k and i∈[n]∖U𝑖delimited-[]𝑛𝑈i\in[n]\setminus Uitalic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] ∖ italic_U, let

Pi,U={x∈ℝn∣xj≤xi≤xℓ⁢∀ℓ∈U,j∈[n]∖U}.subscript𝑃𝑖𝑈conditional-set𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛formulae-sequencesubscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥ℓfor-allℓ𝑈𝑗delimited-[]𝑛𝑈P_{i,U}=\{x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\mid x_{j}\leq x_{i}\leq x_{\ell}\;\forall\ell\in U% ,j\in[n]\setminus U\}.italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∀ roman_ℓ ∈ italic_U , italic_j ∈ [ italic_n ] ∖ italic_U } .

All such polyhedra and their faces form a polyhedral complex 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P that is compatible with the function f:ℝn→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R given by f⁢(Pi,U)=xi𝑓subscript𝑃𝑖𝑈subscript𝑥𝑖f(P_{i,U})=x_{i}italic_f ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. It is not hard to see that f=g−h𝑓𝑔ℎf=g-hitalic_f = italic_g - italic_h where g,h∈𝒱¯𝒫+𝑔ℎsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫g,h\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}italic_g , italic_h ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are convex functions given by

g⁢(x)≔maxI⊆[n]|I|=k⁡(∑i∈Ixi)⁢ and ⁢h⁢(x)≔maxI⊆[n]|I|=k−1⁡(∑i∈Ixi).≔𝑔𝑥subscript𝐼delimited-[]𝑛𝐼𝑘subscript𝑖𝐼subscript𝑥𝑖 and ℎ𝑥≔subscript𝐼delimited-[]𝑛𝐼𝑘1subscript𝑖𝐼subscript𝑥𝑖g(x)\coloneqq\max\limits_{\begin{subarray}{c}I\subseteq[n]\\ |I|=k\end{subarray}}\left(\sum_{i\in I}x_{i}\right)\text{ and }h(x)\coloneqq% \max\limits_{\begin{subarray}{c}I\subseteq[n]\\ |I|=k-1\end{subarray}}\left(\sum_{i\in I}x_{i}\right).italic_g ( italic_x ) ≔ roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_I ⊆ [ italic_n ] end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL | italic_I | = italic_k end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and italic_h ( italic_x ) ≔ roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_I ⊆ [ italic_n ] end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL | italic_I | = italic_k - 1 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

Moreover, let σi,j,U≔{x∈ℝn∣xℓ≤xj=xi≤xm\sigma_{i,j,U}\coloneqq\{x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\mid x_{\ell}\leq x_{j}=x_{i}\leq x% _{m}italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j , italic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ { italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all m∈U,ℓ∈[n]∖U}m\in U,\ell\in[n]\setminus U\}italic_m ∈ italic_U , roman_ℓ ∈ [ italic_n ] ∖ italic_U }. Then supp𝒫⁡(g)=supp𝒫+⁡(f)={σi,j,U∣U⊆[n],|U|=k+1}subscriptsupp𝒫𝑔superscriptsubscriptsupp𝒫𝑓conditional-setsubscript𝜎𝑖𝑗𝑈formulae-sequence𝑈delimited-[]𝑛𝑈𝑘1\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(g)=\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}(f)=% \{\sigma_{i,j,U}\mid U\subseteq[n],|U|=k+1\}roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ) = roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_f ) = { italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j , italic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_U ⊆ [ italic_n ] , | italic_U | = italic_k + 1 } and supp𝒫⁡(h)=supp𝒫−⁡(f)={σi,j,U∣U⊆[n],|U|=k}subscriptsupp𝒫ℎsuperscriptsubscriptsupp𝒫𝑓conditional-setsubscript𝜎𝑖𝑗𝑈formulae-sequence𝑈delimited-[]𝑛𝑈𝑘\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(h)=\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}^{-}(f)=% \{\sigma_{i,j,U}\mid U\subseteq[n],|U|=k\}roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_h ) = roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_f ) = { italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j , italic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_U ⊆ [ italic_n ] , | italic_U | = italic_k }. Thus, Proposition 3.15 implies that (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is the unique vertex of every regular polyhedral complex compatible with f𝑓fitalic_f.

Appendix B Constructions by Kripfganz & Schulze (1987)

Construction B.1 (Hyperplane extension).

For all convex breakpoints, the local convex functions are extended to global convex functions with breakpoints supported on a single hyperplane, and the function g𝑔gitalic_g is defined as the sum of all these functions. To analyze it in our framework, let 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P be any polyhedral complex that is compatible with f𝑓fitalic_f and let wf∈𝒲𝒫subscript𝑤𝑓subscript𝒲𝒫w_{f}\in\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the weight function corresponding to f𝑓fitalic_f. For σ∈𝒫n−1𝜎superscript𝒫𝑛1\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, let Hσsubscript𝐻𝜎H_{\sigma}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the hyperplane spanned by σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ and 𝒜f+={Hσ∣wf⁢(σ)>0}subscriptsuperscript𝒜𝑓conditional-setsubscript𝐻𝜎subscript𝑤𝑓𝜎0\mathcal{A}^{+}_{f}=\{H_{\sigma}\mid w_{f}(\sigma)>0\}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ ) > 0 } be the hyperplane arrangement consisting of the hyperplanes supporting the breakpoints where f𝑓fitalic_f is convex. Let ℋf+subscriptsuperscriptℋ𝑓\mathcal{H}^{+}_{f}caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the common refinement of the polyhedral complex induced by 𝒜f+subscriptsuperscript𝒜𝑓\mathcal{A}^{+}_{f}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. The weight function wg:𝒫n−1→ℝ:subscript𝑤𝑔→superscript𝒫𝑛1ℝw_{g}\colon\mathcal{P}^{n-1}\to\mathbb{R}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R given by wg⁢(σ)≔∑σ⊆Hσ′,wf⁢(σ′)>0wf⁢(σ′)≔subscript𝑤𝑔𝜎subscript𝜎subscript𝐻superscript𝜎′subscript𝑤𝑓superscript𝜎′0subscript𝑤𝑓superscript𝜎′w_{g}(\sigma)\coloneqq\sum\limits_{\begin{subarray}{c}\sigma\subseteq H_{% \sigma^{\prime}},\\ w_{f}(\sigma^{\prime})>0\end{subarray}}w_{f}(\sigma^{\prime})italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ ) ≔ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_σ ⊆ italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) > 0 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is in 𝒲ℋf+subscript𝒲subscriptsuperscriptℋ𝑓\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{H}^{+}_{f}}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and nonnegative and hence the corresponding function g∈𝒱ℋf+𝑔subscript𝒱subscriptsuperscriptℋ𝑓g\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{H}^{+}_{f}}italic_g ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is convex. It follows that h≔g−f≔ℎ𝑔𝑓h\coloneqq g-fitalic_h ≔ italic_g - italic_f is convex as well, yielding the desired decomposition.

Construction B.2 (Local Maxima Decomposition).

Let {P1,…,Pm}=𝒫nsubscript𝑃1…subscript𝑃𝑚superscript𝒫𝑛\{P_{1},\ldots,P_{m}\}=\mathcal{P}^{n}{ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } = caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the unique linear extension of f|Pievaluated-at𝑓subscript𝑃𝑖f|_{P_{i}}italic_f | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Moreover, let Mi≔{j∈[m]∣fi(x)≥fj(x)M_{i}\coloneqq\{j\in[m]\mid f_{i}(x)\geq f_{j}(x)italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ { italic_j ∈ [ italic_m ] ∣ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ≥ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) for all x∈Pi}x\in P_{i}\}italic_x ∈ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and gi≔maxj∈Mi⁡Pj≔subscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝑗subscript𝑀𝑖subscript𝑃𝑗g_{i}\coloneqq\max_{j\in M_{i}}P_{j}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j ∈ italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then

f=mini∈[m]⁡maxj∈Mi⁡fi=mini∈[m]⁡gi𝑓subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑚subscript𝑗subscript𝑀𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑚subscript𝑔𝑖f=\min_{i\in[m]}\max_{j\in M_{i}}f_{i}=\min_{i\in[m]}g_{i}italic_f = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j ∈ italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

and g≔∑i∈[m]gi≔𝑔subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑚subscript𝑔𝑖g\coloneqq\sum_{i\in[m]}g_{i}italic_g ≔ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a convex function. Furthermore, let hi≔g−gi≔subscriptℎ𝑖𝑔subscript𝑔𝑖h_{i}\coloneqq g-g_{i}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ italic_g - italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then h≔maxi∈[m]⁡hi≔ℎsubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑚subscriptℎ𝑖h\coloneqq\max_{i\in[m]}h_{i}italic_h ≔ roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a convex function as well and it holds that

g−h=g−maxi∈[m]⁡(g−gi)=g−(g−mini∈[m]⁡gi)=g−(g−f)=f𝑔ℎ𝑔subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑚𝑔subscript𝑔𝑖𝑔𝑔subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑚subscript𝑔𝑖𝑔𝑔𝑓𝑓g-h=g-\max_{i\in[m]}(g-g_{i})=g-(g-\min_{i\in[m]}g_{i})=g-(g-f)=fitalic_g - italic_h = italic_g - roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g - italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_g - ( italic_g - roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_g - ( italic_g - italic_f ) = italic_f

Let Hi,j≔{x∈ℝn∣fi⁢(x)=fj⁢(x)}≔subscript𝐻𝑖𝑗conditional-set𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥subscript𝑓𝑗𝑥H_{i,j}\coloneqq\{x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\mid f_{i}(x)=f_{j}(x)\}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ { italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) } and 𝒜f={Hi,j∣i≠j}subscript𝒜𝑓conditional-setsubscript𝐻𝑖𝑗𝑖𝑗\mathcal{A}_{f}=\{H_{i,j}\mid i\neq j\}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_i ≠ italic_j }. Furthermore, let ℋfsubscriptℋ𝑓\mathcal{H}_{f}caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the polyhedral complex induced by the hyperplane arrangement 𝒜fsubscript𝒜𝑓\mathcal{A}_{f}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then we have that g,h∈𝒱ℋf𝑔ℎsubscript𝒱subscriptℋ𝑓g,h\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{H}_{f}}italic_g , italic_h ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Proposition B.3.

There is a CPWL function f𝑓fitalic_f and convex CPWL functions g,h𝑔ℎg,hitalic_g , italic_h with f=g−h𝑓𝑔ℎf=g-hitalic_f = italic_g - italic_h such that every decomposition (g′,h′)∈𝒟ℋf⁢(f)superscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′subscript𝒟subscriptℋ𝑓𝑓(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{H}_{f}}(f)( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) as well as every decomposition (g′,h′)∈𝒟ℋf+⁢(f)superscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′subscript𝒟subscriptsuperscriptℋ𝑓𝑓(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{H}^{+}_{f}}(f)( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) is dominated by (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ).

Proof.

Let 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P be the polyhedral complex in ℝ2superscriptℝ2\mathbb{R}^{2}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with rays ρ1=cone⁡((1,0))subscript𝜌1cone10\rho_{1}=\operatorname{cone}((1,0))italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_cone ( ( 1 , 0 ) ), ρ2=cone⁡((0,1))subscript𝜌2cone01\rho_{2}=\operatorname{cone}((0,1))italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_cone ( ( 0 , 1 ) ), ρ3=cone⁡((1,2))subscript𝜌3cone12\rho_{3}=\operatorname{cone}((1,2))italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_cone ( ( 1 , 2 ) ) and ρ4=cone⁡((2,1))subscript𝜌4cone21\rho_{4}=\operatorname{cone}((2,1))italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_cone ( ( 2 , 1 ) ). Let wf⁢(ρ1)=wf⁢(ρ2)=1subscript𝑤𝑓subscript𝜌1subscript𝑤𝑓subscript𝜌21w_{f}(\rho_{1})=w_{f}(\rho_{2})=1italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 1 and wf⁢(ρ3)=wf⁢(ρ4)=53subscript𝑤𝑓subscript𝜌3subscript𝑤𝑓subscript𝜌453w_{f}(\rho_{3})=w_{f}(\rho_{4})=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{3}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 5 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG. Then according to Theorem C.1 the unique minimal decomposition is given by the complex obtained by adding the ray ρ5=cone⁡((−1,−1))subscript𝜌5cone11\rho_{5}=\operatorname{cone}((-1,-1))italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_cone ( ( - 1 , - 1 ) ) and the weight function

wg⁢(ρ)={wf⁢(ρ)ρ∈supp𝒫+⁡(f)0ρ∈supp𝒫−⁡(f)2ρ=ρ5subscript𝑤𝑔𝜌casessubscript𝑤𝑓𝜌𝜌superscriptsubscriptsupp𝒫𝑓0𝜌superscriptsubscriptsupp𝒫𝑓2𝜌subscript𝜌5w_{g}(\rho)=\begin{cases}w_{f}(\rho)&\rho\in\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}^% {+}(f)\\ 0&\rho\in\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}^{-}(f)\\ \sqrt{2}&\rho=\rho_{5}\end{cases}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) = { start_ROW start_CELL italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) end_CELL start_CELL italic_ρ ∈ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_f ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL italic_ρ ∈ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_f ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_CELL start_CELL italic_ρ = italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW

as well as wh=wg−wfsubscript𝑤ℎsubscript𝑤𝑔subscript𝑤𝑓w_{h}=w_{g}-w_{f}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Nevertheless, the ray ρ5subscript𝜌5\rho_{5}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is not contained in (the support of) ℋfsubscriptℋ𝑓\mathcal{H}_{f}caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and hence this solution is not in 𝒟ℋf⁢(f)subscript𝒟subscriptℋ𝑓𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{H}_{f}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ). Since (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is the unique (up to adding a linear function) minimal decomposition, it follows that any solution in 𝒟ℋf⁢(f)subscript𝒟subscriptℋ𝑓𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{H}_{f}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) must be dominated by (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ). Since ℋf+subscriptsuperscriptℋ𝑓\mathcal{H}^{+}_{f}caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a coarsening of ℋfsubscriptℋ𝑓\mathcal{H}_{f}caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, it holds that every decomposition in 𝒟ℋf+⁢(f)subscript𝒟subscriptsuperscriptℋ𝑓𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{H}^{+}_{f}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) is contained in 𝒟ℋf⁢(f)subscript𝒟subscriptℋ𝑓𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{H}_{f}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) as well, impyling the result for 𝒟ℋf+⁢(f)subscript𝒟subscriptsuperscriptℋ𝑓𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{H}^{+}_{f}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ). ∎

B.1 Examples of existing decompositions

Example B.4 (hyperplane extension of k𝑘kitalic_k-th order statistic).

Let f𝑓fitalic_f be the function from Example A.3. For any i,j∈[n]𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑛i,j\in[n]italic_i , italic_j ∈ [ italic_n ] and U⊆[n]𝑈delimited-[]𝑛U\subseteq[n]italic_U ⊆ [ italic_n ] with i,j∈U𝑖𝑗𝑈i,j\in Uitalic_i , italic_j ∈ italic_U and |U|=k+1𝑈𝑘1|U|=k+1| italic_U | = italic_k + 1 it holds that σi,j,U∈supp+⁡(f)subscript𝜎𝑖𝑗𝑈superscriptsupp𝑓\sigma_{i,j,U}\in\operatorname{supp}^{+}(f)italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j , italic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ roman_supp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_f ) and Hσi,j,U={x∈ℝn∣xi=xj}subscript𝐻subscript𝜎𝑖𝑗𝑈conditional-set𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗H_{\sigma_{i,j,U}}=\{x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\mid x_{i}=x_{j}\}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j , italic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. Hence, 𝒫gsubscript𝒫𝑔\mathcal{P}_{g}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the braid fan and it holds that g⁢(x)=(nk−1)⁢∑i≠jmax⁡{xi,xj}𝑔𝑥binomial𝑛𝑘1subscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗g(x)=\binom{n}{k-1}\sum_{i\neq j}\max\{x_{i},x_{j}\}italic_g ( italic_x ) = ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_k - 1 end_ARG ) ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ≠ italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max { italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. Thus, the unique vertex (g∗,h∗)superscript𝑔superscriptℎ(g^{*},h^{*})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) from Example A.3 is clearly a non-trivial coarsening of the decomposition obtained from the hyperplane extension (since g∗superscript𝑔g^{*}italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a non-trivial coarsening of g𝑔gitalic_g) and hence the decomposition cannot be a vertex of 𝒟𝒬⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒬𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{Q}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) for any regular polyhedral complex 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q.

Example B.5 (local maxima decomposition of k𝑘kitalic_k-th order statistic).

Let f𝑓fitalic_f be the function from Example A.3. Then, for U⊆[n]𝑈delimited-[]𝑛U\subseteq[n]italic_U ⊆ [ italic_n ] with |U|=k−1𝑈𝑘1|U|=k-1| italic_U | = italic_k - 1 and i∈[n]∖U𝑖delimited-[]𝑛𝑈i\in[n]\setminus Uitalic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] ∖ italic_U, we have that gi,U⁢(x)=maxj∈[n]∖U⁡xjsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑈𝑥subscript𝑗delimited-[]𝑛𝑈subscript𝑥𝑗g_{i,U}(x)=\max\limits_{j\in[n]\setminus U}x_{j}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j ∈ [ italic_n ] ∖ italic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Thus,

g⁢(x)=∑i,Ugi,U⁢(x)=(n−k+1)⋅∑S⊆[n]|S|=n−k+1maxj∈S⁡xj.𝑔𝑥subscript𝑖𝑈subscript𝑔𝑖𝑈𝑥⋅𝑛𝑘1subscript𝑆delimited-[]𝑛𝑆𝑛𝑘1subscript𝑗𝑆subscript𝑥𝑗g(x)=\sum_{i,U}g_{i,U}(x)=(n-k+1)\cdot\sum\limits_{\begin{subarray}{c}S% \subseteq[n]\\ |S|=n-k+1\end{subarray}}\max_{j\in S}x_{j}.italic_g ( italic_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = ( italic_n - italic_k + 1 ) ⋅ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_S ⊆ [ italic_n ] end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL | italic_S | = italic_n - italic_k + 1 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j ∈ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Note that g𝑔gitalic_g has only breakpoints when two coordinates that are the two highest coordinates in some set S𝑆Sitalic_S swap places in the ordering. So, for any T⊆[n]𝑇delimited-[]𝑛T\subseteq[n]italic_T ⊆ [ italic_n ] such that |T|=n−k𝑇𝑛𝑘|T|=n-k| italic_T | = italic_n - italic_k and any bijection π:[k]→[n]∖T:𝜋→delimited-[]𝑘delimited-[]𝑛𝑇\pi\colon[k]\to[n]\setminus Titalic_π : [ italic_k ] → [ italic_n ] ∖ italic_T, let

PT,π≔{x∈ℝn∣xj≤xπ⁢(1)≤…≤xπ⁢(k+1),j∈T}.≔subscript𝑃𝑇𝜋conditional-set𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛formulae-sequencesubscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑥𝜋1…subscript𝑥𝜋𝑘1𝑗𝑇P_{T,\pi}\coloneqq\{x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\mid x_{j}\leq x_{\pi(1)}\leq\ldots\leq x% _{\pi(k+1)},j\in T\}.italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T , italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ { italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ … ≤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( italic_k + 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_j ∈ italic_T } .

It follows that the set of full-dimensional cones 𝒫gnsubscriptsuperscript𝒫𝑛𝑔\mathcal{P}^{n}_{g}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the unique coarsest polyhedral complex 𝒫gsubscript𝒫𝑔\mathcal{P}_{g}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT compatible with g𝑔gitalic_g is given as 𝒫gn={Pπ,T}π,Tsuperscriptsubscript𝒫𝑔𝑛subscriptsubscript𝑃𝜋𝑇𝜋𝑇\mathcal{P}_{g}^{n}=\{P_{\pi,T}\}_{\pi,T}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π , italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π , italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Again, the unique vertex (g∗,h∗)superscript𝑔superscriptℎ(g^{*},h^{*})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) from Example A.3 is clearly a non-trivial coarsening of the decomposition obtained from the lattice representation and hence the decomposition cannot be a vertex of 𝒟𝒬⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒬𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{Q}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) for any regular polyhedral complex 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q.

Appendix C Counterexample to a construction of Tran & Wang (2024)

C.1 Duality and Newton polytopes

In this section we describe the duality between convex piecewiese linear functions and Newton polytopes, adapted to our setup.

A positively homogenous convex CPWL function is a function f𝑓fitalic_f such that f⁢(0)=0𝑓00f(0)=0italic_f ( 0 ) = 0, and 𝒫fsubscript𝒫𝑓\mathcal{P}_{f}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a polyhedral fan. In this case, it can be written as f⁢(x)=maxi∈[k]⁡⟨x,vi⟩𝑓𝑥subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑘𝑥subscript𝑣𝑖f(x)=\max_{i\in[k]}\langle x,v_{i}\rangleitalic_f ( italic_x ) = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_k ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟨ italic_x , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩, where vi∈ℝnsubscript𝑣𝑖superscriptℝ𝑛v_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We define the Newton polytope of f𝑓fitalic_f as the convex hull Newt⁡(f)=conv⁡(v1,…,vk)Newt𝑓convsubscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑘\operatorname{Newt}(f)=\operatorname{conv}(v_{1},\dots,v_{k})roman_Newt ( italic_f ) = roman_conv ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Then f𝑓fitalic_f is the support function of Newt⁡(f)Newt𝑓\operatorname{Newt}(f)roman_Newt ( italic_f ), i.e., f⁢(x)=maxp∈Newt⁡(f)⁡⟨p,x⟩𝑓𝑥subscript𝑝Newt𝑓𝑝𝑥f(x)=\max_{p\in\operatorname{Newt}(f)}\langle p,x\rangleitalic_f ( italic_x ) = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ∈ roman_Newt ( italic_f ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟨ italic_p , italic_x ⟩. We now give an interpretation of 𝒫fsubscript𝒫𝑓\mathcal{P}_{f}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and wfsubscript𝑤𝑓w_{f}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in terms of the Newton polytope.

Given any n𝑛nitalic_n-dimensional polytope P⊂ℝn𝑃superscriptℝ𝑛P\subset\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_P ⊂ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the (outer) normal cone of a k𝑘kitalic_k-dimensional face F𝐹Fitalic_F of P𝑃Pitalic_P is the (n−k)𝑛𝑘(n-k)( italic_n - italic_k )-dimensional cone

NF⁢(P)={x∈ℝn|⟨z,x⟩=maxp∈P⁡⟨p,x⟩⁢ for all ⁢z∈F}.subscript𝑁𝐹𝑃conditional-set𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛𝑧𝑥subscript𝑝𝑃𝑝𝑥 for all 𝑧𝐹N_{F}(P)=\left\{x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\ \middle|\ \langle z,x\rangle=\max_{p\in P}% \langle p,x\rangle\text{ for all }z\in F\right\}.italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_P ) = { italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | ⟨ italic_z , italic_x ⟩ = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ∈ italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟨ italic_p , italic_x ⟩ for all italic_z ∈ italic_F } . (1)

In particular, if P=Newt⁡(f)𝑃Newt𝑓P=\operatorname{Newt}(f)italic_P = roman_Newt ( italic_f ) and v𝑣vitalic_v is a vertex of P𝑃Pitalic_P, then the description of the normal cone turns into

Nv⁢(Newt⁡(f))={x∈ℝn|⟨v,x⟩=f⁢(x)},subscript𝑁𝑣Newt𝑓conditional-set𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛𝑣𝑥𝑓𝑥N_{v}(\operatorname{Newt}(f))=\left\{x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\ \middle|\ \langle v,x% \rangle=f(x)\right\},italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Newt ( italic_f ) ) = { italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | ⟨ italic_v , italic_x ⟩ = italic_f ( italic_x ) } ,

and agrees with a maximal polyhedron in 𝒫fnsuperscriptsubscript𝒫𝑓𝑛\mathcal{P}_{f}^{n}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The normal fan of a polytope is the collection of normal cones over all faces. Thus, for positively homogeneous convex functions, the polyhedral complex 𝒫fsubscript𝒫𝑓\mathcal{P}_{f}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT agrees with the normal fan of Newt⁡(f)Newt𝑓\operatorname{Newt}(f)roman_Newt ( italic_f ), and the number of linear pieces of f𝑓fitalic_f equals the number of vertices of Newt⁡(f)Newt𝑓\operatorname{Newt}(f)roman_Newt ( italic_f ). The duality between 𝒫fsubscript𝒫𝑓\mathcal{P}_{f}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Newt⁡(f)Newt𝑓\operatorname{Newt}(f)roman_Newt ( italic_f ) also establishes a bijection between faces σ∈𝒫fn−1𝜎superscriptsubscript𝒫𝑓𝑛1\sigma\in\mathcal{P}_{f}^{n-1}italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and edges of Newt⁡(f)Newt𝑓\operatorname{Newt}(f)roman_Newt ( italic_f ), and for the corresponding weight function wf∈𝒲𝒫subscript𝑤𝑓subscript𝒲𝒫w_{f}\in\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT holds that wf⁢(σ)subscript𝑤𝑓𝜎w_{f}(\sigma)italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ ) equals the Euclidean length of the edge that is dual to σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ. This correspondence extends to general convex CWPL functions, where 𝒫fsubscript𝒫𝑓\mathcal{P}_{f}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a complex which is dual to a polyhedral subdivision of Newt⁡(f)Newt𝑓\operatorname{Newt}(f)roman_Newt ( italic_f ), and wfsubscript𝑤𝑓w_{f}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT corresponds to lengths of edges in this subdivision (Maclagan & Sturmfels, 2015, Chapter 3.4).

C.2 The Construction from Tran & Wang (2024)

The duality between positively homogeneous convex CPWL functions and Newton polytopes, as described in Section C.1, serves as a motivation for Tran & Wang (2024) to construct minimal decompositions f=g−h𝑓𝑔ℎf=g-hitalic_f = italic_g - italic_h of positively homogeneous CPWL functions as the difference of two convex such functions in dimension 2222.

Theorem C.1 (Tran & Wang (2024)).

For every positively homogeneous CPWL-function f:ℝ2→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ2ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{2}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R exists a unique (up to adding a linear function) minimal representation as difference of two convex functions g,h𝑔ℎg,hitalic_g , italic_h.

The decomposition can be obtained as follows. Let 𝒫fsubscript𝒫𝑓\mathcal{P}_{f}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be a 2222-dimensional polyhedral fan compatible with f𝑓fitalic_f with rays ρ1,…,ρm⊂ℝ2subscript𝜌1…subscript𝜌𝑚superscriptℝ2\rho_{1},\dots,\rho_{m}\subset\mathbb{R}^{2}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊂ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ray generators r1,…,rm∈ℝ2subscript𝑟1…subscript𝑟𝑚superscriptℝ2r_{1},\dots,r_{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{2}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that ‖ri‖=1normsubscript𝑟𝑖1\|r_{i}\|=1∥ italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ = 1 for i=1,…,m𝑖1…𝑚i=1,\dots,mitalic_i = 1 , … , italic_m. Furthermore, let wfsubscript𝑤𝑓w_{f}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the corresponding element in 𝒲𝒫fsubscript𝒲subscript𝒫𝑓\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}_{f}}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and wf+≔max⁡{wf,0}≔subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑓subscript𝑤𝑓0w^{+}_{f}\coloneqq\max\{w_{f},0\}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ roman_max { italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 0 }. We now define an additional ray ρm+1subscript𝜌𝑚1\rho_{m+1}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with ray generator rm+1=−∑i=1mmax⁡(wf⁢(ρi),0)⁢risubscript𝑟𝑚1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑤𝑓subscript𝜌𝑖0subscript𝑟𝑖r_{m+1}=-\sum_{i=1}^{m}\max(w_{f}(\rho_{i}),0)r_{i}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_max ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , 0 ) italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and a convex function g𝑔gitalic_g through the weights

wg⁢(ρi)={wf⁢(ρi)if ⁢wf⁢(ρi)>0,i∈[m]0if ⁢wf⁢(ρi)≤0,i∈[m]∑i=1mmax⁡(wf⁢(ρi),0)if ⁢i=m+1.subscript𝑤𝑔subscript𝜌𝑖casessubscript𝑤𝑓subscript𝜌𝑖formulae-sequenceif subscript𝑤𝑓subscript𝜌𝑖0𝑖delimited-[]𝑚0formulae-sequenceif subscript𝑤𝑓subscript𝜌𝑖0𝑖delimited-[]𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑤𝑓subscript𝜌𝑖0if 𝑖𝑚1w_{g}(\rho_{i})=\begin{cases}w_{f}(\rho_{i})&\text{if }w_{f}(\rho_{i})>0,i\in[% m]\\ 0&\text{if }w_{f}(\rho_{i})\leq 0,i\in[m]\\ \sum_{i=1}^{m}\max(w_{f}(\rho_{i}),0)&\text{if }i=m+1.\end{cases}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = { start_ROW start_CELL italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL start_CELL if italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > 0 , italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ] end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL if italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ 0 , italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ] end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_max ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , 0 ) end_CELL start_CELL if italic_i = italic_m + 1 . end_CELL end_ROW

This defines the convex functions g𝑔gitalic_g, h=g−fℎ𝑔𝑓h=g-fitalic_h = italic_g - italic_f, and results in a minimal decomposition f=g−h𝑓𝑔ℎf=g-hitalic_f = italic_g - italic_h in the 2-dimensional positively homogeneous case. Considering this construction through to the duality to Newton polytopes, we can identify rays of 𝒫fsubscript𝒫𝑓\mathcal{P}_{f}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which correspond to convex breakpoints of f𝑓fitalic_f with edges of the Newton polytope Newt⁡(g)Newt𝑔\operatorname{Newt}(g)roman_Newt ( italic_g ), and the construction from Theorem C.1 adds a "missing" edge to the Newton polygon Newt⁡(g)Newt𝑔\operatorname{Newt}(g)roman_Newt ( italic_g ). We now describe the proposed construction to generalize the 2222-dimensional method to higher dimensions.

Construction C.2 (Tran & Wang (2024, Section 4.1)).

Let f:ℝn→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R be a positively homogeneous CWPL-function and 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P a polyhedral fan compatible with f𝑓fitalic_f. The attempt is to balance wf+subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑓w^{+}_{f}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT locally around every τ∈𝒫n−2𝜏superscript𝒫𝑛2\tau\in\mathcal{P}^{n-2}italic_τ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and then “glue together" the local balancings to a global balancing. So, for some τ∈𝒫n−2𝜏superscript𝒫𝑛2\tau\in\mathcal{P}^{n-2}italic_τ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, suppose that {σ1,…⁢σk}=star𝒫⁡(τ)subscript𝜎1…subscript𝜎𝑘subscriptstar𝒫𝜏\{\sigma_{1},\ldots\sigma_{k}\}=\operatorname{star}_{\mathcal{P}}(\tau){ italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } = roman_star start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_τ ) are the cones containing τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. The rays spanned by eσi/τsubscript𝑒subscript𝜎𝑖𝜏e_{\sigma_{i}/\tau}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that inherit the weights wf+⁢(σi)subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑓subscript𝜎𝑖w^{+}_{f}(\sigma_{i})italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for i∈[k]𝑖delimited-[]𝑘i\in[k]italic_i ∈ [ italic_k ] induce a 2222-dimensional fan 𝒫τsubscript𝒫𝜏\mathcal{P}_{\tau}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the 2222-dimensional linear space span(τ)⟂\operatorname{span}(\tau)^{\perp}roman_span ( italic_τ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟂ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT orthogonal to span⁡(τ)span𝜏\operatorname{span}(\tau)roman_span ( italic_τ ). Let Pτsubscript𝑃𝜏P_{\tau}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the polygon in span(τ)⟂\operatorname{span}(\tau)^{\perp}roman_span ( italic_τ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟂ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT corresponding to the minimal balancing of wf+subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑓w^{+}_{f}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT regarded as map wf+:𝒫τ1→ℝ:subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑓→superscriptsubscript𝒫𝜏1ℝw^{+}_{f}\colon\mathcal{P}_{\tau}^{1}\to\mathbb{R}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R. Now proceed with the following steps.

  1. 1.

    For every τ∈𝒫n−2𝜏superscript𝒫𝑛2\tau\in\mathcal{P}^{n-2}italic_τ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, construct the polygon Pτsubscript𝑃𝜏P_{\tau}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  2. 2.

    Place the polygons Pτsubscript𝑃𝜏P_{\tau}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in such a way, that whenever τ1,τ2∈𝒫n−2subscript𝜏1subscript𝜏2superscript𝒫𝑛2\tau_{1},\tau_{2}\in\mathcal{P}^{n-2}italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are faces of σ∈supp𝒫+⁡(f)𝜎subscriptsuperscriptsupp𝒫𝑓\sigma\in\operatorname{supp}^{+}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)italic_σ ∈ roman_supp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ), then the edges in Pτ1subscript𝑃subscript𝜏1P_{\tau_{1}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Pτ2subscript𝑃subscript𝜏2P_{\tau_{2}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that correspond to σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ are identified with each other.

  3. 3.

    Take the convex hull Pgsubscript𝑃𝑔P_{g}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the polygons {Pτ}τ∈𝒫n−2subscriptsubscript𝑃𝜏𝜏superscript𝒫𝑛2\{P_{\tau}\}_{\tau\in\mathcal{P}^{n-2}}{ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  4. 4.

    The support function g𝑔gitalic_g of the polytope Pgsubscript𝑃𝑔P_{g}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and h≔g−f≔ℎ𝑔𝑓h\coloneqq g-fitalic_h ≔ italic_g - italic_f are a decomposition of f𝑓fitalic_f.

One can check that for some σ∈𝒫n−1𝜎superscript𝒫𝑛1\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and τ∈𝒫n−2𝜏superscript𝒫𝑛2\tau\in\mathcal{P}^{n-2}italic_τ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT being a face of σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ, the edge eσsubscript𝑒𝜎e_{\sigma}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of length w⁢(σ)𝑤𝜎w(\sigma)italic_w ( italic_σ ) which is perpendicular in span(τ)⟂\operatorname{span}(\tau)^{\perp}roman_span ( italic_τ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟂ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is independent of the choice of the face τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. In particular, the direction of the edge eσsubscript𝑒𝜎e_{\sigma}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is normal to the hyperplane spanned by σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ. However, it remained unclear, whether or not, the second step in this procedure is always well-defined, that is, that placing the polygons in such a coherent way is possible. To make this more precise, let for some τ∈𝒫n−2𝜏superscript𝒫𝑛2\tau\in\mathcal{P}^{n-2}italic_τ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the edges of the polygon Pτsubscript𝑃𝜏P_{\tau}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be given in a cyclic way {eσ1,…⁢eσm}subscript𝑒subscript𝜎1…subscript𝑒subscript𝜎𝑚\{e_{\sigma_{1}},\ldots e_{\sigma_{m}}\}{ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. Placing a polygon Pτsubscript𝑃𝜏P_{\tau}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT refers to choosing an xτ∈ℝnsubscript𝑥𝜏superscriptℝ𝑛x_{\tau}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and defining the placed polygon as Pτ⁢(xτ)=conv⁡(xτ,xτ+eσ1,xτ+eσ1+eσ2,…,xτ+∑i=1meσm)subscript𝑃𝜏subscript𝑥𝜏convsubscript𝑥𝜏subscript𝑥𝜏subscript𝑒subscript𝜎1subscript𝑥𝜏subscript𝑒subscript𝜎1subscript𝑒subscript𝜎2…subscript𝑥𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑒subscript𝜎𝑚P_{\tau}(x_{\tau})=\operatorname{conv}(x_{\tau},x_{\tau}+e_{\sigma_{1}},x_{% \tau}+e_{\sigma_{1}}+e_{\sigma_{2}},\ldots,x_{\tau}+\sum_{i=1}^{m}e_{\sigma_{m% }})italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = roman_conv ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Placing them in a coherent way means choosing an xτ∈ℝnsubscript𝑥𝜏superscriptℝ𝑛x_{\tau}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for every τ∈𝒫n−2𝜏superscript𝒫𝑛2\tau\in\mathcal{P}^{n-2}italic_τ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that Pτ1⁢(xτ1)∩Pτ2⁢(xτ2)=conv⁡(xσ,xσ+eσ)subscript𝑃subscript𝜏1subscript𝑥subscript𝜏1subscript𝑃subscript𝜏2subscript𝑥subscript𝜏2convsubscript𝑥𝜎subscript𝑥𝜎subscript𝑒𝜎P_{\tau_{1}}(x_{\tau_{1}})\cap P_{\tau_{2}}(x_{\tau_{2}})=\operatorname{conv}(% x_{\sigma},x_{\sigma}+e_{\sigma})italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∩ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = roman_conv ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for some xσ∈ℝnsubscript𝑥𝜎superscriptℝ𝑛x_{\sigma}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT whenever τ1subscript𝜏1\tau_{1}italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and τ2subscript𝜏2\tau_{2}italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are faces of σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ. A priori it is not clear that such xτsubscript𝑥𝜏x_{\tau}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT always exist. The following example will in fact show that the resulting linear equation system not always yields a solution.

C.3 Counterexample to the construction

In the remaining of this section, we give a counterexample to Construction C.2, which is stated in Tran & Wang (2024) in terms of (virtual) Newton polytopes as a potential generalization of the 2222-dimensional construction to higher dimensions.

Example C.3 (Counterexample to Construction C.2).

Figure 4 is an illustration of 4444 polygons with labelled edges that cannot be placed in ℝ3superscriptℝ3\mathbb{R}^{3}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that the edges of different polygons with the same label are identified with each other. Hence, applying the above procedure to the CPWL-function f:ℝ3→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ3ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{3}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R given by

f⁢(x)=max⁡{0,maxi,j∈[3]i≠j⁡{min⁡{xi,xj−xi}}}𝑓𝑥0subscript𝑖𝑗delimited-[]3𝑖𝑗subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑥𝑖f(x)=\max\{0,\max\limits_{\begin{subarray}{c}i,j\in[3]\\ i\neq j\end{subarray}}\{\min\{x_{i},x_{j}-x_{i}\}\}\}italic_f ( italic_x ) = roman_max { 0 , roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_i , italic_j ∈ [ 3 ] end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_i ≠ italic_j end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { roman_min { italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } } }

is not well-defined since these 4444 polygons arise and should be identified in the indicated way, which is impossible.

We describe the 2222-skeleton of a polyhedral fan 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P that is compatible with f𝑓fitalic_f. Let eisubscript𝑒𝑖e_{i}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the i𝑖iitalic_i-th standard unit vector. The rays are given as follows:

𝒫1={cone(−ei),cone(ei),cone(ei+ej),cone(ei+ej+2ek),cone(ei+2ej+2ek),cone(ei+ej+2ek),cone(ei+ej+ek)∣i,j,k∈[3] pairwise distinct}superscript𝒫1conditional-setconesubscript𝑒𝑖conesubscript𝑒𝑖conesubscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗conesubscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗2subscript𝑒𝑘conesubscript𝑒𝑖2subscript𝑒𝑗2subscript𝑒𝑘conesubscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗2subscript𝑒𝑘conesubscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗subscript𝑒𝑘𝑖𝑗𝑘delimited-[]3 pairwise distinct\mathcal{P}^{1}=\{\operatorname{cone}(-e_{i}),\operatorname{cone}(e_{i}),% \operatorname{cone}(e_{i}+e_{j}),\operatorname{cone}(e_{i}+e_{j}+2e_{k}),% \operatorname{cone}(e_{i}+2e_{j}+2e_{k}),\\ \operatorname{cone}(e_{i}+e_{j}+2e_{k}),\operatorname{cone}(e_{i}+e_{j}+e_{k})% \mid i,j,k\in[3]\text{ pairwise distinct}\}start_ROW start_CELL caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { roman_cone ( - italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , roman_cone ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , roman_cone ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , roman_cone ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , roman_cone ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL roman_cone ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , roman_cone ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∣ italic_i , italic_j , italic_k ∈ [ 3 ] pairwise distinct } end_CELL end_ROW

and the 2222-dimensional cones as

𝒫2={\displaystyle\mathcal{P}^{2}=\{caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { cone⁡(ei,−ej),cone⁡(−ei,ei+ej+2⁢ek),cone⁡(−ei,ej+ek),cone⁡(ei,ei+ej+2⁢ek),conesubscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗conesubscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗2subscript𝑒𝑘conesubscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗subscript𝑒𝑘conesubscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗2subscript𝑒𝑘\displaystyle\operatorname{cone}(e_{i},-e_{j}),\operatorname{cone}(-e_{i},e_{i% }+e_{j}+2e_{k}),\operatorname{cone}(-e_{i},e_{j}+e_{k}),\operatorname{cone}(e_% {i},e_{i}+e_{j}+2e_{k}),roman_cone ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , - italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , roman_cone ( - italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , roman_cone ( - italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , roman_cone ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,
cone⁡(ej+ek,ei+ej+2⁢ek),cone⁡(ei+ej+2⁢ek,ei+2⁢ej+2⁢ek),cone⁡(ei+ej+2⁢ek,ei+ej+ek),conesubscript𝑒𝑗subscript𝑒𝑘subscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗2subscript𝑒𝑘conesubscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗2subscript𝑒𝑘subscript𝑒𝑖2subscript𝑒𝑗2subscript𝑒𝑘conesubscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗2subscript𝑒𝑘subscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗subscript𝑒𝑘\displaystyle\operatorname{cone}(e_{j}+e_{k},e_{i}+e_{j}+2e_{k}),\operatorname% {cone}(e_{i}+e_{j}+2e_{k},e_{i}+2e_{j}+2e_{k}),\operatorname{cone}(e_{i}+e_{j}% +2e_{k},e_{i}+e_{j}+e_{k}),roman_cone ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , roman_cone ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , roman_cone ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,
cone(ei+2ej+2ek,ei+ej+ek),cone(ej+ek,ei+2ej+2ek)∣i,j,k∈[3] pairwise distinct}\displaystyle\operatorname{cone}(e_{i}+2e_{j}+2e_{k},e_{i}+e_{j}+e_{k}),% \operatorname{cone}(e_{j}+e_{k},e_{i}+2e_{j}+2e_{k})\mid i,j,k\in[3]\text{ % pairwise distinct}\}roman_cone ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , roman_cone ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∣ italic_i , italic_j , italic_k ∈ [ 3 ] pairwise distinct }

The weight function wf:𝒫2→ℝ:subscript𝑤𝑓→superscript𝒫2ℝw_{f}\colon\mathcal{P}^{2}\to\mathbb{R}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R given by

w⁢(cone⁡(ei,−ej))=1𝑤conesubscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗1\displaystyle w(\operatorname{cone}(e_{i},-e_{j}))=1italic_w ( roman_cone ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , - italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = 1
w⁢(cone⁡(−ei,ei+ej+2⁢ek))=−5𝑤conesubscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗2subscript𝑒𝑘5\displaystyle w(\operatorname{cone}(-e_{i},e_{i}+e_{j}+2e_{k}))=-\sqrt{5}italic_w ( roman_cone ( - italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = - square-root start_ARG 5 end_ARG
w⁢(cone⁡(−ei,ej+ek))=8𝑤conesubscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗subscript𝑒𝑘8\displaystyle w(\operatorname{cone}(-e_{i},e_{j}+e_{k}))=\sqrt{8}italic_w ( roman_cone ( - italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = square-root start_ARG 8 end_ARG
w⁢(cone⁡(ei,ei+ej+2⁢ek))=2,𝑤conesubscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗2subscript𝑒𝑘2\displaystyle w(\operatorname{cone}(e_{i},e_{i}+e_{j}+2e_{k}))=\sqrt{2},italic_w ( roman_cone ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG ,
w⁢(cone⁡(ej+ek,ei+ej+2⁢ek))=3,𝑤conesubscript𝑒𝑗subscript𝑒𝑘subscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗2subscript𝑒𝑘3\displaystyle w(\operatorname{cone}(e_{j}+e_{k},e_{i}+e_{j}+2e_{k}))=\sqrt{3},italic_w ( roman_cone ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG ,
w⁢(cone⁡(ei+ej+2⁢ek,ei+2⁢ej+2⁢ek))=−5,𝑤conesubscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗2subscript𝑒𝑘subscript𝑒𝑖2subscript𝑒𝑗2subscript𝑒𝑘5\displaystyle w(\operatorname{cone}(e_{i}+e_{j}+2e_{k},e_{i}+2e_{j}+2e_{k}))=-% \sqrt{5},italic_w ( roman_cone ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = - square-root start_ARG 5 end_ARG ,
w⁢(cone⁡(ei+ej+2⁢ek,ei+ej+ek))=2,𝑤conesubscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗2subscript𝑒𝑘subscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗subscript𝑒𝑘2\displaystyle w(\operatorname{cone}(e_{i}+e_{j}+2e_{k},e_{i}+e_{j}+e_{k}))=% \sqrt{2},italic_w ( roman_cone ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG ,
w⁢(cone⁡(ei+2⁢ej+2⁢ek,ei+ej+ek))=2,𝑤conesubscript𝑒𝑖2subscript𝑒𝑗2subscript𝑒𝑘subscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗subscript𝑒𝑘2\displaystyle w(\operatorname{cone}(e_{i}+2e_{j}+2e_{k},e_{i}+e_{j}+e_{k}))=% \sqrt{2},italic_w ( roman_cone ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG ,
w⁢(cone⁡(ej+ek,ei+2⁢ej+2⁢ek))=0𝑤conesubscript𝑒𝑗subscript𝑒𝑘subscript𝑒𝑖2subscript𝑒𝑗2subscript𝑒𝑘0\displaystyle w(\operatorname{cone}(e_{j}+e_{k},e_{i}+2e_{j}+2e_{k}))=0italic_w ( roman_cone ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = 0

corresponds to the function f𝑓fitalic_f and is therefore balanced. See Figure 5 for a 2222-dimensional illustration of 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P.

Consider the 4444 rays

ρ1=cone⁡((0,1,1)),ρ2=cone⁡((1,1,2)),ρ3=cone⁡((1,2,1)),ρ4=cone⁡((1,1,1))formulae-sequencesubscript𝜌1cone011formulae-sequencesubscript𝜌2cone112formulae-sequencesubscript𝜌3cone121subscript𝜌4cone111\displaystyle\rho_{1}=\operatorname{cone}((0,1,1)),\rho_{2}=\operatorname{cone% }((1,1,2)),\rho_{3}=\operatorname{cone}((1,2,1)),\rho_{4}=\operatorname{cone}(% (1,1,1))italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_cone ( ( 0 , 1 , 1 ) ) , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_cone ( ( 1 , 1 , 2 ) ) , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_cone ( ( 1 , 2 , 1 ) ) , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_cone ( ( 1 , 1 , 1 ) )

The direction of the edges of the polygons are given by the normal vectors of the hyperplanes spanned by the corresponding 2222-dimensional cone and their length by the weight of the corresponding 2222-dimensional cone.

eσ1=(0,2,−2),eσ2=(1,−1,1),eσ3=(−1,−1,1),eσ4=(1,−1,0),eσ5=(1,1,−1),formulae-sequencesubscript𝑒subscript𝜎1022formulae-sequencesubscript𝑒subscript𝜎2111formulae-sequencesubscript𝑒subscript𝜎3111formulae-sequencesubscript𝑒subscript𝜎4110subscript𝑒subscript𝜎5111\displaystyle e_{\sigma_{1}}=(0,2,-2),\,e_{\sigma_{2}}=(1,-1,1),\,e_{\sigma_{3% }}=(-1,-1,1),\,e_{\sigma_{4}}=(1,-1,0),\,e_{\sigma_{5}}=(1,1,-1),\,italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 0 , 2 , - 2 ) , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 , - 1 , 1 ) , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( - 1 , - 1 , 1 ) , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 , - 1 , 0 ) , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 , 1 , - 1 ) ,

In order to construct the polygons one needs to consider the orientation of the edge (and the normal vector) in the particular polygon. Figure 4 already shows that they cannot be placed in a coherent way. To make this mathematically precise, one obtains a system of linear equations for xρ1,xρ2,xρ3subscript𝑥subscript𝜌1subscript𝑥subscript𝜌2subscript𝑥subscript𝜌3x_{\rho_{1}},x_{\rho_{2}},x_{\rho_{3}}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and xρ4subscript𝑥subscript𝜌4x_{\rho_{4}}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, by plugging in the values for the normal vectors, that ensures that the edges for the same 2222-dimensional cone in different polygons are identified. This linear equation system does not have a solution.

Appendix D Submodular Functions

This section is a detailed version of Section 5, where we demonstrate that a special case of our framework is to decompose a general set function into a difference of submodular set funtions and translate our results to this setting. Such decompositions are a popular approach to solve optimization problems as disussed in the introduction.

Definition D.1.

The braid arrangement in ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the hyperplane arrangement consisting of the (n2)binomial𝑛2\binom{n}{2}( FRACOP start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) hyperplanes xi=xjsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗x_{i}=x_{j}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with 1≤i<j≤n1𝑖𝑗𝑛1\leq i<j\leq n1 ≤ italic_i < italic_j ≤ italic_n.

For the remaining section, let 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P be the polyhedral complex arising from the braid arrangement. Let ℱnsubscriptℱ𝑛\mathcal{F}_{n}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the vector space of set functions from 2[n]superscript2delimited-[]𝑛2^{[n]}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to ℝℝ\mathbb{R}blackboard_R. We first show that functions in 𝒱𝒫subscript𝒱𝒫\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are in one-to-one correspondence with the set functions ℱnsubscriptℱ𝑛\mathcal{F}_{n}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To this end, for a set S⊆[n]𝑆delimited-[]𝑛S\subseteq[n]italic_S ⊆ [ italic_n ], let 𝟙S=∑i∈Seisubscript1𝑆subscript𝑖𝑆subscript𝑒𝑖\mathds{1}_{S}=\sum_{i\in S}e_{i}blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the indicator vector of S𝑆Sitalic_S, that is, the vector that contains entries 1111 for indices in S𝑆Sitalic_S and 00 otherwise.

Proposition D.2.

The mapping ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ that maps f∈𝒱𝒫𝑓subscript𝒱𝒫f\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to the set function F⁢(S)=f⁢(𝟙S)𝐹𝑆𝑓subscript1𝑆F(S)=f(\mathds{1}_{S})italic_F ( italic_S ) = italic_f ( blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a vector space isomorphism.

Proof.

The map ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ is clearly a linear map. To prove that ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ is an isomorphism, we show that a function f∈𝒱𝒫𝑓subscript𝒱𝒫f\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is uniquely determined by its values on {𝟙S}S⊆[n]subscriptsubscript1𝑆𝑆delimited-[]𝑛\{\mathds{1}_{S}\}_{S\subseteq[n]}{ blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S ⊆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and any choice of real values {yS}S⊆[n]subscriptsubscript𝑦𝑆𝑆delimited-[]𝑛\{y_{S}\}_{S\subseteq[n]}{ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S ⊆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT give rise to a function f∈𝒱𝒫𝑓subscript𝒱𝒫f\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that f⁢(𝟙S)=yS𝑓subscript1𝑆subscript𝑦𝑆f(\mathds{1}_{S})=y_{S}italic_f ( blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

First, note that the maximal polyhedra 𝒫nsuperscript𝒫𝑛\mathcal{P}^{n}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are of the form Pπ={x∈ℝn∣xπ⁢(1)≤…≤xπ⁢(n)}subscript𝑃𝜋conditional-set𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛subscript𝑥𝜋1…subscript𝑥𝜋𝑛P_{\pi}=\{x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\mid x_{\pi(1)}\leq\ldots\leq x_{\pi(n)}\}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ … ≤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } for a permutation π:[n]→[n]:𝜋→delimited-[]𝑛delimited-[]𝑛\pi\colon[n]\to[n]italic_π : [ italic_n ] → [ italic_n ]. There are exactly the n+1𝑛1n+1italic_n + 1 indicator vectors {𝟙Si}i=0,…,nsubscriptsubscript1subscript𝑆𝑖𝑖0…𝑛\{\mathds{1}_{S_{i}}\}_{i=0,\ldots,n}{ blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 0 , … , italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contained in Pπsubscript𝑃𝜋P_{\pi}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where Si≔{π⁢(n+1−i),…,π⁢(n)}≔subscript𝑆𝑖𝜋𝑛1𝑖…𝜋𝑛S_{i}\coloneqq\{\pi(n+1-i),\ldots,\pi(n)\}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ { italic_π ( italic_n + 1 - italic_i ) , … , italic_π ( italic_n ) } for i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] and S0≔∅≔subscript𝑆0S_{0}\coloneqq\emptysetitalic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ ∅. Moreover, the vectors {𝟙Si}i=0,…,nsubscriptsubscript1subscript𝑆𝑖𝑖0…𝑛\{\mathds{1}_{S_{i}}\}_{i=0,\ldots,n}{ blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 0 , … , italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are affinely independent and hence the values {f⁢(𝟙Si)}i=0,…,nsubscript𝑓subscript1subscript𝑆𝑖𝑖0…𝑛\{f(\mathds{1}_{S_{i}})\}_{i=0,\ldots,n}{ italic_f ( blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 0 , … , italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT uniquely determine the affine linear function f|Pπevaluated-at𝑓subscript𝑃𝜋f|_{P_{\pi}}italic_f | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, f𝑓fitalic_f is uniquely determined by {f⁢(𝟙Si)}S⊆[n]subscript𝑓subscript1subscript𝑆𝑖𝑆delimited-[]𝑛\{f(\mathds{1}_{S_{i}})\}_{S\subseteq[n]}{ italic_f ( blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S ⊆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Given any values {yS}S⊆[n]subscriptsubscript𝑦𝑆𝑆delimited-[]𝑛\{y_{S}\}_{S\subseteq[n]}{ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S ⊆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, by the discussion above, there are unique affine linear maps f|Pπevaluated-at𝑓subscript𝑃𝜋f|_{P_{\pi}}italic_f | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT yielding f|Pπ⁢(𝟙S)=ySevaluated-at𝑓subscript𝑃𝜋subscript1𝑆subscript𝑦𝑆f|_{P_{\pi}}(\mathds{1}_{S})=y_{S}italic_f | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all S⊆[n]𝑆delimited-[]𝑛S\subseteq[n]italic_S ⊆ [ italic_n ] such that 𝟙S∈Pπsubscript1𝑆subscript𝑃𝜋\mathds{1}_{S}\in P_{\pi}blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. It remains to show that the resulting function f𝑓fitalic_f is well-defined on the facets 𝒫n−1superscript𝒫𝑛1\mathcal{P}^{n-1}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Any such facet is of the form

σπ,i={x∈ℝn∣xπ⁢(1)≤…≤xπ⁢(i)=xπ⁢(i+1)≤…≤xπ⁢(n)},subscript𝜎𝜋𝑖conditional-set𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛subscript𝑥𝜋1…subscript𝑥𝜋𝑖subscript𝑥𝜋𝑖1…subscript𝑥𝜋𝑛\sigma_{\pi,i}=\{x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\mid x_{\pi(1)}\leq\ldots\leq x_{\pi(i)}=x_% {\pi(i+1)}\leq\ldots\leq x_{\pi(n)}\},italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ … ≤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( italic_i + 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ … ≤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } ,

which is the intersection of Pπsubscript𝑃𝜋P_{\pi}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Pπ∘(i,i+1)subscript𝑃𝜋𝑖𝑖1P_{\pi\circ(i,i+1)}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ∘ ( italic_i , italic_i + 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where (i,i+1)𝑖𝑖1(i,i+1)( italic_i , italic_i + 1 ) denotes the transposition swapping i𝑖iitalic_i and i+1𝑖1i+1italic_i + 1.
