However, the indicator vectors {𝟙Si}i∈[n]∖{i}subscriptsubscript1subscript𝑆𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛𝑖\{\mathds{1}_{S_{i}}\}_{i\in[n]\setminus\{i\}}{ blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] ∖ { italic_i } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contained in σπ,isubscript𝜎𝜋𝑖\sigma_{\pi,i}italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are a subset of the indicator vectors contained in Pπsubscript𝑃𝜋P_{\pi}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Pπ∘(i,i+1)subscript𝑃𝜋𝑖𝑖1P_{\pi\circ(i,i+1)}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ∘ ( italic_i , italic_i + 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, it holds that f|Pπ⁢(x)=f|Pπ∘(i,i+1)⁢(x)evaluated-at𝑓subscript𝑃𝜋𝑥evaluated-at𝑓subscript𝑃𝜋𝑖𝑖1𝑥f|_{P_{\pi}}(x)=f|_{P_{\pi\circ(i,i+1)}}(x)italic_f | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_f | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ∘ ( italic_i , italic_i + 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) for all x∈σπ,i𝑥subscript𝜎𝜋𝑖x\in\sigma_{\pi,i}italic_x ∈ italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT implying that f𝑓fitalic_f is well-defined as a CPWL function. ∎

If we think this the other way around, starting with a set function F𝐹Fitalic_F, then f=Φ−1⁢(F)𝑓superscriptΦ1𝐹f=\Phi^{-1}(F)italic_f = roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ) is by definition a continuous extension of F𝐹Fitalic_F. It turns out that this particular extension is known as the Lovász extension (Lovász, 1983), as we argue below. The Lovász extension is an important concept in the theory and practice of submodular function optimization as it provides a link between discrete submodular functions and continuous convex functions.

Definition D.3.

For a set function F:2[n]→ℝ:𝐹→superscript2delimited-[]𝑛ℝF\colon 2^{[n]}\to\mathbb{R}italic_F : 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R, the Lovász extension f:ℝn→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R is defined by f⁢(x)=∑i=0nλi⁢F⁢(Si)𝑓𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑛subscript𝜆𝑖𝐹subscript𝑆𝑖f(x)=\sum_{i=0}^{n}\lambda_{i}F(S_{i})italic_f ( italic_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where ∅=S0⊂S1⊂…⊂Sn=[n]subscript𝑆0subscript𝑆1…subscript𝑆𝑛delimited-[]𝑛\emptyset=S_{0}\subset S_{1}\subset\ldots\subset S_{n}=[n]∅ = italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊂ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊂ … ⊂ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ italic_n ] is a chain such that ∑i=1nλi⁢𝟙Si=xsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝜆𝑖subscript1subscript𝑆𝑖𝑥\sum_{i=1}^{n}\lambda_{i}\mathds{1}_{S_{i}}=x∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x and λi≥0subscript𝜆𝑖0\lambda_{i}\geq 0italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0 for all i∈[n−1]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛1i\in[n-1]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n - 1 ] and λ0=1−∑i=1nλisubscript𝜆01superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{0}=1-\sum_{i=1}^{n}\lambda_{i}italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 - ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Remark D.4.

In many contexts in the literature, the Lovász extension is only defined on the hypercube [0,1]nsuperscript01𝑛[0,1]^{n}[ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For our purposes, it is more convenient to omit this restriction, which is captured by the above definition.

The intuition of the Lovász extension can already be seen in the proof of Proposition D.2: depending on the ordering of the components of an input vector x𝑥xitalic_x, the Lovász extension writes x𝑥xitalic_x as an affine combination of indicator vectors 𝟙Sisubscript1subscript𝑆𝑖\mathds{1}_{S_{i}}blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and uses the coefficients of the affine combination to compute the value f⁢(x)𝑓𝑥f(x)italic_f ( italic_x ). Following the intuition, we see in the next proposition that Φ−1⁢(F)superscriptΦ1𝐹\Phi^{-1}(F)roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ) is actually the Lovász extension of F𝐹Fitalic_F.

Proposition D.5.

For a set function F∈ℱn𝐹subscriptℱ𝑛F\in\mathcal{F}_{n}italic_F ∈ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the function f=Φ−1⁢(F)𝑓superscriptΦ1𝐹f=\Phi^{-1}(F)italic_f = roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ) is precisely the Lovász extension of F𝐹Fitalic_F.

Proof.

By the definition of the Lovász extension, it follows that it is compatible with 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. Thus, the Lovász extension is contained in 𝒱𝒫subscript𝒱𝒫\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Moreover, as it is an extension that fixes indicator vectors, it follows that ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ applied to the Lovász extension of F𝐹Fitalic_F gives us back F𝐹Fitalic_F. As ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ is an isomorphism by Proposition D.2, the Lovász extension must be exactly Φ−1⁢(F)superscriptΦ1𝐹\Phi^{-1}(F)roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ). ∎

Definition D.6.

A set function F:2[n]→ℝ:𝐹→superscript2delimited-[]𝑛ℝF\colon 2^{[n]}\to\mathbb{R}italic_F : 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R is called submodular if

F⁢(A)+F⁢(B)≥F⁢(A∪B)+F⁢(A∩B)𝐹𝐴𝐹𝐵𝐹𝐴𝐵𝐹𝐴𝐵F(A)+F(B)\geq F(A\cup B)+F(A\cap B)italic_F ( italic_A ) + italic_F ( italic_B ) ≥ italic_F ( italic_A ∪ italic_B ) + italic_F ( italic_A ∩ italic_B ) (2)

for all A,B⊆[n]𝐴𝐵delimited-[]𝑛A,B\subseteq[n]italic_A , italic_B ⊆ [ italic_n ]. F𝐹Fitalic_F is called modular if equality holds for all A,B⊆[n]𝐴𝐵delimited-[]𝑛A,B\subseteq[n]italic_A , italic_B ⊆ [ italic_n ].

The following well-known property is key to the insights of this section.

Proposition D.7 (Lovász (1983)).

A set function F𝐹Fitalic_F is submodular if and only if its Lovász extension f=Φ−1⁢(F)𝑓superscriptΦ1𝐹f=\Phi^{-1}(F)italic_f = roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ) is convex.

Applying our insights from Section 3 to the previous proposition, we obtain the following well-known statement.

Corollary D.8.

The set of submodular functions forms a polyhedral cone 𝒮⁢ℳn𝒮subscriptℳ𝑛\mathcal{SM}_{n}caligraphic_S caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the vector space ℱnsubscriptℱ𝑛\mathcal{F}_{n}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

In particular, we can specialize 1.1 in the setting of this section as follows.

Problem D.9.

Given a set function F∈ℱn𝐹subscriptℱ𝑛F\in\mathcal{F}_{n}italic_F ∈ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, how to decompose it into a difference of submodular set functions such that their Lovász extensions have as few pieces as possible?

Having a Lovász extension with few pieces is desirable because it allows the submodular function to be stored and accessed efficiently during computational tasks. As D.9 is a special case of 1.1, we are able to translate our results from Section 3 to the setting of submodular functions.

Let ℳn⊆ℱnsubscriptℳ𝑛subscriptℱ𝑛\mathcal{M}_{n}\subseteq\mathcal{F}_{n}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the vector space of modular functions, that is, set functions that satisfy equation 2 with equality. Note that a set function is modular if and only if its Lovász extension is an affine function (Lovász, 1983). Since for any M∈ℳn𝑀subscriptℳ𝑛M\in\mathcal{M}_{n}italic_M ∈ caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, a set function F𝐹Fitalic_F is submodular if and only if F+M𝐹𝑀F+Mitalic_F + italic_M is submodular, we define the vector space ℱ¯n=ℱn/ℳnsubscript¯ℱ𝑛subscriptℱ𝑛subscriptℳ𝑛\overline{\mathcal{F}}_{n}=\mathcal{F}_{n}/\mathcal{M}_{n}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of set functions modulo modular functions. Furthermore, let 𝒮⁢ℳ¯nsubscript¯𝒮ℳ𝑛\overline{\mathcal{SM}}_{n}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_S caligraphic_M end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the cone of submodular functions in this quotient. A decomposition (G,H)∈𝒮⁢ℳ¯n×𝒮⁢ℳ¯n𝐺𝐻subscript¯𝒮ℳ𝑛subscript¯𝒮ℳ𝑛(G,H)\in\overline{\mathcal{SM}}_{n}\times\overline{\mathcal{SM}}_{n}( italic_G , italic_H ) ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_S caligraphic_M end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT × over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_S caligraphic_M end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of a set function F∈ℱ¯n𝐹subscript¯ℱ𝑛F\in\overline{\mathcal{F}}_{n}italic_F ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is called irreducible if there does not exist a submodular function I∈𝒮⁢ℳ¯n∖{0}𝐼subscript¯𝒮ℳ𝑛0I\in\overline{\mathcal{SM}}_{n}\setminus\{0\}italic_I ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_S caligraphic_M end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ { 0 } such that G−I𝐺𝐼G-Iitalic_G - italic_I and H−I𝐻𝐼H-Iitalic_H - italic_I are submodular. Since a set function M∈ℱn𝑀subscriptℱ𝑛M\in\mathcal{F}_{n}italic_M ∈ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is modular if and only if Φ−1⁢(M)superscriptΦ1𝑀\Phi^{-1}(M)roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_M ) is affine linear, the isomorphism ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ of Proposition D.2 descends to an isomorphism Φ¯:ℱ¯n→𝒱¯𝒫:¯Φ→subscript¯ℱ𝑛subscript¯𝒱𝒫\overline{\Phi}\colon\overline{\mathcal{F}}_{n}\to\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{% \mathcal{P}}over¯ start_ARG roman_Φ end_ARG : over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that Φ¯⁢(𝒮⁢ℳ¯n)=𝒱¯𝒫+¯Φsubscript¯𝒮ℳ𝑛superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫\overline{\Phi}(\overline{\mathcal{SM}}_{n})=\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{% P}}^{+}over¯ start_ARG roman_Φ end_ARG ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_S caligraphic_M end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

For a set function F∈ℱ¯n𝐹subscript¯ℱ𝑛F\in\overline{\mathcal{F}}_{n}italic_F ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the set of decompositions 𝒟⁢(F)≔{(G,H)∈𝒮⁢ℳ¯n×𝒮⁢ℳ¯n∣F=G−H}≔𝒟𝐹conditional-set𝐺𝐻subscript¯𝒮ℳ𝑛subscript¯𝒮ℳ𝑛𝐹𝐺𝐻\mathcal{D}(F)\coloneqq\{(G,H)\in\overline{\mathcal{SM}}_{n}\times\overline{% \mathcal{SM}}_{n}\mid F=G-H\}caligraphic_D ( italic_F ) ≔ { ( italic_G , italic_H ) ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_S caligraphic_M end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT × over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_S caligraphic_M end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_F = italic_G - italic_H } is a polyhedron.

Corollary D.10.

A decomposition (G,H)𝐺𝐻(G,H)( italic_G , italic_H ) is irreducible if and only if (G,H)𝐺𝐻(G,H)( italic_G , italic_H ) is contained in a bounded face of 𝒟⁢(ℱ)𝒟ℱ\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_D ( caligraphic_F ).

Proof.

The extension of Φ¯¯Φ\overline{\Phi}over¯ start_ARG roman_Φ end_ARG to the cartesian product Φ¯×Φ¯:𝒱¯𝒫×𝒱¯𝒫→ℱ¯n×ℱ¯n:¯Φ¯Φ→subscript¯𝒱𝒫subscript¯𝒱𝒫subscript¯ℱ𝑛subscript¯ℱ𝑛\overline{\Phi}\times\overline{\Phi}\colon\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}% \times\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}\to\overline{\mathcal{F}}_{n}\times% \overline{\mathcal{F}}_{n}over¯ start_ARG roman_Φ end_ARG × over¯ start_ARG roman_Φ end_ARG : over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT × over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT × over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an isomorphism. Then the statement follows from the fact that 𝒟(F)=(Φ¯×Φ¯)(𝒟𝒫(Φ−1(F))\mathcal{D}(F)=(\overline{\Phi}\times\overline{\Phi})(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}% }(\Phi^{-1}(F))caligraphic_D ( italic_F ) = ( over¯ start_ARG roman_Φ end_ARG × over¯ start_ARG roman_Φ end_ARG ) ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ) ) and Theorem 3.8. ∎

Definition D.11.

For a submodular function F:2[n]→ℝ:𝐹→superscript2delimited-[]𝑛ℝF\colon 2^{[n]}\to\mathbb{R}italic_F : 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R, the base polytope B⁢(F)𝐵𝐹B(F)italic_B ( italic_F ) is defined as

B⁢(F)≔{x∈ℝn∣∑i∈Sxi≤F⁢(S)⁢∀S⊂[n],∑i∈[n]xi=F⁢([n])}.≔𝐵𝐹conditional-set𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛formulae-sequencesubscript𝑖𝑆subscript𝑥𝑖𝐹𝑆for-all𝑆delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖𝐹delimited-[]𝑛B(F)\coloneqq\{x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\mid\sum_{i\in S}x_{i}\leq F(S)\,\forall S% \subset[n],\sum_{i\in[n]}x_{i}=F([n])\}.italic_B ( italic_F ) ≔ { italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_F ( italic_S ) ∀ italic_S ⊂ [ italic_n ] , ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_F ( [ italic_n ] ) } .

Since we factored out modular functions, we can assume without loss of generality that a set function F∈ℱ¯n𝐹subscript¯ℱ𝑛F\in\overline{\mathcal{F}}_{n}italic_F ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is normalized, that is, F⁢(∅)=0𝐹0F(\emptyset)=0italic_F ( ∅ ) = 0. In this case, f=Φ−1⁢(F)𝑓superscriptΦ1𝐹f=\Phi^{-1}(F)italic_f = roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ) is positively homogeneous. For the remaining chapter, we will assume all set functions to be normalized and all CPWL functions to be positively homogeneous. If F𝐹Fitalic_F is submodular, f𝑓fitalic_f agrees with the support function of the base polytope B⁢(F)𝐵𝐹B(F)italic_B ( italic_F ), and therefore B⁢(F)𝐵𝐹B(F)italic_B ( italic_F ) is the Newton polytope Newt⁡(f)Newt𝑓\operatorname{Newt}(f)roman_Newt ( italic_f ) of the Lovász extension f𝑓fitalic_f (see e.g. Aguiar & Ardila (2017) Theorem 12.3.). The Newton polytopes of functions that differ by a linear map are a translation of each other and modular functions correspond to linear functions. Hence, if we denote by ℬ¯nsubscript¯ℬ𝑛\overline{\mathcal{B}}_{n}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_B end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the set of base polytopes in ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT modulo translation, the maps B:ℱ¯n→ℬ¯n,F↦B⁢(F):𝐵formulae-sequence→subscript¯ℱ𝑛subscript¯ℬ𝑛maps-to𝐹𝐵𝐹B\colon\overline{\mathcal{F}}_{n}\to\overline{\mathcal{B}}_{n},F\mapsto B(F)italic_B : over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_B end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F ↦ italic_B ( italic_F ) and Newt:𝒱¯𝒫→ℬ¯n,f↦Newt⁡(f):Newtformulae-sequence→subscript¯𝒱𝒫subscript¯ℬ𝑛maps-to𝑓Newt𝑓\operatorname{Newt}\colon\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}\to\overline{% \mathcal{B}}_{n},f\mapsto\operatorname{Newt}(f)roman_Newt : over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_B end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f ↦ roman_Newt ( italic_f ) are well defined and we obtain the following diagramm:

In this setting, we call a decomposition (G,H)∈𝒟⁢(F)𝐺𝐻𝒟𝐹(G,H)\in\mathcal{D}(F)( italic_G , italic_H ) ∈ caligraphic_D ( italic_F ) minimal, if it is not dominated by any other decomposition, that is, if there is no other decomposition (G′,H′)∈𝒟⁢(F)superscript𝐺′superscript𝐻′𝒟𝐹(G^{\prime},H^{\prime})\in\mathcal{D}(F)( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_D ( italic_F ) where B⁢(G′)𝐵superscript𝐺′B(G^{\prime})italic_B ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) has at most as many vertices as B⁢(G)𝐵𝐺B(G)italic_B ( italic_G ), B⁢(H′)𝐵superscript𝐻′B(H^{\prime})italic_B ( italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) has at most as many vertices as B⁢(H)𝐵𝐻B(H)italic_B ( italic_H ), and one of the two has strictly fewer vertices.

For a tuple of submodular functions (G,H)∈𝒮⁢ℳ¯×𝒮⁢ℳ¯𝐺𝐻¯𝒮ℳ¯𝒮ℳ(G,H)\in\overline{\mathcal{SM}}\times\overline{\mathcal{SM}}( italic_G , italic_H ) ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_S caligraphic_M end_ARG × over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_S caligraphic_M end_ARG, let (𝒫G,𝒫H)subscript𝒫𝐺subscript𝒫𝐻(\mathcal{P}_{G},\mathcal{P}_{H})( caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) be the tuple of the normal fans of the base polytopes B⁢(G)𝐵𝐺B(G)italic_B ( italic_G ) and B⁢(H)𝐵𝐻B(H)italic_B ( italic_H ). A decomposition (G′,H′)∈𝒟⁢(F)superscript𝐺′superscript𝐻′𝒟𝐹(G^{\prime},H^{\prime})\in\mathcal{D}(F)( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_D ( italic_F ) is called a (non-trivial) coarsening of (G,H)∈𝒟⁢(F)𝐺𝐻𝒟𝐹(G,H)\in\mathcal{D}(F)( italic_G , italic_H ) ∈ caligraphic_D ( italic_F ) if 𝒫G′subscript𝒫superscript𝐺′\mathcal{P}_{G^{\prime}}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝒫H′subscript𝒫superscript𝐻′\mathcal{P}_{H^{\prime}}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are coarsenings of 𝒫Gsubscript𝒫𝐺\mathcal{P}_{G}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝒫Hsubscript𝒫𝐻\mathcal{P}_{H}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively (and at least one of them is a non-trivial coarsening).

Corollary D.12.

(G,H)∈𝒟⁢(F)𝐺𝐻𝒟𝐹(G,H)\in\mathcal{D}(F)( italic_G , italic_H ) ∈ caligraphic_D ( italic_F ) is a vertex if and only if there is no non-trivial coarsening of (G,H)𝐺𝐻(G,H)( italic_G , italic_H ).

Proof.

Since g=Φ−1⁢(G)𝑔superscriptΦ1𝐺g=\Phi^{-1}(G)italic_g = roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_G ) and h=Φ−1⁢(H)ℎsuperscriptΦ1𝐻h=\Phi^{-1}(H)italic_h = roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_H ) are the support functions of the base polytopes B⁢(G)𝐵𝐺B(G)italic_B ( italic_G ) respectively B⁢(H)𝐵𝐻B(H)italic_B ( italic_H ), the tuple of normal fans (𝒫G,𝒫H)subscript𝒫𝐺subscript𝒫𝐻(\mathcal{P}_{G},\mathcal{P}_{H})( caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) agrees with the tuple (𝒫g,𝒫h)subscript𝒫𝑔subscript𝒫ℎ(\mathcal{P}_{g},\mathcal{P}_{h})( caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of the unique coarsest polyhedral complexes compatible with g𝑔gitalic_g and hℎhitalic_h. Hence by Theorem 3.11, there is no non-trivial coarsening of (G,H)𝐺𝐻(G,H)( italic_G , italic_H ) if and only if (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is a vertex of 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) which is the case if and only if (G,H)𝐺𝐻(G,H)( italic_G , italic_H ) is a vertex of 𝒟⁢(F)𝒟𝐹\mathcal{D}(F)caligraphic_D ( italic_F ). ∎

Corollary D.13.

For a normalized set function F∈ℱ¯n𝐹subscript¯ℱ𝑛F\in\overline{\mathcal{F}}_{n}italic_F ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, a minimal decomposition of F𝐹Fitalic_F is a vertex of 𝒟⁢(F)𝒟𝐹\mathcal{D}(F)caligraphic_D ( italic_F ).

Proof.

If (G,H)𝐺𝐻(G,H)( italic_G , italic_H ) is not a vertex, then there is a coarsening (G′,H′)∈𝒟⁢(F)superscript𝐺′superscript𝐻′𝒟𝐹(G^{\prime},H^{\prime})\in\mathcal{D}(F)( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_D ( italic_F ) of (G,H)𝐺𝐻(G,H)( italic_G , italic_H ) implying that (G′,H′)superscript𝐺′superscript𝐻′(G^{\prime},H^{\prime})( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) dominates (G,H)𝐺𝐻(G,H)( italic_G , italic_H ). ∎

The following example shows that the Lovász extensions of cut functions are hyperplane functions thus admit a unique minimal decomposition into submodular functions, which are themselves cut functions. In particular, the Lovász extensions of the decomposition have at most as many pieces as the Lovász extensions of the original cut function.

Example D.14 (Minimal decompositions of cut functions).

Let G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E ) be a graph where V=[n]𝑉delimited-[]𝑛V=[n]italic_V = [ italic_n ] and c:E→ℝ:𝑐→𝐸ℝc\colon E\to\mathbb{R}italic_c : italic_E → blackboard_R a weight function on the edges. Let F∈ℱn𝐹subscriptℱ𝑛F\in\mathcal{F}_{n}italic_F ∈ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the cut function given by F⁢(S)=∑{u,v}∈δ⁢(S)c⁢({u,v})𝐹𝑆subscript𝑢𝑣𝛿𝑆𝑐𝑢𝑣F(S)=\sum_{\{u,v\}\in\delta(S)}c(\{u,v\})italic_F ( italic_S ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_u , italic_v } ∈ italic_δ ( italic_S ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c ( { italic_u , italic_v } ), where δ⁢(S)≔{{u,v}∈E∣u∈S,v∈V∖S}≔𝛿𝑆conditional-set𝑢𝑣𝐸formulae-sequence𝑢𝑆𝑣𝑉𝑆\delta(S)\coloneqq\{\{u,v\}\in E\mid u\in S,v\in V\setminus S\}italic_δ ( italic_S ) ≔ { { italic_u , italic_v } ∈ italic_E ∣ italic_u ∈ italic_S , italic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_S }. The function f≔Φ−1⁢(F)∈𝒱𝒫≔𝑓superscriptΦ1𝐹subscript𝒱𝒫f\coloneqq\Phi^{-1}(F)\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ≔ roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is given by f⁢(x)=∑{u,v}∈Ec⁢({u,v})⋅fu,v⁢(x)𝑓𝑥subscript𝑢𝑣𝐸⋅𝑐𝑢𝑣subscript𝑓𝑢𝑣𝑥f(x)=\sum_{\{u,v\}\in E}c(\{u,v\})\cdot f_{u,v}(x)italic_f ( italic_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_u , italic_v } ∈ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c ( { italic_u , italic_v } ) ⋅ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ), where fu,v⁢(x)=max⁡{xu−xv,xv−xu}subscript𝑓𝑢𝑣𝑥subscript𝑥𝑢subscript𝑥𝑣subscript𝑥𝑣subscript𝑥𝑢f_{u,v}(x)=\max\{x_{u}-x_{v},x_{v}-x_{u}\}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = roman_max { italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. To see this, first note that f∈𝒱𝒫𝑓subscript𝒱𝒫f\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Thus, it suffices to check that F⁢(S)=f⁢(𝟙S)𝐹𝑆𝑓subscript1𝑆F(S)=f(\mathds{1}_{S})italic_F ( italic_S ) = italic_f ( blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for all S⊆[n]𝑆delimited-[]𝑛S\subseteq[n]italic_S ⊆ [ italic_n ], which follows due to the observation that

fu,v⁢(𝟙S)={1{u,v}∈δ⁢(S)0{u,v}∉δ⁢(S)subscript𝑓𝑢𝑣subscript1𝑆cases1𝑢𝑣𝛿𝑆0𝑢𝑣𝛿𝑆f_{u,v}(\mathds{1}_{S})=\begin{cases}1&\{u,v\}\in\delta(S)\\ 0&\{u,v\}\not\in\delta(S)\end{cases}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = { start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL start_CELL { italic_u , italic_v } ∈ italic_δ ( italic_S ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL { italic_u , italic_v } ∉ italic_δ ( italic_S ) end_CELL end_ROW

Hence, Example A.2 implies that the functions

g=∑c⁢({u,v})>0c⁢({u,v})⋅fu,v⁢ and ⁢h=∑c⁢({u,v})<0c⁢({u,v})⋅fu,v𝑔subscript𝑐𝑢𝑣0⋅𝑐𝑢𝑣subscript𝑓𝑢𝑣 and ℎsubscript𝑐𝑢𝑣0⋅𝑐𝑢𝑣subscript𝑓𝑢𝑣g=\sum_{c(\{u,v\})>0}c(\{u,v\})\cdot f_{u,v}\text{ and }h=\sum_{c(\{u,v\})<0}c% (\{u,v\})\cdot f_{u,v}italic_g = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c ( { italic_u , italic_v } ) > 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c ( { italic_u , italic_v } ) ⋅ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and italic_h = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c ( { italic_u , italic_v } ) < 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c ( { italic_u , italic_v } ) ⋅ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

form the unique minimal decomposition of f𝑓fitalic_f. Thus, G=Φ⁢(g)𝐺Φ𝑔G=\Phi(g)italic_G = roman_Φ ( italic_g ) and H=Φ⁢(h)𝐻ΦℎH=\Phi(h)italic_H = roman_Φ ( italic_h ), the submodular functions given by

G⁢(S)=∑{u,v}∈δ⁢(S)c⁢({u,v})>0c⁢({u,v})⁢ and ⁢H⁢(S)=∑{u,v}∈δ⁢(S)c⁢({u,v})<0c⁢({u,v})𝐺𝑆subscript𝑢𝑣𝛿𝑆𝑐𝑢𝑣0𝑐𝑢𝑣 and 𝐻𝑆subscript𝑢𝑣𝛿𝑆𝑐𝑢𝑣0𝑐𝑢𝑣G(S)=\sum\limits_{\begin{subarray}{c}\{u,v\}\in\delta(S)\\ c(\{u,v\})>0\end{subarray}}c(\{u,v\})\text{ and }H(S)=\sum\limits_{\begin{% subarray}{c}\{u,v\}\in\delta(S)\\ c(\{u,v\})<0\end{subarray}}c(\{u,v\})italic_G ( italic_S ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL { italic_u , italic_v } ∈ italic_δ ( italic_S ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_c ( { italic_u , italic_v } ) > 0 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c ( { italic_u , italic_v } ) and italic_H ( italic_S ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL { italic_u , italic_v } ∈ italic_δ ( italic_S ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_c ( { italic_u , italic_v } ) < 0 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c ( { italic_u , italic_v } )

are the unique minimal decompositions of F𝐹Fitalic_F into submodular functions.

Appendix E Proofs

E.1 Proof of Lemma 3.1

Proof.

Let f,g𝑓𝑔f,gitalic_f , italic_g be CPWL functions which are compatible with 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P, and λ,μ∈ℝ𝜆𝜇ℝ\lambda,\mu\in\mathbb{R}italic_λ , italic_μ ∈ blackboard_R. Then for any P∈𝒫n𝑃subscript𝒫𝑛P\in\mathcal{P}_{n}italic_P ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT holds (λ⁢f+μ⁢g)|P=λ⁢f|P+μ⁢g|Pevaluated-at𝜆𝑓𝜇𝑔𝑃evaluated-at𝜆𝑓𝑃evaluated-at𝜇𝑔𝑃(\lambda f+\mu g)|_{P}=\lambda f|_{P}+\mu g|_{P}( italic_λ italic_f + italic_μ italic_g ) | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_λ italic_f | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_μ italic_g | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is an affine function restricted to P𝑃Pitalic_P. Thus, the set 𝒱𝒫subscript𝒱𝒫\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of CPWL functions compatible with 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P forms a linear subspace of the space of continuous functions. ∎

E.2 Proof of Lemma 3.2

Proof.

Let f∈𝒱𝒫𝑓subscript𝒱𝒫f\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Since 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is a complete polyhedral complex, for every σ∈𝒫n−1𝜎superscript𝒫𝑛1\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, there are P,Q∈𝒫n𝑃𝑄superscript𝒫𝑛P,Q\in\mathcal{P}^{n}italic_P , italic_Q ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that σ=P∩Q𝜎𝑃𝑄\sigma=P\cap Qitalic_σ = italic_P ∩ italic_Q. Let aP,aQ∈ℝnsubscript𝑎𝑃subscript𝑎𝑄superscriptℝ𝑛a_{P},a_{Q}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and bP,bQ∈ℝsubscript𝑏𝑃subscript𝑏𝑄ℝb_{P},b_{Q}\in\mathbb{R}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R such that f|P⁢(x)=⟨aP,x⟩+bPevaluated-at𝑓𝑃𝑥subscript𝑎𝑃𝑥subscript𝑏𝑃f|_{P}(x)=\langle a_{P},x\rangle+b_{P}italic_f | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = ⟨ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x ⟩ + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and f|Q⁢(x)=⟨aQ,x⟩+bQevaluated-at𝑓𝑄𝑥subscript𝑎𝑄𝑥subscript𝑏𝑄f|_{Q}(x)=\langle a_{Q},x\rangle+b_{Q}italic_f | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = ⟨ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x ⟩ + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Consider the linear map ϕ:𝒱𝒫→𝒲𝒫:italic-ϕ→subscript𝒱𝒫subscript𝒲𝒫\phi\colon\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}\to\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_ϕ : caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT given by

wf⁢(σ)≔⟨eP/σ,aP⟩+⟨eQ/σ,aQ⟩=⟨eP/σ,aP−aQ⟩.≔subscript𝑤𝑓𝜎subscript𝑒𝑃𝜎subscript𝑎𝑃subscript𝑒𝑄𝜎subscript𝑎𝑄subscript𝑒𝑃𝜎subscript𝑎𝑃subscript𝑎𝑄w_{f}(\sigma)\coloneqq\langle e_{P/\sigma},a_{P}\rangle+\langle e_{Q/\sigma},a% _{Q}\rangle=\langle e_{P/\sigma},a_{P}-a_{Q}\rangle.italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ ) ≔ ⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ + ⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ = ⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ .

Note that if f𝑓fitalic_f is locally convex at σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ, then ⟨eP/σ,aP−aQ⟩=‖aP−aQ‖2subscript𝑒𝑃𝜎subscript𝑎𝑃subscript𝑎𝑄subscriptnormsubscript𝑎𝑃subscript𝑎𝑄2\langle e_{P/\sigma},a_{P}-a_{Q}\rangle=\|a_{P}-a_{Q}\|_{2}⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ = ∥ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and if f𝑓fitalic_f is locally concave at σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ, then ⟨eP/σ,aP−aQ⟩=−‖aP−aQ‖2subscript𝑒𝑃𝜎subscript𝑎𝑃subscript𝑎𝑄subscriptnormsubscript𝑎𝑃subscript𝑎𝑄2\langle e_{P/\sigma},a_{P}-a_{Q}\rangle=-\|a_{P}-a_{Q}\|_{2}⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ = - ∥ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The proof proceeds analogously to the case where f𝑓fitalic_f has only convex breakpoints and the coefficients of the affine maps are rational. In this case, the lemma follows from the structure theorem of tropical geometry. See Maclagan & Sturmfels (2015) Proposition 3.3.2 for a proof that wf∈𝒲𝒫subscript𝑤𝑓subscript𝒲𝒫w_{f}\in\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Maclagan & Sturmfels (2015) Proposition 3.3.10 for a proof that ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ is surjective. Here, we present an adjusted proof (to not necessarily convex functions and irrational coefficients). First, we check that wf∈𝒲𝒫subscript𝑤𝑓subscript𝒲𝒫w_{f}\in\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let τ∈𝒫n−2𝜏superscript𝒫𝑛2\tau\in\mathcal{P}^{n-2}italic_τ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and {P1,…,Pm}=star𝒫⁡(τ)∩𝒫nsubscript𝑃1…subscript𝑃𝑚subscriptstar𝒫𝜏superscript𝒫𝑛\{P_{1},\ldots,P_{m}\}=\operatorname{star}_{\mathcal{P}}(\tau)\cap\mathcal{P}^% {n}{ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } = roman_star start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_τ ) ∩ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and {σ1,…,σm}=star𝒫⁡(τ)∩𝒫n−1subscript𝜎1…subscript𝜎𝑚subscriptstar𝒫𝜏superscript𝒫𝑛1\{\sigma_{1},\ldots,\sigma_{m}\}=\operatorname{star}_{\mathcal{P}}(\tau)\cap% \mathcal{P}^{n-1}{ italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } = roman_star start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_τ ) ∩ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be ordered in a cyclic way, that is, Pi∩Pi+1=σisubscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖1subscript𝜎𝑖P_{i}\cap P_{i+1}=\sigma_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m]italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ], where Pm+1=P1subscript𝑃𝑚1subscript𝑃1P_{m+1}=P_{1}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that, since f𝑓fitalic_f is continuous, we have that aPi−aPi+1∈span⁡(ePi/σi)subscript𝑎subscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝑎subscript𝑃𝑖1spansubscript𝑒subscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖a_{P_{i}}-a_{P_{i+1}}\in\operatorname{span}(e_{P_{i}/\sigma_{i}})italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ roman_span ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). The linear map Tτ:aff(τ)⟂→aff(τ)⟂T_{\tau}\colon\operatorname{aff}(\tau)^{\perp}\to\operatorname{aff}(\tau)^{\perp}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : roman_aff ( italic_τ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟂ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → roman_aff ( italic_τ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟂ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfying Tτ⁢(ePi/σi)=eσi/τsubscript𝑇𝜏subscript𝑒subscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖subscript𝑒subscript𝜎𝑖𝜏T_{\tau}(e_{P_{i}/\sigma_{i}})=e_{\sigma_{i}/\tau}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (given by a rotation matrix) is an automorphism, implying that

∑σ⊃τσ∈𝒫n−1wf⁢(σ)⋅eσ/τsubscript𝜏𝜎𝜎superscript𝒫𝑛1⋅subscript𝑤𝑓𝜎subscript𝑒𝜎𝜏\displaystyle\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}\sigma\supset\tau\\ \sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}\end{subarray}}w_{f}(\sigma)\cdot e_{\sigma/\tau}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_σ ⊃ italic_τ end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ ) ⋅ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ / italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =∑i=1mwf⁢(σi)⋅Tτ⁢(ePi/σi)absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚⋅subscript𝑤𝑓subscript𝜎𝑖subscript𝑇𝜏subscript𝑒subscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖\displaystyle=\sum_{i=1}^{m}w_{f}(\sigma_{i})\cdot T_{\tau}(e_{P_{i}/\sigma_{i% }})= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⋅ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
=Tτ⁢(∑i=1m⟨ePi/σi,aPi−aPi+1⟩⋅ePi/σi)absentsubscript𝑇𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚⋅subscript𝑒subscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖subscript𝑎subscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝑎subscript𝑃𝑖1subscript𝑒subscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖\displaystyle=T_{\tau}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{m}\langle e_{P_{i}/\sigma_{i}},a_{P_{i% }}-{a_{P_{i+1}}}\rangle\cdot e_{P_{i}/\sigma_{i}}\right)= italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ ⋅ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
=Tτ⁢(∑i=1m⟨ePi/σi,ePi/σi⟩⋅(aPi−aPi+1))absentsubscript𝑇𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚⋅subscript𝑒subscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖subscript𝑒subscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖subscript𝑎subscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝑎subscript𝑃𝑖1\displaystyle=T_{\tau}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{m}\langle e_{P_{i}/\sigma_{i}},e_{P_{i% }/\sigma_{i}}\rangle\cdot(a_{P_{i}}-{a_{P_{i+1}}})\right)= italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ ⋅ ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) )
=Tτ⁢(0)=0absentsubscript𝑇𝜏00\displaystyle=T_{\tau}(0)=0= italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) = 0

We proceed by showing that the map ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ is surjective and its kernel is precisely Aff⁡(ℝn)Affsuperscriptℝ𝑛\operatorname{Aff}(\mathbb{R}^{n})roman_Aff ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and therefore, it induces an isomorphism between 𝒱¯𝒫subscript¯𝒱𝒫\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝒲𝒫subscript𝒲𝒫\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The kernel of ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ is Aff⁡(ℝn)Affsuperscriptℝ𝑛\operatorname{Aff}(\mathbb{R}^{n})roman_Aff ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) since wf⁢(σ)=⟨eP/σ,aP⟩+⟨eQ/σ,aQ⟩=⟨eP/σ,aP−aQ⟩=0subscript𝑤𝑓𝜎subscript𝑒𝑃𝜎subscript𝑎𝑃subscript𝑒𝑄𝜎subscript𝑎𝑄subscript𝑒𝑃𝜎subscript𝑎𝑃subscript𝑎𝑄0w_{f}(\sigma)=\langle e_{P/\sigma},a_{P}\rangle+\langle e_{Q/\sigma},a_{Q}% \rangle=\langle e_{P/\sigma},a_{P}-a_{Q}\rangle=0italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ ) = ⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ + ⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ = ⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ = 0 if and only if aP−aQ=0subscript𝑎𝑃subscript𝑎𝑄0a_{P}-a_{Q}=0italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 due to the fact that aP−aQ∈span⁡(eP/σ)subscript𝑎𝑃subscript𝑎𝑄spansubscript𝑒𝑃𝜎a_{P}-a_{Q}\in\operatorname{span}(e_{P/\sigma})italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ roman_span ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Due to the continuity of f𝑓fitalic_f, this also implies that bP=bQsubscript𝑏𝑃subscript𝑏𝑄b_{P}=b_{Q}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and hence f|Q=f|Pevaluated-at𝑓𝑄evaluated-at𝑓𝑃f|_{Q}=f|_{P}italic_f | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and therefore the map f𝑓fitalic_f is affine linear.

To show surjectivity, let w∈𝒲𝒫𝑤subscript𝒲𝒫w\in\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_w ∈ caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We aim to find an f∈𝒱𝒫𝑓subscript𝒱𝒫f\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that w=ϕ⁢(f)𝑤italic-ϕ𝑓w=\phi(f)italic_w = italic_ϕ ( italic_f ). Let 𝒫n={P1,…⁢Pk}superscript𝒫𝑛subscript𝑃1…subscript𝑃𝑘\mathcal{P}^{n}=\{P_{1},\ldots P_{k}\}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and for P∈𝒫n,σ∈𝒫n−1formulae-sequence𝑃superscript𝒫𝑛𝜎superscript𝒫𝑛1P\in\mathcal{P}^{n},\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}italic_P ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, let bP/σ∈ℝsubscript𝑏𝑃𝜎ℝb_{P/\sigma}\in\mathbb{R}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R such that σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ is contained in the hyperplane {x∈ℝn∣⟨eP/σ,x⟩+bP/σ=0}conditional-set𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛subscript𝑒𝑃𝜎𝑥subscript𝑏𝑃𝜎0\{x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\mid\langle e_{P/\sigma},x\rangle+b_{P/\sigma}=0\}{ italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ ⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x ⟩ + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 } and define the function fP/σ:ℝn→ℝ:subscript𝑓𝑃𝜎→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝf_{P/\sigma}\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R by fP/σ⁢(x)=⟨eP/σ,x⟩+bP/σsubscript𝑓𝑃𝜎𝑥subscript𝑒𝑃𝜎𝑥subscript𝑏𝑃𝜎f_{P/\sigma}(x)=\langle e_{P/\sigma},x\rangle+b_{P/\sigma}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = ⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x ⟩ + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Since 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is complete, the graph G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E ) given by V={1,…,k}𝑉1…𝑘V=\{1,\ldots,k\}italic_V = { 1 , … , italic_k } and E={{i,j}∣Pj∩Pi∈𝒫n−1}𝐸conditional-set𝑖𝑗subscript𝑃𝑗subscript𝑃𝑖superscript𝒫𝑛1E=\{\{i,j\}\mid P_{j}\cap P_{i}\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}\}italic_E = { { italic_i , italic_j } ∣ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } is connected. Start by defining the function f|P1=0evaluated-at𝑓subscript𝑃10f|_{P_{1}}=0italic_f | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0. For 1<i≤k1𝑖𝑘1<i\leq k1 < italic_i ≤ italic_k, let (j1,…⁢jm)subscript𝑗1…subscript𝑗𝑚(j_{1},\ldots j_{m})( italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) be a path from 1111 to i𝑖iitalic_i and for ℓ∈[m−1]ℓdelimited-[]𝑚1\ell\in[m-1]roman_ℓ ∈ [ italic_m - 1 ], let σℓ=Pjℓ∩Pjℓ+1subscript𝜎ℓsubscript𝑃subscript𝑗ℓsubscript𝑃subscript𝑗ℓ1\sigma_{\ell}=P_{j_{\ell}}\cap P_{j_{\ell+1}}italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and define the function

f|Pi=∑ℓ=1m−1w⁢(σℓ)⋅fPjℓ/σℓ.evaluated-at𝑓subscript𝑃𝑖superscriptsubscriptℓ1𝑚1⋅𝑤subscript𝜎ℓsubscript𝑓subscript𝑃subscript𝑗ℓsubscript𝜎ℓf|_{P_{i}}=\sum_{\ell=1}^{m-1}w(\sigma_{\ell})\cdot f_{P_{j_{\ell}}/\sigma_{% \ell}}.italic_f | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w ( italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⋅ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

First, we argue that f|Pievaluated-at𝑓subscript𝑃𝑖f|_{P_{i}}italic_f | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is well-defined, that is, the definition of f|Pievaluated-at𝑓subscript𝑃𝑖f|_{P_{i}}italic_f | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT does not depend on the path from vertex 1111 to i𝑖iitalic_i. Equivalently, it suffices to show that for any cycle (i1,…,im)subscript𝑖1…subscript𝑖𝑚(i_{1},\ldots,i_{m})( italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in G𝐺Gitalic_G with i1=imsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑖𝑚i_{1}=i_{m}italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, it holds that ∑ℓ=1m−1w⁢(σℓ)⁢fPiℓ/σℓ=0superscriptsubscriptℓ1𝑚1𝑤subscript𝜎ℓsubscript𝑓subscript𝑃subscript𝑖ℓsubscript𝜎ℓ0\sum_{\ell=1}^{m-1}w(\sigma_{\ell})f_{{P_{i_{\ell}}/\sigma_{\ell}}}=0∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w ( italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, where σℓ=Piℓ∩Piℓ+1subscript𝜎ℓsubscript𝑃subscript𝑖ℓsubscript𝑃subscript𝑖ℓ1\sigma_{\ell}=P_{i_{\ell}}\cap P_{i_{\ell+1}}italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Since 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is complete any cycle decomposes into cycles (i1,…,im)subscript𝑖1…subscript𝑖𝑚(i_{1},\ldots,i_{m})( italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) corresponding to the star of a cone τ∈𝒫n−2𝜏superscript𝒫𝑛2\tau\in\mathcal{P}^{n-2}italic_τ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, that is, {σ1,…,σm−1}={σ∈𝒫n−1∣σ⊃τ}subscript𝜎1…subscript𝜎𝑚1conditional-set𝜎superscript𝒫𝑛1𝜏𝜎\{\sigma_{1},\ldots,\sigma_{m-1}\}=\{\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}\mid\sigma% \supset\tau\}{ italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } = { italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ italic_σ ⊃ italic_τ }. Since Tτsubscript𝑇𝜏T_{\tau}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an automorphism, it holds that ∑ℓ=1m−1w⁢(σℓ)⋅eσℓ/τ=0superscriptsubscriptℓ1𝑚1⋅𝑤subscript𝜎ℓsubscript𝑒subscript𝜎ℓ𝜏0\sum_{\ell=1}^{m-1}w(\sigma_{\ell})\cdot e_{\sigma_{\ell}/\tau}=0∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w ( italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⋅ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 if and only if ∑ℓ=1m−1w⁢(σℓ)⋅ePiℓ/σℓ=0superscriptsubscriptℓ1𝑚1⋅𝑤subscript𝜎ℓsubscript𝑒subscript𝑃subscript𝑖ℓsubscript𝜎ℓ0\sum_{\ell=1}^{m-1}w(\sigma_{\ell})\cdot e_{P_{i_{\ell}}/\sigma_{\ell}}=0∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w ( italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⋅ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0

So, let x∈ℝn𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be arbitrary and x′∈aff⁡(τ)superscript𝑥′aff𝜏x^{\prime}\in\operatorname{aff}(\tau)italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ roman_aff ( italic_τ ) and x′′∈aff(τ)⟂x^{\prime\prime}\in\operatorname{aff}(\tau)^{\perp}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ roman_aff ( italic_τ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟂ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that x=x′+x′′𝑥superscript𝑥′superscript𝑥′′x=x^{\prime}+x^{\prime\prime}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Since w𝑤witalic_w is in 𝒲𝒫subscript𝒲𝒫\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, it holds that ∑σ⊃τσ∈𝒫n−1w⁢(σ)⋅eσ/τ=0subscript𝜏𝜎𝜎superscript𝒫𝑛1⋅𝑤𝜎subscript𝑒𝜎𝜏0\sum\limits_{\begin{subarray}{c}\sigma\supset\tau\\ \sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}\end{subarray}}w(\sigma)\cdot e_{\sigma/\tau}=0∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_σ ⊃ italic_τ end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w ( italic_σ ) ⋅ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ / italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 and hence it follows that

∑ℓ=1m−1w⁢(σℓ)⁢fPiℓ/σℓ⁢(x)superscriptsubscriptℓ1𝑚1𝑤subscript𝜎ℓsubscript𝑓subscript𝑃subscript𝑖ℓsubscript𝜎ℓ𝑥\displaystyle\sum_{\ell=1}^{m-1}w(\sigma_{\ell})f_{{P_{i_{\ell}}/\sigma_{\ell}% }}(x)∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w ( italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) =∑ℓ=1m−1w⁢(σℓ)⋅⟨ePiℓ/σℓ,x′+x′′⟩+bPiℓ/σℓabsentsuperscriptsubscriptℓ1𝑚1⋅𝑤subscript𝜎ℓsubscript𝑒subscript𝑃subscript𝑖ℓsubscript𝜎ℓsuperscript𝑥′superscript𝑥′′subscript𝑏subscript𝑃subscript𝑖ℓsubscript𝜎ℓ\displaystyle=\sum_{\ell=1}^{m-1}w(\sigma_{\ell})\cdot\langle e_{P_{i_{\ell}}/% \sigma_{\ell}},x^{\prime}+x^{\prime\prime}\rangle+b_{P_{i_{\ell}}/\sigma_{\ell}}= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w ( italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⋅ ⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟩ + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
=∑ℓ=1m−1w⁢(σℓ)⋅⟨ePiℓ/σℓ,x′′⟩absentsuperscriptsubscriptℓ1𝑚1⋅𝑤subscript𝜎ℓsubscript𝑒subscript𝑃subscript𝑖ℓsubscript𝜎ℓsuperscript𝑥′′\displaystyle=\sum_{\ell=1}^{m-1}w(\sigma_{\ell})\cdot\langle e_{P_{i_{\ell}}/% \sigma_{\ell}},x^{\prime\prime}\rangle= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w ( italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⋅ ⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟩
=⟨∑ℓ=1m−1w⁢(σℓ)⋅ePiℓ/σℓ,x′′⟩absentdelimited-⟨⟩superscriptsubscriptℓ1𝑚1⋅𝑤subscript𝜎ℓsubscript𝑒subscript𝑃subscript𝑖ℓsubscript𝜎ℓsuperscript𝑥′′\displaystyle=\langle\sum_{\ell=1}^{m-1}w(\sigma_{\ell})\cdot e_{P_{i_{\ell}}/% \sigma_{\ell},x^{\prime\prime}}\rangle= ⟨ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w ( italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⋅ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩
=0absent0\displaystyle=0= 0

By definition, f𝑓fitalic_f is a CPWL function and compatible with 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P and hence in 𝒱𝒫subscript𝒱𝒫\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To see that w=ϕ⁢(f)𝑤italic-ϕ𝑓w=\phi(f)italic_w = italic_ϕ ( italic_f ), let P,Q∈𝒫n𝑃𝑄superscript𝒫𝑛P,Q\in\mathcal{P}^{n}italic_P , italic_Q ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that σ=P∩Q∈𝒫n−1𝜎𝑃𝑄superscript𝒫𝑛1\sigma=P\cap Q\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}italic_σ = italic_P ∩ italic_Q ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then it holds that aP−aQ=w⁢(σ)⋅eP/σsubscript𝑎𝑃subscript𝑎𝑄⋅𝑤𝜎subscript𝑒𝑃𝜎a_{P}-a_{Q}=w(\sigma)\cdot e_{P/\sigma}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_w ( italic_σ ) ⋅ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and hence

wf⁢(σ)=⟨eP/σ,aP⟩+⟨eQ/σ,aQ⟩=⟨eP/σ,aP−aQ⟩=⟨eP/σ,w⁢(σ)⋅eP/σ⟩=w⁢(σ),subscript𝑤𝑓𝜎subscript𝑒𝑃𝜎subscript𝑎𝑃subscript𝑒𝑄𝜎subscript𝑎𝑄subscript𝑒𝑃𝜎subscript𝑎𝑃subscript𝑎𝑄subscript𝑒𝑃𝜎⋅𝑤𝜎subscript𝑒𝑃𝜎𝑤𝜎w_{f}(\sigma)=\langle e_{P/\sigma},a_{P}\rangle+\langle e_{Q/\sigma},a_{Q}% \rangle=\langle e_{P/\sigma},a_{P}-a_{Q}\rangle=\langle e_{P/\sigma},w(\sigma)% \cdot e_{P/\sigma}\rangle=w(\sigma),italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ ) = ⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ + ⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ = ⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ = ⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_w ( italic_σ ) ⋅ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ = italic_w ( italic_σ ) ,

finishing the proof. ∎

E.3 Corollary E.1

Corollary E.1.

𝒱𝒫subscript𝒱𝒫\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is finite-dimensional.

Proof.

By Lemma 3.2, we have that 𝒱¯𝒫=𝒱𝒫/Aff⁡(ℝn)≅𝒲𝒫subscript¯𝒱𝒫subscript𝒱𝒫Affsuperscriptℝ𝑛subscript𝒲𝒫\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}=\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}/\operatorname{% Aff}(\mathbb{R}^{n})\cong\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / roman_Aff ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≅ caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Thus, the dimension of 𝒱𝒫subscript𝒱𝒫\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is bounded from above by dim(𝒲𝒫)+dim(Aff⁡(ℝn))≤|𝒫n−1|+(n+1)dimensionsubscript𝒲𝒫dimensionAffsuperscriptℝ𝑛superscript𝒫𝑛1𝑛1\dim(\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}})+\dim(\operatorname{Aff}(\mathbb{R}^{n}))\leq% \lvert\mathcal{P}^{n-1}\rvert+(n+1)roman_dim ( caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + roman_dim ( roman_Aff ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ≤ | caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | + ( italic_n + 1 ). ∎

E.4 Proof of Proposition 3.3

Proof.

The function f𝑓fitalic_f is convex if and only if it is locally convex around any σ∈𝒫n−1𝜎superscript𝒫𝑛1\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, that is, f𝑓fitalic_f is locally convex around every x𝑥xitalic_x in the relative interior of σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ. For any such x𝑥xitalic_x, there is a λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0italic_λ > 0 such that x+λ⋅eP/σ∈P𝑥⋅𝜆subscript𝑒𝑃𝜎𝑃x+\lambda\cdot e_{P/\sigma}\in Pitalic_x + italic_λ ⋅ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_P and x+λ⋅eQ/σ∈Q𝑥⋅𝜆subscript𝑒𝑄𝜎𝑄x+\lambda\cdot e_{Q/\sigma}\in Qitalic_x + italic_λ ⋅ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_Q, by construction of eP/σsubscript𝑒𝑃𝜎e_{P/\sigma}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and eQ/σsubscript𝑒𝑄𝜎e_{Q/\sigma}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Recall from the proof of Lemma 3.2 that wf⁢(σ)=⟨eP/σ,aP⟩+⟨eQ/σ,aQ⟩subscript𝑤𝑓𝜎subscript𝑒𝑃𝜎subscript𝑎𝑃subscript𝑒𝑄𝜎subscript𝑎𝑄w_{f}(\sigma)=\langle e_{P/\sigma},a_{P}\rangle+\langle e_{Q/\sigma},a_{Q}\rangleitalic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ ) = ⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ + ⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩, where f|P⁢(x)=⟨aP,x⟩+bPevaluated-at𝑓𝑃𝑥subscript𝑎𝑃𝑥subscript𝑏𝑃f|_{P}(x)=\langle a_{P},x\rangle+b_{P}italic_f | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = ⟨ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x ⟩ + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and f|Q⁢(x)=⟨aQ,x⟩+bQevaluated-at𝑓𝑄𝑥subscript𝑎𝑄𝑥subscript𝑏𝑄f|_{Q}(x)=\langle a_{Q},x\rangle+b_{Q}italic_f | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = ⟨ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x ⟩ + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Since P,Q∈𝒫n𝑃𝑄superscript𝒫𝑛P,Q\in\mathcal{P}^{n}italic_P , italic_Q ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ‖eP/σ‖=‖eQ/σ‖=1normsubscript𝑒𝑃𝜎normsubscript𝑒𝑄𝜎1\|e_{P/\sigma}\|=\|e_{Q/\sigma}\|=1∥ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ = ∥ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ = 1, we have that x𝑥xitalic_x is the midpoint of x+λ⋅eP/σ𝑥⋅𝜆subscript𝑒𝑃𝜎x+\lambda\cdot e_{P/\sigma}italic_x + italic_λ ⋅ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and x+λ⋅eQ/σ𝑥⋅𝜆subscript𝑒𝑄𝜎x+\lambda\cdot e_{Q/\sigma}italic_x + italic_λ ⋅ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, f𝑓fitalic_f is convex if and only if f⁢(x)≤12⁢f⁢(x+λ⋅eP/σ)+12⁢f⁢(x+λ⋅eQ/σ)𝑓𝑥12𝑓𝑥⋅𝜆subscript𝑒𝑃𝜎12𝑓𝑥⋅𝜆subscript𝑒𝑄𝜎f(x)\leq\frac{1}{2}f(x+\lambda\cdot e_{P/\sigma})+\frac{1}{2}f(x+\lambda\cdot e% _{Q/\sigma})italic_f ( italic_x ) ≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_f ( italic_x + italic_λ ⋅ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_f ( italic_x + italic_λ ⋅ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Equivalently,

0≤f⁢(x+λ⋅eP/σ)+f⁢(x+λ⋅eQ/σ)−2⁢f⁢(x)=λ⁢(⟨eP/σ,aP⟩+⟨eQ/σ,aQ⟩)=λ⋅wf⁢(σ).0𝑓𝑥⋅𝜆subscript𝑒𝑃𝜎𝑓𝑥⋅𝜆subscript𝑒𝑄𝜎2𝑓𝑥𝜆subscript𝑒𝑃𝜎subscript𝑎𝑃subscript𝑒𝑄𝜎subscript𝑎𝑄⋅𝜆subscript𝑤𝑓𝜎0\leq f(x+\lambda\cdot e_{P/\sigma})+f(x+\lambda\cdot e_{Q/\sigma})-2f(x)=% \lambda(\langle e_{P/\sigma},a_{P}\rangle+\langle e_{Q/\sigma},a_{Q}\rangle)=% \lambda\cdot w_{f}(\sigma).0 ≤ italic_f ( italic_x + italic_λ ⋅ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_f ( italic_x + italic_λ ⋅ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - 2 italic_f ( italic_x ) = italic_λ ( ⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ + ⟨ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q / italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ ) = italic_λ ⋅ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ ) .

If 𝒫=𝒫f𝒫subscript𝒫𝑓\mathcal{P}=\mathcal{P}_{f}caligraphic_P = caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then we have strict local convexity at every σ∈𝒫n−1𝜎superscript𝒫𝑛1\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which means a strict inequality in the inequality above. ∎

E.5 Lemma E.2

Lemma E.2.

𝒱¯𝒫+superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT forms a polyhedral cone in 𝒱¯𝒫subscript¯𝒱𝒫\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Proof.

Lemma 3.2 and Proposition 3.3 imply that the set of convex functions in 𝒱¯𝒫subscript¯𝒱𝒫\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies 𝒱¯𝒫+≅𝒲𝒫+≔⋂σ∈𝒫n−1{w∈𝒲𝒫∣w⁢(σ)≥0}superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫superscriptsubscript𝒲𝒫≔subscript𝜎superscript𝒫𝑛1conditional-set𝑤subscript𝒲𝒫𝑤𝜎0\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\cong\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}% \coloneqq\bigcap_{\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}}\{w\in\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}% \mid w(\sigma)\geq 0\}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≅ caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≔ ⋂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_w ∈ caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_w ( italic_σ ) ≥ 0 }. This is a finite intersection of linear inequalities, so 𝒲𝒫+superscriptsubscript𝒲𝒫\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a polyhedral cone. Moreover, “≅\cong≅” is a linear isomorphism, which implies that 𝒱¯𝒫+superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a polyhedral cone. ∎

E.6 Lemma E.3

Lemma E.3.

Let 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P be a regular polyhredral complex. Then every CPWL function compatible with 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P can be written as a difference of two convex CPWL functions that are also compatible with 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. In particular, 𝒱¯𝒫=span⁡(𝒱¯𝒫+)subscript¯𝒱𝒫spansuperscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}=\operatorname{span}(\overline{\mathcal{V}% }_{\mathcal{P}}^{+})over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_span ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

Proof.

Let f∈𝒱𝒫𝑓subscript𝒱𝒫f\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be an arbirtary function. Since 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is regular, by definition there exists a convex function g∈𝒱𝒫𝑔subscript𝒱𝒫g\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_g ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that 𝒫=𝒫g𝒫subscript𝒫𝑔\mathcal{P}=\mathcal{P}_{g}caligraphic_P = caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Proposition 3.3 implies that wg⁢(σ)>0subscript𝑤𝑔𝜎0w_{g}(\sigma)>0italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ ) > 0 for all σ∈𝒫n−1𝜎superscript𝒫𝑛1\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For sufficiently large λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0italic_λ > 0, it follows that wf+λ⁢g≥0subscript𝑤𝑓𝜆𝑔0w_{f+\lambda g}\geq 0italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f + italic_λ italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0 and thus f=(f+λ⁢g)−λ⁢g𝑓𝑓𝜆𝑔𝜆𝑔f=(f+\lambda g)-\lambda gitalic_f = ( italic_f + italic_λ italic_g ) - italic_λ italic_g is a representation of f𝑓fitalic_f as a difference of two compatible, convex functions, as desired. ∎

E.7 Proof Theorem 3.5

Proof.

For the set of decompositions holds

𝒟𝒫⁢(f)={(g,h)∣g∈𝒱¯𝒫+,h∈𝒱¯𝒫+,f=g−h}=(𝒱¯𝒫+×𝒱¯𝒫+)∩Hf.subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓conditional-set𝑔ℎformulae-sequence𝑔superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫formulae-sequenceℎsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫𝑓𝑔ℎsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫subscript𝐻𝑓\displaystyle\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)=\{(g,h)\mid g\in\overline{\mathcal{V% }}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+},h\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+},f=g-h\}=(% \overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\times\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal% {P}}^{+})\cap H_{f}.caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) = { ( italic_g , italic_h ) ∣ italic_g ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_f = italic_g - italic_h } = ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT × over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∩ italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

For the projection we have

π⁢(𝒟𝒫⁢(f))=π⁢({(g,g−f)∣g∈𝒱¯𝒫+,g−f∈𝒱¯𝒫+})={g∣g∈𝒱¯𝒫+,g∈f+𝒱¯𝒫+}=𝒱¯𝒫+∩(f+𝒱¯𝒫+).𝜋subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓𝜋conditional-set𝑔𝑔𝑓formulae-sequence𝑔superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫𝑔𝑓superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫conditional-set𝑔formulae-sequence𝑔superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫𝑔𝑓superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫𝑓superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫\displaystyle\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))=\pi(\{(g,g-f)\mid g\in\overline% {\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+},g-f\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}% \})=\{g\mid g\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+},g\in f+\overline{% \mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\}=\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\cap(% f+\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}).italic_π ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) = italic_π ( { ( italic_g , italic_g - italic_f ) ∣ italic_g ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_g - italic_f ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) = { italic_g ∣ italic_g ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_g ∈ italic_f + over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } = over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∩ ( italic_f + over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

∎

E.8 Proof of Theorem 3.8

The statement follows from a more general statement about polyhedra. Recall that any polyhedron P𝑃Pitalic_P can written as the Minkowski sum

P=Q+C={q+c∣q∈Q,c∈C}𝑃𝑄𝐶conditional-set𝑞𝑐formulae-sequence𝑞𝑄𝑐𝐶P=Q+C=\{q+c\mid q\in Q,c\in C\}italic_P = italic_Q + italic_C = { italic_q + italic_c ∣ italic_q ∈ italic_Q , italic_c ∈ italic_C }

where Q𝑄Qitalic_Q is a bounded polytope, and C𝐶Citalic_C a unique polyhedral cone, the recession cone of P𝑃Pitalic_P.

Proposition E.4.

A point x∈P𝑥𝑃x\in Pitalic_x ∈ italic_P is contained in a bounded face of P𝑃Pitalic_P if and only if x−c∉P⁢∀c∈C∖{0}𝑥𝑐𝑃for-all𝑐𝐶0x-c\not\in P\ \forall c\in C\setminus\{0\}italic_x - italic_c ∉ italic_P ∀ italic_c ∈ italic_C ∖ { 0 }.

Proof.

Any face of the polyhedron P𝑃Pitalic_P is of the form

Pu={x∈P∣⟨x,u⟩≥⟨y,u⟩⁢∀y∈P},superscript𝑃𝑢conditional-set𝑥𝑃𝑥𝑢𝑦𝑢for-all𝑦𝑃P^{u}=\{x\in P\mid\langle x,u\rangle\geq\langle y,u\rangle\ \forall y\in P\},italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { italic_x ∈ italic_P ∣ ⟨ italic_x , italic_u ⟩ ≥ ⟨ italic_y , italic_u ⟩ ∀ italic_y ∈ italic_P } ,

and for Minkowski sums holds Pu=Qu+Cusuperscript𝑃𝑢superscript𝑄𝑢superscript𝐶𝑢P^{u}=Q^{u}+C^{u}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let x∈P𝑥𝑃x\in Pitalic_x ∈ italic_P be a point contained in a bounded face Pusuperscript𝑃𝑢P^{u}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of P𝑃Pitalic_P. Since Pusuperscript𝑃𝑢P^{u}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is bounded, we have that Pu=Qu+Cusuperscript𝑃𝑢superscript𝑄𝑢superscript𝐶𝑢P^{u}=Q^{u}+C^{u}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with Cu={0}superscript𝐶𝑢0C^{u}=\{0\}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { 0 } being the unique bounded face of C𝐶Citalic_C. Thus, ⟨c,u⟩<⟨0,u⟩𝑐𝑢0𝑢\langle c,u\rangle<\langle 0,u\rangle⟨ italic_c , italic_u ⟩ < ⟨ 0 , italic_u ⟩ for all c∈C∖{0}𝑐𝐶0c\in C\setminus\{0\}italic_c ∈ italic_C ∖ { 0 }. This implies that ⟨x−c,u⟩=⟨x,u⟩−⟨c,u⟩>⟨x,u⟩𝑥𝑐𝑢𝑥𝑢𝑐𝑢𝑥𝑢\langle x-c,u\rangle=\langle x,u\rangle-\langle c,u\rangle>\langle x,u\rangle⟨ italic_x - italic_c , italic_u ⟩ = ⟨ italic_x , italic_u ⟩ - ⟨ italic_c , italic_u ⟩ > ⟨ italic_x , italic_u ⟩ and therefore, by definition of Pusuperscript𝑃𝑢P^{u}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have that x−c∉P𝑥𝑐𝑃x-c\not\in Pitalic_x - italic_c ∉ italic_P.

Conversely, suppose that x∈P𝑥𝑃x\in Pitalic_x ∈ italic_P is not contained in a bounded face. We want to show that there exists some direction c∈C∖{0}𝑐𝐶0c\in C\setminus\{0\}italic_c ∈ italic_C ∖ { 0 } such that x−c∈P𝑥𝑐𝑃x-c\in Pitalic_x - italic_c ∈ italic_P. Since x𝑥xitalic_x is not contained in a bounded face, it is contained in the relative interior of an unbounded face F𝐹Fitalic_F (where possibly F=P𝐹𝑃F=Pitalic_F = italic_P). Since the face is unbounded, it contains a ray x+ℝ⁢c𝑥ℝ𝑐x+\mathbb{R}citalic_x + blackboard_R italic_c for some direction c∈C𝑐𝐶c\in Citalic_c ∈ italic_C. On the other hand, since x∈int⁡(F)𝑥int𝐹x\in\operatorname{int}(F)italic_x ∈ roman_int ( italic_F ), we have that x−ε⁢c∈F𝑥𝜀𝑐𝐹x-\varepsilon c\in Fitalic_x - italic_ε italic_c ∈ italic_F for ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0italic_ε > 0 small enough. As C𝐶Citalic_C is a cone, we have that ε⁢c∈C𝜀𝑐𝐶\varepsilon c\in Citalic_ε italic_c ∈ italic_C, which finishes the proof. ∎

Proof of Theorem 3.8.

Since π𝜋\piitalic_π induces a bijection between 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) and its image, this is also a bijection between bounded faces. By Theorem 3.5, π⁢(𝒟𝒫⁢(f))𝜋subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))italic_π ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) is a polyhedron with recession cone 𝒱¯𝒫+superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Proposition E.4 implies that g𝑔gitalic_g is contained in a bounded face if and only if there exists no convex function ϕ∈𝒱¯𝒫+italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫\phi\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}italic_ϕ ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that g−ϕ∈π⁢(𝒟𝒫⁢(f))𝑔italic-ϕ𝜋subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓g-\phi\in\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))italic_g - italic_ϕ ∈ italic_π ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ). Therefore, π−1⁢(g)=(g,h),h=g−fformulae-sequencesuperscript𝜋1𝑔𝑔ℎℎ𝑔𝑓\pi^{-1}(g)=(g,h),h=g-fitalic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_g ) = ( italic_g , italic_h ) , italic_h = italic_g - italic_f is contained in a bounded face of 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) if and only if there is no ϕ∈𝒱¯𝒫+italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫\phi\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}italic_ϕ ∈ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that (g−ϕ,g−f−ϕ)=(g−ϕ,h−ϕ)∉𝒟𝒫⁢(f)𝑔italic-ϕ𝑔𝑓italic-ϕ𝑔italic-ϕℎitalic-ϕsubscript𝒟𝒫𝑓(g-\phi,g-f-\phi)=(g-\phi,h-\phi)\not\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)( italic_g - italic_ϕ , italic_g - italic_f - italic_ϕ ) = ( italic_g - italic_ϕ , italic_h - italic_ϕ ) ∉ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ). Since (g−ϕ)−(h−ϕ)=f𝑔italic-ϕℎitalic-ϕ𝑓(g-\phi)-(h-\phi)=f( italic_g - italic_ϕ ) - ( italic_h - italic_ϕ ) = italic_f, this is equivalent to g−ϕ𝑔italic-ϕg-\phiitalic_g - italic_ϕ or h−ϕℎitalic-ϕh-\phiitalic_h - italic_ϕ being nonconvex, i.e., (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is reduced. ∎

E.9 Proof of Lemma 3.10

Proof.

First note that B⁢(g)≔⋃σ∈supp𝒫⁡(g)σ≔𝐵𝑔subscript𝜎subscriptsupp𝒫𝑔𝜎B(g)\coloneqq\bigcup\limits_{\sigma\in\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(g)}\sigmaitalic_B ( italic_g ) ≔ ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ ∈ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ are exactly the points where g𝑔gitalic_g is not affine linear. Hence, the closures of the connected components of the complement of B⁢(g)𝐵𝑔B(g)italic_B ( italic_g ) are the maximal polyhedra of the unique coarsest polyhedral complex 𝒫gsubscript𝒫𝑔\mathcal{P}_{g}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT compatible with g𝑔gitalic_g.

Let supp𝒫⁡(g′)⊆supp𝒫⁡(g)subscriptsupp𝒫superscript𝑔′subscriptsupp𝒫𝑔\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}({g^{\prime}})\subseteq\operatorname{supp}_{% \mathcal{P}}(g)roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ⊆ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ). Equivalently, for the complement holds (ℝn∖B⁢(g))⊆(ℝn∖B⁢(g′))superscriptℝ𝑛𝐵𝑔superscriptℝ𝑛𝐵superscript𝑔′(\mathbb{R}^{n}\setminus B(g))\subseteq(\mathbb{R}^{n}\setminus B(g^{\prime}))( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∖ italic_B ( italic_g ) ) ⊆ ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∖ italic_B ( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ), and the same holds for the closures of the (open) connected components, i.e., the maximal faces in 𝒫gnsubscriptsuperscript𝒫𝑛𝑔\mathcal{P}^{n}_{g}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝒫g′nsubscriptsuperscript𝒫𝑛superscript𝑔′\mathcal{P}^{n}_{g^{\prime}}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In other words, this is equivalent to that for every face P∈𝒫gn𝑃superscriptsubscript𝒫𝑔𝑛P\in\mathcal{P}_{g}^{n}italic_P ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT there exists some P′∈𝒫g′nsuperscript𝑃′superscriptsubscript𝒫superscript𝑔′𝑛P^{\prime}\in\mathcal{P}_{g^{\prime}}^{n}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that P⊆P′𝑃superscript𝑃′P\subseteq P^{\prime}italic_P ⊆ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Thus, supp𝒫⁡(g′)⊆supp𝒫⁡(g)subscriptsupp𝒫superscript𝑔′subscriptsupp𝒫𝑔\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}({g^{\prime}})\subseteq\operatorname{supp}_{% \mathcal{P}}(g)roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ⊆ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ) if and only if 𝒫g′subscript𝒫superscript𝑔′\mathcal{P}_{g^{\prime}}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a coarsening of 𝒫gsubscript𝒫𝑔\mathcal{P}_{g}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The coarsening is non-trivial if and only if there is a P′∈𝒫g′nsuperscript𝑃′superscriptsubscript𝒫superscript𝑔′𝑛P^{\prime}\in\mathcal{P}_{g^{\prime}}^{n}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that there is no P∈𝒫gn𝑃superscriptsubscript𝒫𝑔𝑛P\in\mathcal{P}_{g}^{n}italic_P ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with P′⊆Psuperscript𝑃′𝑃P^{\prime}\subseteq Pitalic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊆ italic_P. This is the case if and only if there is a σ∈𝒫gn−1𝜎superscriptsubscript𝒫𝑔𝑛1\sigma\in\mathcal{P}_{g}^{n-1}italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that intersects the interior of P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which occurs if and only if σ∈supp𝒫⁡(g)∖supp𝒫⁡(g′)𝜎subscriptsupp𝒫𝑔subscriptsupp𝒫superscript𝑔′\sigma\in\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(g)\setminus\operatorname{supp}_{% \mathcal{P}}(g^{\prime})italic_σ ∈ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ) ∖ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). ∎

E.10 Proof of Theorem 3.11

We first prove the following proposition that relates coarsenings of the decompositions to inclusion relations of the minimal faces that contain the decompositions.

Proposition E.5.

For (g,h)∈𝒟𝒫⁢(f)𝑔ℎsubscript𝒟𝒫𝑓(g,h)\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)( italic_g , italic_h ) ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ), let F𝐹Fitalic_F be the minimal face of 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) containing (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ).
