Then (g′,h′)superscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is a coarsening of (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) if and only if there is a face G𝐺Gitalic_G of 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) with G⊆F𝐺𝐹G\subseteq Fitalic_G ⊆ italic_F such that (g′,h′)∈Gsuperscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′𝐺(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})\in G( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ italic_G. The coarsening is non-trivial if and only if F≠G𝐹𝐺F\neq Gitalic_F ≠ italic_G.

Proof.

For a face F𝐹Fitalic_F, let 𝒢F={σ∈𝒫n−1∣wg(σ)=0\mathcal{G}_{F}=\{\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}\mid w_{g}(\sigma)=0caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ ) = 0 for all (wg,wh)∈F}(w_{g},w_{h})\in F\}( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ italic_F } and ℋF={σ∈𝒫fn−1∣wh(σ)=0\mathcal{H}_{F}=\{\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}_{f}\mid w_{h}(\sigma)=0caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ ) = 0 for all (wg,wh)∈F}(w_{g},w_{h})\in F\}( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ italic_F } be the set of facets where the corresponding inequalities ensuring convexity of the functions g𝑔gitalic_g and hℎhitalic_h are tight. It is not hard to see that G⊆F𝐺𝐹G\subseteq Fitalic_G ⊆ italic_F if and only if 𝒢F⊆𝒢Gsubscript𝒢𝐹subscript𝒢𝐺\mathcal{G}_{F}\subseteq\mathcal{G}_{G}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ℋF⊆ℋGsubscriptℋ𝐹subscriptℋ𝐺\mathcal{H}_{F}\subseteq\mathcal{H}_{G}caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In other words, if (g′,h′)superscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is contained in a face G⊆F𝐺𝐹G\subseteq Fitalic_G ⊆ italic_F, then one can move from (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) to (g′,h′)superscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) without losing tight inequalities. Hence, Lemma 3.10 implies that (g′,h′)superscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is a coarsening of (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ). If G⊂F𝐺𝐹G\subset Fitalic_G ⊂ italic_F, then either 𝒢F⊂𝒢Gsubscript𝒢𝐹subscript𝒢𝐺\mathcal{G}_{F}\subset\mathcal{G}_{G}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊂ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or ℋF⊂ℋGsubscriptℋ𝐹subscriptℋ𝐺\mathcal{H}_{F}\subset\mathcal{H}_{G}caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊂ caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Thus, another inequality becomes tight when moving from (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) to (g′,h′)superscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) implying that the coarsening is non-trivial.

For the converse direction, let (g′,h′)superscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) be a coarsening of (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ), which in particular means that g′superscript𝑔′g^{\prime}italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and h′superscriptℎ′h^{\prime}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are compatible with 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. Hence, f=g′−h′𝑓superscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′f=g^{\prime}-h^{\prime}italic_f = italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT implies that (g′,h′)∈𝒟𝒫⁢(f)superscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ). Now, assume that there is no face G⊆F𝐺𝐹G\subseteq Fitalic_G ⊆ italic_F such that (g′,h′)∈Gsuperscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′𝐺(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})\in G( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ italic_G. Then the line between (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) and (g′,h′)superscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is not contained in F𝐹Fitalic_F. Thus, a tight inequality gets lost when moving from (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) towards (g′,h′)superscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Hence, without loss of generality, there is a σ∈supp𝒫⁡(g′)∖supp𝒫⁡(g)𝜎subscriptsupp𝒫superscript𝑔′subscriptsupp𝒫𝑔\sigma\in\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(g^{\prime})\setminus\operatorname{% supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(g)italic_σ ∈ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∖ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ), which according to Lemma 3.10 is a contradiction to (g′,h′)superscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) being a coarsening of (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ). ∎

Proof of Theorem 3.11.

1 and 2 are equivalent by Proposition E.5. 3 trivially implies 2. Hence, it remains to show 1 ⟹\implies⟹ 3. Assume that there is a polyhedral complex 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q compatible with g𝑔gitalic_g and hℎhitalic_h such that (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is not a vertex of 𝒟𝒬⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒬𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{Q}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ). Then there is vertex (g′,h′)superscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) of 𝒟𝒬⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒬𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{Q}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) contained in the face containing (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ). By Proposition E.5, it follows that (g′,h′)superscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is a non-trivial coarsening of (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ). ∎

E.11 Proof of Theorem 3.13

Proof.

If (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is not not a vertex, the by Theorem 3.11, there is a coarsening (g′,h′)superscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) of (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ). Thus, (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is dominated by (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) and therefore not minimal. ∎

E.12 Proof of Proposition 3.14

Proof.

As 𝒟𝒫⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) is nonempty, there must exist a minimal decomposition. By Theorem 3.13, every minimal decomposition must be a vertex. As there is only one vertex, it must coincide with the unique minimal decomposition. ∎

E.13 Lemma E.6

Lemma E.6.

Let C⊂ℝd𝐶superscriptℝ𝑑C\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_C ⊂ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a convex, pointed polyhedral cone. If C𝐶Citalic_C is simplicial then C∩(C+t)𝐶𝐶𝑡C\cap(C+t)italic_C ∩ ( italic_C + italic_t ) is a (potentially shifted) cone, i.e. a polyhedron with a single vertex, for any translation t𝑡titalic_t. If C𝐶Citalic_C is not simplicial, then C∩(C+t)𝐶𝐶𝑡C\cap(C+t)italic_C ∩ ( italic_C + italic_t ) is a (shifted) cone if t∈C𝑡𝐶t\in Citalic_t ∈ italic_C.

Proof.

If C𝐶Citalic_C is a simplicial full-dimensional cone, then it is the image of the nonnegative orthant under an affine isomorphism. Thus, it suffices to show that C∩(C+t)𝐶𝐶𝑡C\cap(C+t)italic_C ∩ ( italic_C + italic_t ) is a shifted cone for C=ℝ≥0d𝐶superscriptsubscriptℝabsent0𝑑C=\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}^{d}italic_C = blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let t^∈ℝd^𝑡superscriptℝ𝑑\hat{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}over^ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that t^i=max⁡(ti,0)subscript^𝑡𝑖subscript𝑡𝑖0\hat{t}_{i}=\max(t_{i},0)over^ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_max ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 0 ). Then

C∩(C+t)={x∣xi≥0⁢ and ⁢xi≥ti}={x∣xi≥t^i}=C+t^.𝐶𝐶𝑡conditional-set𝑥subscript𝑥𝑖0 and subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑡𝑖conditional-set𝑥subscript𝑥𝑖subscript^𝑡𝑖𝐶^𝑡C\cap(C+t)=\{x\mid x_{i}\geq 0\text{ and }x_{i}\geq t_{i}\}=\{x\mid x_{i}\geq% \hat{t}_{i}\}=C+\hat{t}.italic_C ∩ ( italic_C + italic_t ) = { italic_x ∣ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0 and italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } = { italic_x ∣ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ over^ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } = italic_C + over^ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG .

On the other hand, if C𝐶Citalic_C is an arbitrary polyhedral cone and t∈C𝑡𝐶t\in Citalic_t ∈ italic_C, then C∩(C+t)=C+t𝐶𝐶𝑡𝐶𝑡C\cap(C+t)=C+titalic_C ∩ ( italic_C + italic_t ) = italic_C + italic_t, and hence a shifted cone. ∎

Example E.7.

The converse of the second statement from Lemma E.6 does not hold, that is, t∉C𝑡𝐶t\not\in Citalic_t ∉ italic_C does not imply that C∩(C+t)𝐶𝐶𝑡C\cap(C+t)italic_C ∩ ( italic_C + italic_t ) is not a shfited cone. Indeed, let C=cone⁡((100),(110),(101),(111))⁢ and ⁢t=(011).𝐶cone100110101111 and 𝑡011C=\operatorname{cone}\left(\left(\begin{smallmatrix}1\\ 0\\ 0\end{smallmatrix}\right),\left(\begin{smallmatrix}1\\ 1\\ 0\end{smallmatrix}\right),\left(\begin{smallmatrix}1\\ 0\\ 1\end{smallmatrix}\right),\left(\begin{smallmatrix}1\\ 1\\ 1\end{smallmatrix}\right)\right)\text{ and }t=\left(\begin{smallmatrix}0\\ 1\\ 1\end{smallmatrix}\right).italic_C = roman_cone ( ( start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW ) , ( start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW ) , ( start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW ) , ( start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW ) ) and italic_t = ( start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW ) . Then C∩(C+t)=C+(111)𝐶𝐶𝑡𝐶111C\cap(C+t)=C+\left(\begin{smallmatrix}1\\ 1\\ 1\end{smallmatrix}\right)italic_C ∩ ( italic_C + italic_t ) = italic_C + ( start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW ) is a shifted cone. On the other hand, the choice t=(012)𝑡012t=\left(\begin{smallmatrix}0\\ 1\\ 2\end{smallmatrix}\right)italic_t = ( start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 2 end_CELL end_ROW ) yields the unbounded polyhedron C∩(C+t)=conv⁡((222),(212))+C,𝐶𝐶𝑡conv222212𝐶C\cap(C+t)=\operatorname{conv}\left(\left(\begin{smallmatrix}2\\ 2\\ 2\end{smallmatrix}\right),\left(\begin{smallmatrix}2\\ 1\\ 2\end{smallmatrix}\right)\right)+C,italic_C ∩ ( italic_C + italic_t ) = roman_conv ( ( start_ROW start_CELL 2 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 2 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 2 end_CELL end_ROW ) , ( start_ROW start_CELL 2 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 2 end_CELL end_ROW ) ) + italic_C , which has two vertices and one line segment as bounded faces.

E.14 Proof of Proposition 3.15

Proof.

Let 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q be any regular complete complex that is compatible with f𝑓fitalic_f. Then, g𝑔gitalic_g and hℎhitalic_h are as well compatible with 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q, since supp𝒫⁡(g),supp𝒫⁡(h)⊆supp𝒫⁡(f)subscriptsupp𝒫𝑔subscriptsupp𝒫ℎsubscriptsupp𝒫𝑓\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(g),\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(h)% \subseteq\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ) , roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_h ) ⊆ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) implies that supp𝒬⁡(g),supp𝒬⁡(h)⊆supp𝒬⁡(f)subscriptsupp𝒬𝑔subscriptsupp𝒬ℎsubscriptsupp𝒬𝑓\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{Q}}(g),\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{Q}}(h)% \subseteq\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{Q}}(f)roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ) , roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_h ) ⊆ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ). Let (g′,h′)∈𝒟𝒬⁢(f)superscript𝑔′superscriptℎ′subscript𝒟𝒬𝑓(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{Q}}(f)( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ). Then it holds that supp𝒬+⁡(f)⊆supp𝒬⁡(g′)subscriptsuperscriptsupp𝒬𝑓subscriptsupp𝒬superscript𝑔′\operatorname{supp}^{+}_{\mathcal{Q}}(f)\subseteq\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal% {Q}}(g^{\prime})roman_supp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ⊆ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) since wg−wf=wh≥0subscript𝑤𝑔subscript𝑤𝑓subscript𝑤ℎ0w_{g}-w_{f}=w_{h}\geq 0italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0. Hence, supp𝒬⁡(g)⊆supp𝒬⁡(g′)subscriptsupp𝒬𝑔subscriptsupp𝒬superscript𝑔′\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{Q}}(g)\subseteq\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{Q}}% (g^{\prime})roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ) ⊆ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and Lemma 3.10 implies that g𝑔gitalic_g is a coarsening of g′superscript𝑔′g^{\prime}italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and analogously it follows that hℎhitalic_h is a coarsening of h′superscriptℎ′h^{\prime}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore, (g,h)𝑔ℎ(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is a coarsening of every decomposition and thus by Theorem 3.11 the only vertex of 𝒟𝒬⁢(f)subscript𝒟𝒬𝑓\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{Q}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ). Clearly, g𝑔gitalic_g and hℎhitalic_h cannot have more pieces than f𝑓fitalic_f. ∎

E.15 Proof of Theorem 3.18

Before proving this statement, we give a description of the dual cone (𝒱¯𝒫+)∨superscriptsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫(\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+})^{\vee}( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∨ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Recall that 𝒱¯𝒫+≅⋂σ∈𝒫n−1{w∈𝒲𝒫∣w⁢(σ)≥0}superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫subscript𝜎superscript𝒫𝑛1conditional-set𝑤subscript𝒲𝒫𝑤𝜎0\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\cong\bigcap_{\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-% 1}}\{w\in\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}\mid w(\sigma)\geq 0\}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≅ ⋂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_w ∈ caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_w ( italic_σ ) ≥ 0 }, i.e., the intersection of the nonnegative orthant {w⁢(σ)≥0}𝑤𝜎0\{w(\sigma)\geq 0\}{ italic_w ( italic_σ ) ≥ 0 } with the linear space 𝒲𝒫subscript𝒲𝒫\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By duality of intersections and sums, it follows that (𝒱¯𝒫+)∨superscriptsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫(\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+})^{\vee}( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∨ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is isomorphic to the Minkowksi sum of the nonnegative orthant with 𝒲𝒫⟂superscriptsubscript𝒲𝒫perpendicular-to\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}^{\perp}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟂ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In particular, any w𝑤witalic_w with positive weights w⁢(σ)>0𝑤𝜎0w(\sigma)>0italic_w ( italic_σ ) > 0 lies in the interior. Theorem 3.18 follows from a general fact about face of polyhedra.

Lemma E.8.

Let C𝐶Citalic_C be a convex, pointed polyhedral cone and P𝑃Pitalic_P a polyhedron with recession cone C𝐶Citalic_C. Then u∈int⁡(C∨)𝑢intsuperscript𝐶u\in\operatorname{int}(C^{\vee})italic_u ∈ roman_int ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∨ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is a direction in the interior of the dual cone of C𝐶Citalic_C if and only if the face Pusuperscript𝑃𝑢P^{u}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of P𝑃Pitalic_P which is minimized by u𝑢uitalic_u is a bounded face.

Proof.

Let P=C+Q𝑃𝐶𝑄P=C+Qitalic_P = italic_C + italic_Q, where Q𝑄Qitalic_Q is a bounded polyhedron. Then for any direction u𝑢uitalic_u holds Pu=Cu+Qusuperscript𝑃𝑢superscript𝐶𝑢superscript𝑄𝑢P^{u}=C^{u}+Q^{u}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. As C𝐶Citalic_C is a pointed cone, we have that Cusuperscript𝐶𝑢C^{u}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is bounded if and only if u∈int⁡(C∨)𝑢intsuperscript𝐶u\in\operatorname{int}(C^{\vee})italic_u ∈ roman_int ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∨ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Since Qusuperscript𝑄𝑢Q^{u}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is bounded for any direction, it follows that Pusuperscript𝑃𝑢P^{u}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is bounded if and only if u∈int⁡(C∨)𝑢intsuperscript𝐶u\in\operatorname{int}(C^{\vee})italic_u ∈ roman_int ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∨ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). ∎

Proof of Theorem 3.18.

P=𝒱¯𝒫+∩(𝒱¯𝒫++f)𝑃superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫𝑓P=\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\cap(\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{% \mathcal{P}}^{+}+f)italic_P = over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∩ ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_f ) is a polyhedron with recession cone 𝒱¯𝒫+superscriptsubscript¯𝒱𝒫\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Applying Lemma E.8 yields that for any u∈(int((𝒱¯𝒫+)∨)u\in(\operatorname{int}((\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+})^{\vee})italic_u ∈ ( roman_int ( ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∨ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), every minimizer in π⁢(𝒟𝒫⁢(f))𝜋subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))italic_π ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) lies in a bounded face, which, by Theorem 3.8, are precisely the reduced decompositions. Moreover, if π⁢(𝒟𝒫⁢(f))𝜋subscript𝒟𝒫𝑓\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))italic_π ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) contains a unique vertex then by Proposition 3.14 this coincides with the unique minimal decompoition. ∎

E.16 Proof of Theorem 6.1

Proof.

In the convex case, this is literally proven by Hertrich et al. (2021). While Hertrich et al. (2021) have a slightly weaker bound for the nonconvex case, it follows from Koutschan et al. (2023, Thm. 2.4) that the stronger bound for the convex case also applies to the nonconvex case. ∎

E.17 Proof of Theorem 6.3

Proof.

Recall that a convex CPWL function can be written as the maximum of its affine components, that is, f⁢(x)=maxi∈[k]⁡aiT⁢x+bi𝑓𝑥subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑇𝑥subscript𝑏𝑖f(x)=\max_{i\in[k]}a_{i}^{T}x+b_{i}italic_f ( italic_x ) = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_k ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The idea is to split the k𝑘kitalic_k affine components of f𝑓fitalic_f into r𝑟ritalic_r groups of size at most s𝑠sitalic_s, apply Theorem 6.1 to compute the maximum within each group, and then simply compute the maximum of the r𝑟ritalic_r group maxima in a straight-forward way.

Let us first focus on computing the maximum of at most s𝑠sitalic_s affine components within each of the r𝑟ritalic_r groups. By Theorem 6.1, one can achieve this with a neural network of depth ⌈log2⁡(n+1)⌉+1subscript2𝑛11\lceil\log_{2}(n+1)\rceil+1⌈ roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_n + 1 ) ⌉ + 1 and overall size 𝒪⁢(sn+1)𝒪superscript𝑠𝑛1\mathcal{O}(s^{n+1})caligraphic_O ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). We put all these r𝑟ritalic_r neural networks in parallel to each other and add, at the end, the simple neural network computing the maximum of these r𝑟ritalic_r maxima according to Arora et al. (2018), which has depth ⌈log2⁡r⌉+1subscript2𝑟1\lceil\log_{2}r\rceil+1⌈ roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r ⌉ + 1 and overall size 𝒪⁢(r)𝒪𝑟\mathcal{O}(r)caligraphic_O ( italic_r ). Altogether, the resulting neural network will have the desired depth and size. ∎

E.18 Proof of Corollary 6.4

Proof.

By Lemma E.3, f𝑓fitalic_f can be decomposed into a difference of two convex functions which are compatible with 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. Consequently, each of them has at most q~~𝑞\tilde{q}over~ start_ARG italic_q end_ARG affine components. Applying Theorem 6.3 to both functions separately and simply putting the two corresponding neural networks in parallel, subtracting the outputs, yields a neural network representing f𝑓fitalic_f with the desired size bounds. ∎

Report Github Issue

Instructions for reporting errors

We are continuing to improve HTML versions of papers, and your feedback helps enhance accessibility and mobile support. To report errors in the HTML that will help us improve conversion and rendering, choose any of the methods listed below:

  • Click the "Report Issue" button.
  • Open a report feedback form via keyboard, use "Ctrl + ?".
  • Make a text selection and click the "Report Issue for Selection" button near your cursor.
  • You can use Alt+Y to toggle on and Alt+Shift+Y to toggle off accessible reporting links at each section.

Our team has already identified the following issues. We appreciate your time reviewing and reporting rendering errors we may not have found yet. Your efforts will help us improve the HTML versions for all readers, because disability should not be a barrier to accessing research. Thank you for your continued support in championing open access for all.

Have a free development cycle? Help support accessibility at arXiv! Our collaborators at LaTeXML maintain a list of packages that need conversion, and welcome developer contributions.
